PROCTEXT.PARA: (Budget Debate)
Debate resumed from 29 August, on motion by Mr Keating:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The topic under discussion in the debate on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1989-90 is the Budget. Yesterday I sat here and listened with interest to members of the Opposition umming and ahing and generally suggesting, as is normally the case, that the great problem that Australia faces is that this Government is such a high taxing government and that, while it is a good thing that we have produced a significant Budget surplus, this has been raised as a result of massive increases in taxation. The honourable member for Bruce (Mr Aldred), with his normal para-noia, suggested that the figures had been cooked. The honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) raised a number of issues and used figures which were not significant. He used gross receipts in taxation rather than relating the figures to gross domestic product (GDP) and growth that has occurred since this Government has been in office.

SPEECH.PARA: Because of the explosion of employment in this country there have been increases in gross tax revenue, but it is very important to put all these things in context. When one looks at revenue, the real figure that counts is revenue as a percentage of GDP. If we look at that figure we find that revenue this year and last year as a percentage of GDP was 26.2 per cent, exactly the same amount of revenue raised by the Government in 1981-82 and 1982-83, when the previous Admi-nistration had its hands on the levers of this country. At a time when we had a Budget deficit of more than $9 billion, the previous Administration was raising exactly the same percentage of revenue as a percentage of GDP that we are raising now.

The reason we have a significant surplus and the reason there has been such a signifi-cant turnaround is that we have been able to cut outlays significantly. We hear talk all the time about fiscal drag and how the Government has increased its revenue share, but if we look at the Budget Statements at page 4.42 we see this passage:

Following the cuts in personal income tax rates from 1 July 1989, taxpayers as a whole will pay less tax in 1989-90 than would have been the case if the tax rate scales in place in 1983-84 had been fully indexed for inflation.

So it is clear that indeed there has been significant improvement for taxpayers on an individual basis. This surplus we are seeing, which demonstrates a significant turnaround in the financial management of this country, has been brought about by cuts in government spending by a smaller, more efficient government sector which is providing targeted assistance to those people who most need it. It is easy with hindsight, I suppose, to think about the economic climate which existed when we came to office, but in 1983 all of the economic gurus were saying, `If you can do something about this domestic deficit, if you can do something about the public sector borrowing requirement, then you will have turned around the economy and the structure within Australia'. It was the view taken by all the economic gurus at the time that that was the first priority.

There were other competing priorities, of course-it was necessary for us to decrease inflation-but the domestic Budget deficit was the principal problem. We find that in 61/2 years that has been turned round from a deficit of $9 billion to a surplus of $9 billion, but it still is not enough. The balance of payments problem is a significant problem and indeed the strategy of the Government has led to a dramatic shift in the way in which Budgets are framed in this country. But that shift has not been enough, so it is necessary for us to continue a rigorous fiscal policy, a rigorous monetary policy, and to control wages in this country because there is more hard work to do.

If one looks at outlays one finds that, over four years, outlays have fallen in an unpre-cedented way, by 8.1 per cent. So the amount of money that the Government is spending on its programs has shifted dramatically downwards and we are now spending at the level we were spending at during 1972-73. If we continue this trend, in two years spending will be at mid-1950s levels and that will exemplify the sort of change that has occurred.

No government wishes to have high interest rates-they are certainly not popular any-where in the electorate-but it is an appropriate setting for them at the moment. It is an appropriate policy position and indeed if we were doing anything other than applying the interest rate policy we have at the moment we would be seen as being delinquent in our duties. It is the case, I think, that in politics it is very hard to win. If a position is taken which is seen as being hard on individuals, which is seen as being difficult, then the Government is seen as being cold and hard-hearted; if a position is taken where the needs and aspirations of others are satisfied, then it is being cynically political.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is like being a parent.

—It is like being a parent. I accept the honourable member for Wide Bay's response. It is very difficult to win. In a sense what a parent has to provide for his child is unconditional love and in the same way we on this side of the House are providing that sort of care and attention. It is harsh medicine but we have to deliver it to the Australian community.

SPEECH.PARA: When one looks at the other aspect of management, wages policy, what we are seeing in action at the moment in the pilots strike is indeed the policy of the Opposition in a microcosm. We are seeing a small group out there who would like to have a wage increase of 30 per cent. All of us in this community would love to have a wage increase of 30 per cent. But I suggest there are very few who would have that wage increase at the expense of the vast majority of people in this country. Very few in this community would want that increase at the cost of bringing Australia to its knees. I make the suggestion that the pilots are taking the position that they want a small wage increase, but they have a very high base wage and enjoy a very significant position of privilege. Their claim is at the expense of many other Australians. Our domestic and international prestige is suffering as a result. The solution suggested by the Opposition is to introduce more draconian laws in the wage structuring system. The response of the previous Go-vernment in 1982, which caused it problems, was not a deregulatory response or a collective bargaining response; it was a centralised response of a wages pause. If one were to try to sell a wages pause now, I suggest that it would be like trying to sell fridges to the Eskimos. One could not get away with it.

Having made those comments on the economy in general and on the stringency of our fiscal policy in particular, let me reinforce those points by referring to a comment made last night in Sydney by David Henderson, the head of the economics and statistics department of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development in Paris. Mr Henderson, in a speech made in Sydney last night, had something to say about Australia's fiscal policy. This was not said by some Government hack; this was not said by somebody who has a particular ideological leaning towards this side of politics; this was said by somebody from an internationally respected organisation, commenting on how he sees the way in which Australia has been restructuring over the last six years. This was his comment on fiscal policy:
. . . Australia is one of a relatively small group of countries that have taken major steps towards fiscal liberalisation across a wide front.

As we have said time and time again, one of the principal actions necessary for micro-economic reform in this country is the freeing up of the financial sector. What does Mr Henderson have to say about Australia in that regard? He said:

I think that in a comparative assessment of recent financial market liberalisation Australia has to be classed among the leading countries within the OECD, simply because of the extent to which reform has been taken.

Again we have a glowing endorsement of the policy structure which this Government has set up, the direction which it has taken, and, indeed, the course on which Australia has embarked. Within the setting of Budget priorities and within the setting of Budget parameters, it is necessary for the Government to determine priorities.

There are one or two particular aspects of policy which I want to pursue in the time remaining to me. The first is the very severe and growing problem that represents the most massive international epidemic which we face in this decade and perhaps in this century-that is, the problem of acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS). Yesterday the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) made a substantial statement in this place on the release of the Government's White Paper policy on AIDS.

TALK.START.PARA: —About two years too late.

—The honourable member opposite, who was previously the health spokesman for the Opposition, says it is two years too late. We must congratulate the Minister on the response that the Government has made on this issue. It is a very difficult, complex problem. The Minister has been acrimoniously attacked in a personal and a policy sense. I recently visited England and the Netherlands to discuss the issue of AIDS with a number of experts in those countries. I spoke about this issue with one of the most eminent people in the United Kingdom. After I had spent some days in the United Kingdom and some days in the Netherlands I said to him that I thought it was important that we in Australia learn what they are doing and it is important that we be able to integrate those things into our program. He said to me, `If you want to see a well thought-out, caring, imaginative, progressive strategy, then go to Sydney and see what they are doing there'.

SPEECH.PARA: It is clear from speaking to people all over the world that Australia's response to this problem is seen as being amongst the most progressive, caring and well developed in any country. We are fortunate to be in one sense isolated in Australia because it means we are able to respond to this problem in a very meaningful way and in some ways to control it. We have set significant priorities in education, prevention, treatment and care, research and our international response, and we see in this Budget a more than 40 per cent increase in the funding available to AIDS programs, a more than 40 per cent increase in areas which will provide for improvements in our education program, improvements in the way in which we spread the message of prevention and improvements in the care and treatment of people, and certainly it will provide for significant input into the area of research.

It is still the case that while there are improvements and advances in the treatment of AIDS we do not have a cure. It is important to understand that while we have made significant progress in the area of the homosexual community and, indeed, the infection rate and the incidence of the disease in that group of people is falling, we are particularly concerned about the new wave of AIDS, the so-called second wave, which is related to the intravenous drug-using community. It is important that our response in that area be dramatic and early. It is the case that all over the world intravenous drug users are increasingly making up the number of those people infected by AIDS. More than 60 per cent of those presenting in places like Edinburgh, and even in parts of New York, have received the infection by the intravenous drug-using route and it is very important for us to respond to that sort of problem.

There have been criticisms of the policy White Paper. There is a view that we should be taking a more liberal philosophy to intravenous drug users and indeed that the thrust of the Government is not as strong as it could be in that area. An intergovernmental committee has been set up and it will be looking into this issue. It has a number of references. One of them is to look into legal sanctions which might impede the changing of personal use patterns of drugs which are not administered by intravenous methods. This raises the question of the decriminalisation of substances like marijuana. In Sydney an ounce of marijuana is more expensive than the equivalent number of dosages of heroin, and if that situation means an implicit attraction for those who wish to be drug users to use the intravenous route rather than the other route, then it is something that we need to consider. The problem when one looks at the liberalisation of policies with regard to drug use is that health professionals are divided. There is a deep division amongst those who treat intravenous drug users as to which is the most appropriate response and so caution on the Government's part is understood. Clearly that is an area which needs considerable review and considerable interest has to be taken in it.

The last area I wish to raise is that of sports funding. The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, of which I am a member, was recently involved in a rather rapid but very thorough review of the funding of sport in Australia. That is an ongoing review. Members of this Parliament must know that we understand that this is not the most important issue that one deals with in this Parliament. There are issues of income, there are issues of education and health care, dramatic issues in industrial relations and issues in a whole lot of other areas, but certainly sport is something that affects the lives of most Australians in some way every day. Whether we sit and watch sport on the television, whether our children are involved in it, or whether we are in fact weekend warriors ourselves and part time participants, it is something which touches our lives and has a dramatic effect on our economy.

There is clear evidence that the financial impact of sport is very significant when one looks at the discretionary income of individuals and the amount of money which is turned over in our economy in that area. There are two areas in particular that are of concern and it is hoped that the injection of funding that the Government has directed towards sport will be spent in an appropriate manner. Certainly it is important for us to raise in schools, and in particular in primary schools, the status of physical activity. It is important for children to be taught the basics of running, jumping, swimming, catching and throwing-those things which can improve their enjoyment of life and their health in the long term. That is not to suggest that we have to make them into champions. What we have to do is provide them with the basics, the techniques, the opportunities to pursue an interest in sport, perhaps throughout their lives. Certainly it is the case that in many States we do not provide physical education teachers in primary schools and it is clear that that is an area we should pursue.

There were many criticisms of the way in which we were directing our finances at the elite end in particular to the Australian Institute of Sport. While the building of the Australian Institute of Sport was a worthwhile project and the direction taken was necessary, we do not need $100m worth of facilities in Canberra and fewer facilities in the States. Because of Australia's geography it is necessary for much of the funding that it is available in sport to be spent around this country. We cannot follow the model of a small European country or even the model that exists in the United States of America. We have to have a unique approach; we have to encourage initiative and talent; and we have to encourage the foresight and ideas that exist in the States. The Western Australian Institute of Sport and other regional based institutes of sport all over this country need increasing assistance. When we talk about spending money in the area of elite sport and in the area of development it is important that that money should be directed throughout this country and not just towards a huge institute based in Canberra which is not appropriate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I join the cacophony of voices in congratulating you on your election as Speaker and wish you success, in an impartial fashion, in the discharge of your new responsibilities.

—I thank the honourable member for Deakin. I am just surprised that he has not celebrated it with me in the way that he celebrated my election as Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure.
—Mr Speaker, with respect, your new responsibilities require you to be in the chamber during the adjournment debate. For that reason I did not think it would be appropriate to visit you last evening.

SPEECH.PARA: A series of threshold questions must be asked in order for the Australian people to decide whether the Government's 1989 Budget attempts to deal with the nation's serious economic and social difficulties. Does the Budget deal with inflation? The answer is no. Does it deal with our accelerating overseas debt? No. Does it establish an economic framework that will allow early reduction of our record commercial and housing interest rates? No, it does not. Does it provide incentives for the traded goods sectors? As the Budget increases taxation in these areas, the answer is certainly not. Does the Budget encourage export incentives? No way. Does it make any attempt to relate labour costs to productivity? No. Does it address the urgent problems of our inefficient transport infrastructure and the waterfront? Most certainly not. Finally, does it make any attempt to straighten out our convoluted and regressive taxation system? No.

What does this wretched document do? The answer is that it increases taxation on all and provides politically calculated handouts to some. One of the chief moral problems of modern-day politics is how to stop politicians bribing the electorate from the public purse. This Budget is a classic demonstration of that moral problem. We have the little team of Hawke and Keating and Richardson, the old Labor wheeler-dealers, the Boulevard Hotel boys, ratting the public purse for electoral purposes. There are the handouts for the youth vote, the handouts for the ethnic vote, the handouts for the pensioner vote, the handouts for the environment vote, and so it goes on. Is it any wonder that Senator Walsh, the only economically literate member of the Cabinet, wanted to resign when he saw the shape of this Budget's handouts?

The Budget makes no attempt to deal with our basic economic, social or strategic problems. It gives no shape to any program of economic reform. There is no outline of the future and no vision for the path ahead for Australia.

It is almost incomprehensible that the Government has made no attempt to deal with inflation. After forecasting a level of 4 1/2 per cent inflation by the end of last financial year, the Treasurer has now found the problem beyond his wits and estimates inflation at 7 1/2 per cent for the current year. Budget Paper No. 1 is 570 pages long. In that whole vast expanse of words and figures, inflation gets about 10 paragraphs-10 lousy, miserable, apologetic paragraphs. Inflation is wrecking our exports, creating turbulence in our labour markets, distorting our taxation system and crushing our national savings. What does the Treasurer do? He gives inflation 10 paragraphs, more or less in passing, in the major Budget document. The irony of all this is not lost on the Reserve Bank, which had this to say in its annual report, released around the time of the Budget:

The setting of incentives and disincentives at the microeconomic level has played a role in creating some of our present economic imbalances. Changes there are essential if we are to avoid a re-emergence in the next upswing of the problems of the past year-
in other words, the Reserve Bank is saying that the Government's labour market, taxation, infrastructure and waterfront policies are all wrong-

but the vital key is inflation. Restructuring is much more difficult, even impossible, in a high inflation environment which destroys competitiveness and discourages saving. Altering this situation must have top priority.

The Reserve Bank says that altering the situation must have not a little priority, not just some priority, but top priority. What priority do Hawke, Keating and Richardson, the Boulevard boys, give to inflation? No priority at all; it hardly rates a mention. In answer to a question asked of the Prime Minister in this House yesterday when he chose to compare what the Reserve Bank was saying with Government policies, did he mention inflation once? Not once. Yet the bank says, talking about inflation:
. . . the vital key is inflation . . . Altering this situation must have top priority.

Within a couple of weeks of its release, the Reserve Bank report has simply blown the whole Budget strategy out of the creek and into the bush. The Treasurer was not able to get to Simon Crean, his looming rival, before the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions said that he was disappointed at the Budget because he thought it had not tackled the inflation problem. The Reserve Bank goes on with this profound warning to the Government:

On its own, monetary policy will not produce the longer-term structural benefits Australia is seeking. Beyond a point, it may even inhibit the structural change because of the effect of high interest rates on investment of all types.
Sadly, it concludes:
Inflation appears set to remain above the average for industrial countries, even if demand pressures are contained.

The Budget strategy and its priorities have been disowned by the Government's own bankers. The policy of selective vote buying and high interest rates will not work. We all know, and the Press Gallery knows, that the Government's priority is not inflation but the next election. We all know that dealing with inflation will conflict with the electoral imperative.

The country's second major problem after inflation is our mountain of overseas debt. This problem gets about the same space in the Budget documents as does inflation. The message seems to be that we should not worry about our external indebtedness, which increased again yesterday, and that `She'll be right'. Unless the Government is prepared to do something about our overseas debt, she will not be right. Does the Government really appreciate that our foreign debt is growing at the rate of more than $50m a day? Is that the legacy this Government wants to leave to our children? The Government's attitude to our overseas debt is irresponsible and immoral. It is our obligation to expose this fraud on our children. The Hawke Government is stealing from our children in order to try to buy its way back to power. The Government admits that our overseas obligations will grow at least a further $181/2 billion this year, and then does nothing about it. Furthermore, the Government's estimate is based on the hope that commodity prices and world trade will hold up well this year. If, however, there is a fall in commodity prices and a downturn in world trade, our current account will deteriorate even further and we will then be, as Senator Walsh has predicted, well and truly down the Argentine road.

In normal circumstances it would be almost inexplicable that the Government has casually accepted that our current account deficit will once more climb to record levels. But these are not normal circumstances, because dealing with our overseas debt realistically would also interfere with Labor's electoral strategy. If it had the political will and the interests of all Australians at heart, the Government could have done many things to reshape the economy in a way that would allow us to escape the debt trap. It could have freed up the labour market. It could have ended the union hierarchy's monopolies in transport, communications and the waterfront. It could have reformed the taxation system to encourage productive investment and savings. It could have privatised some government businesses. It could have contracted out some government services. It could have fostered a production and export culture rather than a handout culture. It could have rewarded achievement and skill in our education system. It could have ceased fostering and funding single issue and social engineering groups, and it could have reduced the scope and intrusion of government in people's lives.

But, Mr Deputy Speaker-and I also take the opportunity to congratulate you on your election-this Government lacks the stamina, the political skills and the will to tackle these challenges or, indeed, any of the challenges. Despite the beliefs of the social engineers who inhabit Australian Labor Party branches and carry out Labor's welfare programs, governments by themselves cannot provide good and satisfying lives for their citizens. Government programs do not normally lead to the greater contentment and fulfilment of individuals or groups, and often make matters worse, as in the case of the creation of an underclass of younger welfare recipients. Social engineering of the kind promoted by Ministers Dawkins, Howe and Blewett does not generally work. It leads to conflicts with traditional and valuable professions. It diminishes the family. It politicises communities and genuine welfare agencies.

The Government's youth policies, for example, are generally regarded as a joke. The operations of the bureaucracies seem comical to most young people. Youth homelessness is an acute problem in our society, yet the Government does not seem to be able to come to terms with it and fails to understand that much of the problem flows from the social disorientation fostered by the Government's other programs and by the views of its social engineering ideological allies. The New South Wales Teachers Federation, for example, is a highly influential organisation within the Labor Party, supplying funds, ideas, programs and even parliamentarians. However, the views of the Federation on school discipline, on minimal core content and socially oriented courses, on work, on the causes of violence and on the family-all those views by that Federation contribute to youth alienation, lack of self-respect and poverty.

It is now characteristic of the welfare and social care industries in Australia that they have become seduced and preoccupied with government. There are, of course, noble exceptions, such as the Salvation Army and the Brotherhood of St Laurence, but many have gone where the big funds are-that is, to government. Accordingly, education, health and welfare have all become substantial clients of the bureaucracy with the resultant decline in the quality of service, in personal relations, in efficiency and in initiative. So the hunt is on for more government funds and programs and in this Budget, and in these documents attached to the Budget, we have them galore. The LATA scheme, the SAAP scheme, the CAP scheme, the LGACHP program, the adolescent mediation initiative, the JSA scheme, the YHA scheme, the Newstart scheme and dozens more-most of them with their funny acronyms-cost tens of millions of dollars extra. Those fabricated schemes and programs will not really work, of course, any more than they worked last time. We have even more schemes and programs trying to remedy the problems created by this Mad Hatter Government's present schemes and programs.

The Government still has not learnt the lesson that social engineering creates more problems than it solves. Genuine need should be met-and no-one disputes that genuine need should be met-with grants, vouchers, the contracting out of services and the encouragement of individual and community initiatives, not by the creation of extra layers of impersonal and expensive bureaucracy. In the training area there are now an incredible 30 or so Commonwealth training schemes. Some are unnecessary employer subsidies. Some are grants to social engineering activist groups. But all are costly and have their own mini-bureaucracies and many have been modified recently because their predecessor schemes simply did not work. Training and skills formation is expected to cost $516m this year. Job creation schemes and employment assistance schemes are expected to cost $123m. Administration costs under the heading of labour and employment-all these figures are from Budget Paper No. 1-are estimated to run to an incredible $436m, including the Commonwealth Employment Service, which the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) is yet again trying to revamp because it has not delivered jobs for our young people. As the Brotherhood of St Laurence and other genuine welfare groups have pointed out, the tragedy is that most of these schemes are useless. There is the Commonwealth rebate for apprentice full time training program, or CRAFT; the Australian traineeship system, or ATS; the industry training services program, or ITS; and the formal training allowance, or FTA; as well as the jobs, education and training program, or JET, and Jobstart and Skillshare, and the propaganda machine. No doubt there is a rash of new programs in the pipeline. The cost increases but productivity does not; neither does the effectiveness in getting our unemployed into jobs. It does not seem to have occurred to the Government that business, big and small, pays the taxes that fund these expensive and, in many cases, useless programs. It does not seem to have occurred to the Government that a reduction of up to $1 billion in taxes and charges on business might provide more incentive than some of these weird schemes dreamed up in the Gilbert and Sullivan world of Jobstart and Skillshare.

Mr Deputy Speaker, this was never a government of rags to riches but it has now become the government of rags and patches. It is a government dying of a thousand schemes and short term programs. It is a government that has lost its way and lost its vision. It is a government that in this Budget has fled from facing its responsibilities by failing to deal with inflation and our foreign debt. It is a government that has instead retreated to electoral handouts combined with social engineering. Ministers Dawkins, Howe and Blewett, with their thousand and one little schemes, are taking over from Hawke and Keating. It is a fitting judgment on this Budget to declare that the social engineers are taking over from the Boulevard boys.

I do not wish to comment on the address of the previous speaker, the honourable member of Deakin (Mr Beale), except to say I am sure quite a number of form 4 teachers around the country will use it as an exercise in unclear thinking. SPEECH.PARA: On Tuesday, 22 August, I had the pleasure and privilege of being a guest of the Wimmera Farm Tree Group and touring the upper reaches of the Wimmera River and its catchment lands to see at first hand the devastation caused by decades of unremitting tree clearance and inappropriate land management practices. The rate of land degradation in this and similar areas now constitutes the greatest problem facing Australia today. While farmers, environmental groups and the Government are determined to attack the multiple causes of land degradation, it cannot yet be said that the urban dwellers of this nation are adequately informed and concerned about the matter.

I know that many schools, particularly primary schools, are devoting much time to the issue and I recently joined the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) in a very pleasant visit to the Delacombe Primary School in Ballarat where the principal, John McManus, and a very dedicated staff are trying to instil in the children an active awareness of the problems besetting the Australian environment. John and his teachers, the parents of the children and the children themselves deserve our congratulations and they deserve our support, as of course do teachers throughout our schools. I exhort them to continue their efforts. May the children develop an even deeper understanding of the problems facing our environment, and commit themselves to putting them right. I only hope that is not going to be labelled an exercise in social engineering, but if it is then I am all for it.

I happen to believe that the restoration of our land cannot be accomplished by the farmers alone. The farmers will need government assistance, both financial and technical. Over time they will need more money than has been allocated. While it ought to be said that these are early days in the development of a planned attack on the immense problem of land degradation, the scale of the problem and the fragility of our soils cannot await a slow growth of commitment to save our soils. It has taken 200 years to reach this point. An area of 3 1/2 million square kilometres of grazing and arable land in this country is affected and the degradation is accelerating at a very rapid rate as the effects come through the soil systems.

If we are to have farmlands at all worth farming in 50 years or so the attack on the problem must be on a vast scale. This is where the urban dwellers need to come to understand this problem. It is not just a problem for farmers on the land or those in small rural service towns. The Australian population is the most urbanised on earth. Over 80 per cent of our people live in cities. The problems of land degradation are theirs no less than they are those of the farmers. The other day I spoke to farmers such as Jack and Vic Start, Jim Kilpatrick, Alan Holden and his son George. I saw the work which they are undertaking to provide leadership by spending considerable sums of money on and dedicating time to gully repairs, diversion banks, tree planting, pasture improvement, et cetera, but the problems are immense.

I am concerned to see that, even after a very intensive rabbit eradication program, if one looks across the farmland one sees a virtual carpet of rabbits, disappearing as one approaches. The threat of an explosion of the rabbit population is imminent. City dwellers do not recognise the horrific environmental damage done by rabbits. Adequate funding must be made available to the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) to ensure that the work on rabbit eradication by biogenetic means and other biological measures proceeds as rapidly as possible. I would like to think that honourable members on both sides of this House, who often are involved in many other issues, recognise that this is something on which we can take very much a bipartisan approach.

The farmers recognise that it is not simply a matter of government handouts to solve the problem because we are talking in terms of billions of dollars. We want an enormous amount of encouragement. We want urban people to marshal their forces-if necessary, to go out to country areas in volunteer teams to assist the farmers in the very large task of, for example, tree planting. I hope that something like that will arise and that people across the country will take up these schemes and get their communities involved, especially now that farmers are taking on the whole farm plan approach, which means that they are changing their whole farm and land management practices.

I reiterate that while this country relies so much upon farm commodities for its export-earned income it had better realise that they will be a dwindling resource, with dwindling revenue, if something is not done very quickly. In Victoria alone it has to be recognised that to maintain the level of productivity from our soil will cost an extra $50m per annum. That is just to mark time. That is the rate at which the problem is now growing. Across Australia it is costing us over $600m. In the Murray-Darling region alone it is costing $250m just to maintain the level of farm produce.

When people throughout Australia begin to recognise how significant this problem is they will begin to take some kind of position on it. I hope it will be a very positive position and one in which we can bridge the gap between the farm and the city. It is really everybody's problem. I make no bones about that.

I want to make a couple of other points. First, I would like to comment on the first home owners scheme. That was introduced on 1 October 1983, with the express aim of assisting low to moderate income earners to purchase their first house. It also was devised to give a stimulus to the home building industry and to create jobs. Honourable members will recall that when we came to office we were left with a legacy of the most serious economic downturn since the Depression of the 1930s. Housing starts had slumped to a record low of 105,000 and the ranks of the unemployed included thousands from the building industry. Alongside the community employment program the Government introduced the first home owners scheme. I hope that is not classified as social engineering. As a kick starter to economic growth the injection of funds into the building industry was a dramatic success. Not only did the building sector itself take off but the feeder industries also showed rapid growth.

From an economic standpoint the first home owners scheme was brilliantly conceived; from a social perspective it was also a winner. The conditions of the first home owners scheme were deliberately aimed at helping eligible first home buyers to get into a home as soon as possible through the grant. In other words, they were not required to have a deposit, which many of them would have found difficult to raise. Previously, under the Liberal-National Party Government, that was the case. It meant that low income people had great difficulty in getting into a home. The poor were virtually excluded. That is not terribly new when it comes to Opposition attitudes.

Since the introduction of the first home owners scheme, in my own electorate of Ballarat for instance, 2,693 applications had been approved as at the end of June. An amount of $11.4m has been approved and $10.1m has been paid out. As a result of this scheme many people have homes much sooner than they would have under the previous Government's programs. Even today the Opposition has no suitable housing policy. Its emphasis completely ignores the poor and concentrates on what it believes to be vote-catching opportunities. The main effect of its policies would be to push up the price of housing and leave very low income earners at the mercy of private landlords.

I know I am running out of time. I want to make a comment that the Government has a deliberate policy of assisting people in the low income area through rental housing, increased rental housing allowances, the family allowance supplement, Austudy and similar programs. I do not resile from supporting programs which are aimed at assisting the people who are out of work to develop relevant skills. I would have thought that honourable members on the other side of the House would have recognised that we are dealing with existing populations of people, many of whom left the school system early and do not have the adequate skills to be able to get themselves a job-to go out with something marketable. That is what these programs are on about. They are targeted at different age groups throughout the spectrum. The Government is concerned about these people. It has never resiled from assisting them. It will never do so.

The comments made by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Deakin, were somewhat irresponsible and very much those of a person who probably would tend to jump into his Rolls Royce and head back to Toorak, where he is not going to see a great number of the poor, and hope that the servants know their places.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset may I congratulate you, Mr Deputy Speaker, on your elevation to the Deputy Speaker's position. I would like to open my comments by speaking about various aspects of the Budget. Much of the fanfare of the Budget centred around a so-called domestic surplus of $9.1 billion. At first blush that sounds quite attractive but when we look at how that surplus came about we see that it is not so attractive after all. There are two ways of getting a surplus. One is by cutting expenditure and the other is by increasing income. In the case of the Government, this is done through increased taxation. Regrettably, it is the latter method by which the Government has come to record this Budget surplus for this year, because taxes have gone up by astronomical amounts, well over 100 per cent in the five years that the present Treasurer has been in place, and are forecast to increase by more than 10 per cent in the coming year. About $40 billion was collected in taxes when the present Treasurer took over not so long ago. This coming year about $91.3 billion is forecast to be collected. Expenditure overall is not being cut at all; in fact, it continues to climb to record levels.

SPEECH.PARA: The worst feature about the Budget was that the basic fundamentals remained untouched-the things that are today so crippling this wonderful country we live in. Inflation is predicted by the Treasurer to run at about 7 1/2 per cent in the coming year, and when that is compared with our overseas trading partners' rates, that bodes ill for us. One of the worst aspects is the high interest rates. We see a lot on television about interest rates at 17 and 18 per cent for home buyers, but let us not forget the small businessmen in this country and the farmers in particular, who are paying interest rates in excess of 22 per cent up to 26 per cent. These high interest rates are crippling the wealth producers of this country, and it is regrettable indeed that the Treasurer is following a one-dimensional policy. I know just what the severe effects of high interest rates are for the small businessmen and the farmers in my electorate of Parkes. The rates are hurting them and they cannot see why they should be penalised in this way to straighten out the economy, by having their enterprise penalised and wound back.

The current account deficit for the year past touched record levels in this country-$17.7 billion. I think it ran at a record monthly level for about eight or nine months out of the previous 12 months. All that the Treasurer can offer us is that it will set even higher levels in the coming year. He predicts $18.5 billion; so there is no joy there either. This all eventually translates back into the overseas debt, which, we were told yesterday, has just gone to a net of $108.2 billion dollars for the June quarter. It has risen by nearly $18 billion in the past year. This happened at a time when wool prices were high and buoyant, when beef prices were strong, when wheat prices were recovering, and when mineral prices had been running at high levels. Goodness knows what would happen if there was a serious downturn in these sectors.

There is no sign that the overseas debt will even stabilise. In fact, it is predicted to worsen, and I read one comment this morning in the newspapers that the net overseas debt could be about $130 billion next year. I remind the House that when Captain Cook arrived and set foot on Botany Bay, the overseas debt was zero. One hundred and ninety-five years later it had risen to the rather high level of $20 billion, and then the present Treasurer, Paul Keating, took over--

TALK.START.PARA: —When was that?

—In 1983. When the present Treasurer took over in March 1983, it started to skyrocket, and it has increased by in excess of five times, to $108 billion today. We are getting almost daily messages from independent commentators both within Australia and overseas condemning our economy and pointing out to us where we are going wrong, but the Treasurer washes his hands of this sort of information. We had Moody's report yesterday downgrading us from a AA1 credit rating to a AA2 rating. Only two or three years ago Moody's had taken away our AAA credit rating. We had the Reserve Bank recently writing a damning report on the way the Treasurer is managing the economy. Considering all these sorts of things, such as our AA2 rating, which is equivalent to what Spain has got, we are close to having the worst Treasurer in the world managing our finances. It will not surprise me if he comes into Question Time one day dressed like a matador.

SPEECH.PARA: The net overseas debt has gone from 13.8 per cent of gross domestic product to 32.2 per cent of GDP, and it is still rising. The interest payments that are going out of this country to service this overseas debt are running in excess of $1,000m a month, which is equivalent to more than 20 per cent of our export income today. If we take interest plus the contractual principal repayments that are due on this debt, the overseas debt servicing runs in excess of 60 per cent of our export income, and let us not forget that much of this debt is short term and needs to be rolled over regularly, so we are in a very vulnerable position.

The per capita debt in Australia today runs in excess of $7,000 a head, and while the Prime Minister tries to say that that is an irrelevant figure, it is nevertheless very significant. It is twice what it is in the United States, it is three times what it is in Argentina, it is four times what it is in Brazil, and it is 10 times what it is in the Philippines-and the Government somehow still cannot grasp the seriousness and the magnitude of this problem. The Government serves us up these inane and ignorant comments that it is paying off debt, that there is no net Commonwealth debt-as if it is likely that they are going to liquidate our international reserves-and they say that it is mainly private debt.

It is frightening that the Government does not seem to have a grasp of what the overseas debt is all about. It does not matter whose debt it is, at the end of the day it is Australia's debt. The private sector has been forced to borrow overseas because of Government policy-because the Government is running a low domestic savings policy in Australia, and because the Government maintains a tax advantage for debt accumulation, and because of the other policies that the Government is running. The Government has set an economic course which has forced increased borrowings by States and by the private sector, and this is the result of it.

The world's greatest Treasurer-when he took over-was downgraded in 1986 by the international Euromoney magazine to the world's second worst Treasurer, behind Egypt's financial Minister, Sultan Abu Ali, and I suspect that today he has even dropped behind him. Overseas independent observers are judging Australia very harshly indeed, and it is time that a more critical realisation of our economic state in Australia today was written about in the media. I will admit that the Treasurer has one marvellous quality. He can portray to the Australian people the impression that he is on top of it all and that things are panning out exactly as he would like, and because of his acid tongue and his ability to do this he seems to be bluffing the media in Australia, and many of the commentators, that he is doing a good job. I ask the House to look at his record. It is the worst record of any Treasurer that Australia has ever had. At the end of the day we have to judge a person by his record, and the record of our present Treasurer is the worst ever. I do not care how skilled he is or what he says; his track record, his runs on the board, are the worst that Australia has ever produced.

I now want to make some specific comments on Budget spending, particularly in the area of foreign affairs. I see that in the coming year we are allocated to spend $1,564m in the area of foreign affairs. Just to put that in perspective, that is some $350m more than the Federal Government will be spending on roads in the coming year. I question whether we have our priorities right in that area. There is, of course, nothing wrong with giving foreign aid, so long as it is spent properly. Australia has a proper and responsible role to play in regard to foreign aid. Unfortunately, I feel that much of this $1,564m is wasted or is even spent in a harmful fashion.

I will give a couple of examples about which I have had some personal experience. Both of the examples relate to the African continent. The first relates to Ethiopia. Ethiopia, of course, is portrayed in the Australian media as a flat, desert country, ravaged by drought, in which people are dying from starvation. Last year I had the remarkable experience of visiting a number of refugee camps in Ethiopia. One was in Asmara, the capital of Eritrea, which is the northern province of Ethiopia-the New South Wales of Ethiopia, if you like. That refugee camp contained 3,500 refugees-women and children. The men, of course, had been shot, conscripted into the army or had fled to fight with the freedom fighters against the brutal government. The refugees had come from the western towns of Tessenai and Barentu, mainly from the latter town. That had occurred when the Ethiopian military, which used to control those two towns, had had to withdraw because they had been hunted out of those two towns by the Eritrean Liberation Front. When the Ethiopian military withdrew they forced the remaining people, under threat of being slaughtered, to go to the refugee camp in Asmara. The people we saw there were mainly Kunamas from the town of Barentu. As the soldiers left that town they burnt 62 houses.

I note that the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) has entered the chamber. He was there with me; so he can vouch for what I am saying. We visited the refugees who were located in a soccer stadium in Asmara. It became apparent to me, as it did to the honourable member for Franklin, that they had been located there as a sort of honey pot to attract international aid, to show politicians from other countries, such as ourselves, and members of the United Nations who visit the country that aid is being distributed to refugees. No mention was made of the fact that these refugees were government created, that they were perfectly happy living in their own towns before they were herded into this place.

We saw Australian wheat being distributed in Asmara to refugees. The honourable member for Franklin and I both found when we spoke to the people in the town and others around the country, rather than to government officials, that much of the wheat and aid from other countries is sent to the Soviet Union to pay for arms. Seven billion dollars of arms have been sent to Ethiopia from the USSR. A lot of the wheat is also sold for profit. Some of it has even ended up in feed lots in South Africa. The money that is obtained for that seems to be lining the pockets of government officials in Ethiopia.

Most of the aid, particularly wheat from Australia, Canada and other places, seems to end up feeding the army. I remind honourable members that the Ethiopian Government maintains an army of 300,000 people. That is five times the total size of the Australian defence forces-Army, Navy and Air Force. Seventy-five per cent of that Government's budget is allocated to the army. The figure is almost 10 times higher than when Emperor Haile Selassie was overthrown in 1974. So at the end of the day only a small amount of the aid is used to feed refugees-government created refugees.

The regime in Ethiopia celebrated its tenth anniversary in 1984 by importing 450 tonnes of whisky from Great Britain for the celebrations. It is almost unbelievable. At the same time as its people were dying from starvation, and the regime was calling upon the world to provide aid, it spent over $100m on that one celebration. Colonel Mengistu, the leader of Ethiopia, has become the African incarnation of Stalin. Over a million people have died since he came to power. We are sending foreign aid to that country, much of which, I regret to say, is assisting to prop up this obscene regime. I have nothing against giving aid to those who are less fortunate than ourselves, but it should be given through private organisations such as the Red Cross, Catholic relief, et cetera, so that it can be properly distributed and accounted for. This sort of direct aid should be given only to genuine refugees.

The Budget Papers show that we will give another $110m to nine of the so-called frontline states in southern Africa. That is on top of the $100m that we have given over the last three years. We will have given these countries a total of $210m by way of government to government aid. All of the nine frontline states that are listed in the Budget Papers either are run by `military governments' or are one-party states.

Budget Paper No. 4 states that this aid is `aimed at offsetting the effects of apartheid'. All of the nine countries trade with South Africa. In fact, they conduct most of the trade with South Africa. Their trade with South Africa has increased in recent years. South Africa is the only country that is keeping these people viable. All of these countries have air links with South Africa. In fact, they get most of their handouts from South Africa. One has only to look at the record of South African aid to Mozambique. This aid is used to dredge its harbour, put goods through its ports and revitalise and protect the electricity generating dam at Cahora Bassa in the north.

If one looks at the document entitled Country Reports on Human Rights Practices for 1988, a document presented to the foreign affairs committees of the United States Senate and the United States House of Representatives, one will note the appalling examples it gives with regard to human rights atrocities in these nine frontline states. Zambia has had a state of emergency since 1964. People have been held in prison for years before being granted a trial. The persecution of Asians in this country is an indictment of that country's regime. I refer to the seizure of Asian goods, et cetera. It is a one-party state. Total censorship exists there. What is the position in Tanzania? The honourable member for Franklin and I visited that country last year. It is a one-party state where only one labour union is permitted. The Government owns all the media-radio, newspaper, et cetera. It has had in place a Ujamaa policy of forced settlement, equivalent to Ethiopia's villagisation program. It has plunged the country into desperation, poverty and misery. It runs a racist persecution of Asians policy which has halved the Asian population in that country over the last 10 years. Mozambique has public floggings, death camps, re-education camps, and no opposition is allowed. I will quote two or three passages from a book sent to me by two missionaries to Mozambique, Rodney and Ellie Hein. The book is entitled Mozambique: The Cross and the Crown. In that book they say:
We did see some sad incidents. We arrived at a certain village and found all the villagers in mourning. The Frelimo soldiers-
that is, the government soldiers-

had raided the village the day before, killing the chief and gouging the eyes of his son. Then they captured his son and all their cattle. Marxism destroys the traditional chieftainship system in Africa, and most of the people deplore this method of breaking down their customs and laws.

In Frelimo controlled areas, villagers are moved away from their homes and placed in communal villages or camps where they have collective fields. The communist soldiers take most of the food, leaving little for the people; thus, the problem of mass starvation. The people in Renamo territory told us they had been liberated from communism and were free to live together in their own villages as families used to, before the communist takeover.

I could quote more passages from this book. These are the sorts of countries to which we are giving aid and comfort. Quite frankly, I question the foreign policy that we are running in this country, which is costing the taxpayers of this country hundreds of millions of dollars in order to prop up these racist, brutal regimes.

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent Mr L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to take part in this year's Budget debate. It gives me the opportunity to congratulate the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on his seventh successive Budget, a Budget which sets in concrete Labor's achievements. Honourable members would know that I am not usually a flatterer. On the contrary, I have at times been critical of the Treasurer. On one occasion I gave vivid expression in this chamber to my criticism. However, I am amazed at the achievements of the Treasurer, who has turned an over $9 billion deficit that we inherited from the conservatives into an over $9 billion surplus in seven years, despite adverse economic conditions created by successive conservative governments.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that to most people Budget debates and debates about the economy are somewhat boring, especially in view of the fact that economists and politicians are using a jargon that makes the debate hard to follow for ordinary people. There would be few people listening outside or inside Parliament House to this debate who would know the precise difference between fiscal and monetary policy; macro-economic or micro-economic policies; the gross national product or gross domestic product; negative growth rate and such terms. So when I compare the policies of our Labor Government with those of the former conservative Government I will avoid the use of such terms that would escape the laic.

But one does not have to be a Rhodes scholar to understand the basic difference between the Hawke Labor Government and the Opposition when it was in government. The basic difference is that the conservatives by their criminal neglect of the Australian economy threw over a million people on to the scrapheap of unemployment while the Hawke Labor Government created 1 1/2 million jobs. We put Australia back to work. Every worker and employee, and indeed employer, in this country understands that. The conservatives do not like to be reminded of their negligence. When the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), was reminded of that the other day, he was quick to defend himself, saying that he was only an adviser to the then Treasurer, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), and as a public servant he cannot be blamed. So he puts the blame on Howard, Howard on Fraser, Fraser on the New Right, the New Right on providence, and so it goes.

Well, I ask then: who was guilty of causing the misery of unemployment and the untold suffering of millions of Australians? Of course, it was the ideology of the New Right that was to blame, an ideology which still forms the main plank of the Peacock-Hewson economic platform. The Opposition still advocates the same old New Right policies-to cut drastically government expenditure, which means cutting health expenditure, pensions, police, education, defence and so on, and thus starting an avalanche of unemployment. No thank you, the Australian people had enough of that experiment in 1982. I would be quite prepared to face my electors at the next election on this issue alone, and I do not have to worry about their verdict. But on every other issue also, be it pensions or the environment, the Hawke Labor Government is miles ahead of the policies of the Opposition, if it has any policies at all. However, I will return to this question later.

Now I would like to devote some of my time in this debate to an exciting new development in transportation-namely, the proposal to link Melbourne, Canberra and Sydney with a very fast train (VFT). Recently, by courtesy of the French Government railways, I was briefed and had the opportunity to travel on the TGV from Paris to Lyon. We travelled on the line, which is the forerunner of a French-European fast railway network, at 270 kilometres per hour. The 400-kilometre journey took exactly two hours from the centre of Paris to the centre of Lyon. The travel was more comfortable than first class air travel, safe, smooth and noiseless. The journey took less time than to fly, considering the travel to and from airports, it cost half of the air fare and was twice as fast as by motor car.

I think it would be accurate to say that in the near future Europe will be served by this new mode of travel and that the fast train will interlink the major population centres. I add also that the Paris-Lyon line-built and run by the French Government railways-is already profit-making after only six years of its existence and that it involved a major redevelopment of the centre of Lyon, with a new hotel, shopping centres and new railway terminal. In Australia a consortium, consisting of four companies-Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, Elders IXL Ltd, Kumagai-Gumi Co. Ltd and TNT Ltd-is engaged in a feasibility study to construct a new high-speed passenger transport system, linking Sydney, Canberra and Melbourne.

The proposed VFT, which was regarded by many with sceptical disbelief only a couple of years ago, will be travelling at 350 kilometres per hour. It will reach Canberra from the centre of Sydney in one hour while it will travel from Canberra to the centre of Melbourne in two hours. This means that it will connect our two largest cities in just three hours. It will provide safe, comfortable high-speed travel with continuous telephone and facsimile facilities for business people. There will be audio and video entertainment aboard, catering, and large windows to enable passengers to enjoy the scenery. It will be more roomy and comfortable than travel by air, just as fast, yet much cheaper. It will be three times faster than the motor car and provide absolute safety.

The VFT will be widely used by tourists and it will become a tourist attraction in its own right. I am certain that it will revitalise fixed rail transport, which has been neglected for too long by successive governments. Indeed, it will become a new mode of travel. It will also create jobs in the construction phase and when it becomes operational and it will assist in the development of new technology. As there will be numerous trains running daily, the capacity of the line being 150 trains a day-some connecting only shorter distances from main centres-the VFT, unlike its European counterpart, will provide exciting possibilities of development of outlying urban areas, satellite cities and regional centres all within the easy reach of the central business district of the metropolis.

As I said, the VFT is not only a new mode of transport but a tool to promote and speed up existing population and industrial development patterns or to establish new patterns altogether. Therefore, while accepting the project in principle, the State and Federal governments should satisfy themselves on a number of issues before giving their imprimatur to the project. There are a number of questions I would like investigated before we get carried away with our enthusiasm for the project. The first question I would like to examine is the type of ownership of the project, private versus public. In my opinion the Commonwealth and the States should enter into partnership with the private consortium. After all, in France the whole system is totally government owned and operated. There is also the question of what effect such enormous investment, $6 billion, private or public, will have on the rest of our rail system and whether it will lead to further deterioration of the existing rail transport systems.

One of the most important areas of the investigation should be the VFT's environmental impact. Its potential effects on our native fauna and flora should be thoroughly studied and where it is possible the detrimental effects should be alleviated. While I am certain that there will be some positive effects of the very fast train, like energy saving, reduction of road travel and the number of road accidents, and reduction of release of avgas into the atmosphere, there are a number of possible detrimental effects which need to be addressed. The route to be chosen is of extreme importance. The proposed route through Dandenong and Gippsland would pass close to newly proclaimed national parks, including the Erinundra Plateau and the Roger River Wilderness. Noise, fencing and all other effects on our native fauna should be seriously considered. Of course, the effect of the VFT on humans, its sociological impact, is just as important.

The very fast train will make possible daily commuting from Gippsland. Overnight it will transform Gippsland's country towns into dormitory suburbs of the central business district of Melbourne; it will do the same on the Sydney side. It will be possible to reach the centre of Melbourne from Warragul or Traralgon quicker than from Frankston. What possible consequences will result from such extensions of suburbia as far as Bairnsdale? Will the quality of life of commuters be better or worse than if they had remained closer to Melbourne? What amount of money is earmarked by the private consortium towards physical aspects and infrastructure such as roads, sewerage, electricity, gas and so on for the new development? How much will the private consortium invest in the cultural infrastructure such as schools, theatres, community halls and sporting facilities for the new communities? What effects will the influx of large numbers of people have on those who already live in these country areas, including the effect on the value of farmland which is subsequently earmarked for rezoning? These questions must be examined in a comprehensive manner before any decision to proceed with the line is made. It is important that decisions on development of the line and the towns alongside it be made on the ground of overall benefit to Australia and not on the profit to be made by the private consortium and land developers.

Land speculation along proposed railway routes is nothing new. During the planning and construction of the Melbourne suburban railway network, including the Dandenong-Gippsland line, in the latter part of the nineteenth century land speculation was rife. Far be it from me to suggest that politicians line their pockets, but I reveal that, at the time, six of the eight members of the Victorian Cabinet were directors of building societies or mortgage companies and many parliamentarians headed suburban land syndicates. Suburbs sprang up along proposed routes. Greedy developers subdivided land into postage stamp-sized blocks in areas remote from entertainment and services that those close to the city took for granted. In the summer months these densely packed and partly drained suburbs became breeding grounds for typhoid and other killer diseases. Fortunately today, with more adequate government regulations and better town planning, the worst consequences of land speculation are removed; but there remain important quality of life questions that need to be addressed.

There are also important implications for existing rural communities as the price of land along the route may be forced up to such an extent that farmers traditionally settled in country areas may not be able to afford to purchase new houses or retain their old houses and farms. They may not like to see their rustic way of life urbanised and destroyed. There is no doubt that land speculation along the route will be rife. The VFT project developers will be in the box seat to capitalise on land values because they will be in the best position to know, before anyone else, the exact route and the location of stations. The consortium itself admitted that part of the $6 billion investment in the project will be financed by land speculation or, as it chose to call it, land value capture. However, notwithstanding my cautious approach to the VFT project, I am an enthusiastic supporter of fixed rail transport in general and the very fast train in particular. I see tremendous possibilities in the future development of Australia being facilitated by the very fast train. I hope that all the problems that surround such a large scale project can be and will be overcome.

I welcome the Victorian inquiry into the project as well as the recently announced reference by the Federal Cabinet to the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure. I am only sorry that the New South Wales Liberal Government has not taken any interest in the project and is ready to give an open go to the developers. This once more illustrates that Labor governments are aware that we have to strike a balance between the need for development and the protection of the environment and that the community cannot afford to allow an absolutely free hand to speculators, who in the past had little regard for the environment.

This brings me back to the performance of the Labor Government, which has an excellent record on environment matters. The only blemish on our record is the mining and exporting of uranium, especially to France. On every other environmental issue, such as the saving of the Franklin River, the handing over of Uluru to its Aboriginal owners, the saving of the Daintree and Kakadu from devastation by loggers and miners, the stopping of the pulp mill that would have polluted Bass Strait and so on, the record of the Hawke Labor Government is exemplary while the conservatives opposed us on every move, from the Franklin River to the Daintree forest.

Let us have a look at social legislation. This Budget brought pensions up to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. It also increased the allowable earnings of pensioners before pensions are reduced, as well as making such earnings by pensioners non-taxable. The only criticism I can make of the Budget is that it did not provide for some form of mortgage relief for first home owners on average income and with average mortgages. Many are now struggling to meet their high repayments because of increased interest rates. I think it is unfair to let a section of the community-the young home buyers-who bought their homes after April 1986 carry the burden. I will continue to fight for easing of that burden through tax relief or interest rate subsidies. However, I remind those who are now finding it difficult to meet their mortgage payments that the alternative would be losing their jobs, if the Opposition's policies were implemented. One has only to remember the position in 1982, when people were not talking only about not being able to pay their mortgages. There were scores of people who could not pay their butcher's bills because they had lost their jobs. They did not have enough to feed their families. The situation was much worse under the conservatives.

The choice before the Australian people today is either to march with Labor into the twenty-first century as a united people, with an independent and self-reliant defence and foreign policy, with a restructured and free economy which will lead to prosperity, or to choose the discredited stop and go economic policies of the Opposition, to go back to high unemployment and high inflation, to relinquish our independence and rely on a powerful ally for our defence, and again base our economy solely on the export of commodities. I am sure that the Australian people will choose the path to independence and economic strength with Labor and reject the New Right policies of a discredited Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shack Mr P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Throughout this Budget debate we on this side of the House have seen Government members rise to their feet and vainly attempt to talk up the Budget and the Government. We can understand their motivation in doing that. In fact, the previous speaker, the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent), went so far as to say that this Budget set in concrete the achievements of the Labor Government. I would like to inform my honourable friend opposite that the only thing this Budget has set in concrete is Labor's demise at the next election. Many people on that side of the House will be making their last Budget speeches in this place, and I do not need to dwell on that matter too long. This Budget will herald the electoral demise of this Government, and the best thing we can say about it in overall terms is that it is Labor's last Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: As the shadow Minister for health I am going to spend the balance of my time in this debate talking about the performance of the Government in the health area, and I must say at the outset that on this benchmark alone the Government deserves to lose office. It has wrecked Australia's health system. When the havoc it has brought on our previously excellent and envied health system is coupled with its abysmal record of economic mismanagement, the Government can expect nothing more than a thumbs down, and a big thumbs down, from the electorate when it goes to the polls within the next 12 months.

We have only to look at some of the key economic indicators. Under Labor foreign debt has quadrupled and we are now in hock to the rest of the world to an extent never before achieved. Government spending in 1989 is 10 per cent higher in real terms than it was in 1983. The honourable member for Hotham, whom I regret has now left the chamber, found it difficult to understand the supposed great achievement of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in coming out with a $9 billion surplus. It is easy to understand when one appreciates that total taxation of individuals under this Government has more than doubled, from $23 billion in 1982-83 to $51 billion in 1989-90. This Government is able to achieve a surplus, even though government spending is 10 per cent higher in real terms, by taxing the heck out of us. That is exactly what it has been doing. Interest rates have reached record heights. People are struggling to pay their mortgages and the housing sector has been knocked for six. Inflation, which the Treasurer predicted in last year's Budget would fall to 4.5 per cent-that Budget, remember, would bring home the bacon-is now stuck at between 7 and 8 per cent.

The honourable member for Hotham cited what is supposedly one of the greatest achievements of this Government, the reduction in unemployment levels. Nothing is more certain than that under this Budget, in the economic circumstances we are now experiencing, we are about to go into a recession and unemployment will steadily and inexorably climb. Do not take my word for it. Just this week Moody's Investors Service Inc. in the United States turned in yet another bad report card on the state of our economy and our credit rating. We are now a higher risk for international lenders than ever before. I say with chilling confidence, when I make my comments about unemployment, that the economy has now been dealt a king hit by the pilots strike, a dispute which has been exacerbated by the intemperate intervention of one man, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke).

TALK.START.PARA: —What nonsense.

—The impact of this dispute on our economy-and the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories will know that what I am about to say is absolutely the case-is something which should not be underestimated. Already it is costing the airlines millions of dollars a day; but worse, as the Minister was reported in the weekend press as saying, it is causing tourism to lose at least $5m a day in foreign exchange earnings. The Minister knows that bookings around the country are being cancelled by the thousands. Yesterday tourist industry sources said that they were losing $56m a day and the Australian Tourism Commission said that the loss could reach $600m. Tourism, again in the words of the Minister, last week had reached the point where it was our greatest foreign exchange earner, our greatest export industry. It has been knocked for six by this pilots strike, a strike which has been exacerbated by the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: By any measure which one cares to apply, we are now in a disastrous situation. Our debt is at record levels. Our biggest problem is the month by month current account deficit, where what we earn by way of exports is less than we pay out for imports. Our debt is increasing on a month by month basis. We have been relying on the tourism industry, along with wool and wheat and our mining industries, to help us turn that situation around. We have been kicked in the guts now, and our tourism industry is not going to make the contribution that we were relying on it to make. Our debt situation is going to get worse and worse and worse. Quite frankly, we are in bad shape and it is going to get worse. All the economic indicators clearly point to the fact that on any net analysis Labor's performance in the past 6 1/2 years has been appalling. This Government has a record that no-one in his right mind would want to claim, and between now and the next election, before its ultimate demise, that is going to get worse.

Let me return to my own shadow ministerial responsibilities and look at health in the context of this Budget. The Budget provides for an appropriation of almost $11.8 billion for the delivery of health services, which is the second largest single Budget item after social security. In the current financial year outlays on health will represent 13.6 per cent of total Budget outlays-up by 0.5 per cent on last year's Budget outlays. Chart 4 on page 317 of Budget Paper No. 1 shows that in the period 1989-90 to 1992-93 estimated real expenditure growth in the field of health is expected to outstrip that for all other areas of Federal Government activity. We are spending billions of dollars on health. Let me try to put it in some context. It is interesting to note that in the 1982-83 Budget, the last Liberal-National Party Budget, Commonwealth health outlays were $3.4 billion, or 6.9 per cent of total outlays. Expenditure now has risen to 13.6 per cent of outlays and we are now spending $8.3 billion. That is how much the Government now needs to fund its Medicare health system. For such an enormous additional amount of money, up from $3.4 billion to $8.3 billion, it is not unreasonable for the community to expect a far superior level of service. But what is the case? Indisputably, the answer to whether we are getting a better service is a resounding no.

In 1982-83 where were the pensioners who were desperately in need of surgery to remove cataracts or replace damaged hip and knee joints, all of which impact upon their ability to retain their mobility and to lead independent lives? I can tell the House one thing: they were not at the end of the hospital queues we have attendant on every major public hospital around the country. It is estimated that there are now 100,000 people in our community, commonly the aged, awaiting important elective surgery to improve their quality of life. When we were last in government they were receiving the care, treatment and attention they required at the time they needed it. Where were the industrial disputes which now plague the public hospital system on an almost daily basis? As I move around the country, spending most of my non-parliamentary time inquiring into the health care system, I am enormously impressed by public health officials, public health authorities, administrators and those doctors and nurses who work in the public health system who say to me, `You have to do something about Medicare.
