The current imbalance between the public and the private sectors is not working, we're getting less money than we need to fund the demands that are now being placed upon us, and we can't cope with those demands'.

Where were the general practitioners six to seven years ago? They were in their surgeries attending to their patients, as they should. They were not fighting against a government which has attempted to conscript them, against their wishes and without due consultation, onto some sort of vocational register. Where were the private hospitals six or seven years ago? They were out there in the community using their resources to the full in the interests of patient care. They were sharing the burden of delivering hospital care with the public sector. Where are they now? While the public sector cannot cope, private hospitals are struggling with rising costs and empty beds. The public hospital systems are under so much pressure that they cannot provide the beds for those who so desperately need them.

Where were the health insurance funds six or seven years ago? They were in the market place providing adequate security and protection for 61.5 per cent of the population. Sixty-one and a half per cent of the population were privately insured. Where are the funds now? Their contributor numbers have dwindled to 45.8 per cent of the population. Their proportion of high risk, high claiming contributors has gone through the roof. Their contribution rates have been pushed up, further squeezing out members of the community who simply cannot afford the rising contribution rates and deterring new members from even considering private health insurance. In short, the ability of the private health funds to hold their heads above water has been seriously undermined.

So what has Labor's massive increase in health spending brought about? It has brought about unprecedented industrial trouble in health care. It has brought about a chaotic and hopelessly overloaded public hospital system. I invite honourable members opposite to go to their nearest public hospital and talk to the administrator, the medical registrar and the nursing registrar. They will tell them that they simply cannot cope. There is a vast imbalance in the system and it is not working. It has brought about an unstable health insurance industry. Where once 60 per cent of the population was privately insured, we are now down to 45.8 per cent.

This week we have dramatically seen-and I am sure that they are knocking on your door in the northern suburbs of Perth, Mr Deputy Speaker-a pharmaceutical benefits scheme which is perilously close to collapsing while this Government ruthlessly attacks pharmacists. The bottom line for Medicare, the cruellest irony of it all, is that it brought about a lower level of service for the sick, the aged and the infirm. Medicare is nothing more or less than a public health insurance system. The very people a public health insurance system should be looking after are the aged, the infirm and the disadvantaged-those people who have no other choice and for whom private insurance is not an option. The very people it should be looking after are the people who are getting less service and who are being pushed further and further to the back of our public hospital waiting lists.

All the rhetoric about budgets bringing home the bacon is simply not matched by reality. It is certainly not matched by reality in the health area. The reality is that the massive blow-out in health costs under this Government has not brought the community anything resembling a masterpiece. To use an analogy similar to `bringing home the bacon', it has saddled the country with a pig in a poke. I wish to take the pharmaceutical benefits scheme as an example. This Budget implements the moves foreshadowed in the April economic statement to achieve savings in the pharmaceutical benefits scheme of $31m this financial year, $96m in the next financial year and $156m in 1991-92. All of this means a cut in expenditure of $283m. The first point to make about this is that ripping $283m out of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, most of it coming from the remuneration package of pharmacists, would not be necessary at all if the Government were willing to face up to the real cost pressures in the health portfolio.

Let us not talk about bringing in money from any other portfolio; let us talk about just the health portfolio. There is an absolute cost explosion which has been caused by Medicare and total medical and hospital benefit outlays have risen from $4 billion to $11 billion. The Government is ideologically unwilling to admit that there is something wrong with Medicare, ideologically unwilling to admit that there is an imbalance between those privately insured and those insured by Medicare, and ideologically unwilling to admit that there is an imbalance in the utilisation of public and private hospitals. The public cost is simply exploding. Instead of trying to do something about that public cost, trying to bring about a better balance between publicly and privately insured patients and trying to bring about a better utilisation between public and private hospitals, it is containing costs at the margin. It is trying to squeeze doctors' fees. It is trying to squeeze pathology fees. Now it is trying to rip the guts out of the pharmaceutical industry and, importantly, slash the remuneration package for pharmacists. This is an absolute outrage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you support the Tribunal?

—The pharmaceutical benefits scheme is a publicly subsidised health care scheme in this country, one which we support. But the Government cannot deliver that scheme by itself. It relies on community based pharmacists to deliver the scheme for it. The Government and the community based pharmacists should be in a partnership relationship to see that this scheme is delivered on behalf of the Australian public. Instead of that cooperative partnership there is an `us and them' mentality. The Government, unwilling to face up to the problems that Medicare has caused, is wheeling on the pharmacists, ripping off $283m and slashing their remuneration package, when what it should be saying to pharmacists is, `You are in partnership with us. We are asking you to discharge a very important responsibility on our behalf through your pharmacies and deliver a very high standard of drug availability and access and general health care to the Australian community. The very least we will do for you is remunerate you fairly and properly'. That is what the Government should be saying, but it is not saying that.

SPEECH.PARA: There are solutions to be found in the health care industry. They include retaining and improving Medicare as a public health insurance system. That is what we intend to do. At the end of the day we should focus our system on the aged, the poor and the disadvantaged. They have no choice. The Government should encourage the rest of us to go back into private health insurance by abolishing the separate Medicare levy and offering people a taxation rebate to assist them with their private health insurance contributions. This solution is not an ideological binge from the Right; it is about recognising that the public health insurance system's responsibility is to look after those who have no other option-the aged and the disadvantaged. That is what Medicare should be doing. At the same time the Government should encourage the rest of us to go back into private insurance, to get those insured numbers back up from 45 per cent to around the 60 per cent level that we enjoyed earlier in the 1980s. When we have 60 per cent of the population privately insured we have a better balance between the public and the private hospital sector. It stands to reason. For every person who drops out of private insurance now there is an increased demand on the Commonwealth budget and another person is potentially in the queue of a public hospital. The hospitals cannot cope, and the reason they cannot cope is that the Commonwealth Government is cutting back on funding to the States. We have a recipe for an absolute crisis and disaster.

Medicare is terrific as long as one never gets sick but once one does get sick and needs a public hospital bed it is not available. That is why we have to go down the route of achieving a better balance. If we achieve that better balance and contain Medicare costs there is no justification-in answer to my friend, we do not support the Tribunal-for attacking pharmacists. All the changes to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme are not health motivated. They are simply in place to try desperately to rip money out of the system to pay for Medicare which, at the end of the day, is absolutely unsustainable and must be reformed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brumby Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Budget we are discussing today is the seventh Hawke Government Budget. It is a Budget which returns a surplus of $9.1 billion. In this respect it stands in stark contrast to the prospective $9.6 billion deficit which we inherited in our first Budget year of 1983. Today I want to talk about this Budget and previous Budgets and their impact on the Federal electorate of Bendigo. Because of Hawke Government policies, in conjunction with a number of local initiatives which I have recently proposed in Bendigo, I am confident that within two years Bendigo will achieve near full employment. When I was elected to Parliament in 1983 Bendigo had an unemployment rate in excess of 10 per cent. Some estimates put the figure at 14 or 15 per cent or even higher. Today the Australian Bureau of Statistics figures for the northern region of Victoria suggests that Bendigo's unemployment rate is around 6 1/2 per cent, which is still too high but it is a vast and dramatic improvement on the double digit figures which existed when I was elected in 1983.

SPEECH.PARA: The recent demographic report of the 2020 study being undertaken in Bendigo by the Loddon Campaspe Regional Planning Authority confirms that Bendigo has well and truly turned the corner. What the report says is that in the late 1960s and 1970s Bendigo was a dying city. We had little population or work force growth and there was net migration away from Bendigo to other regional centres and capital cities. According to the 2020 report, the picture in the 1980s has changed quite dramatically. Bendigo as a city is alive and well and, far from losing population, the 1980s has been a period of solid population growth.

For the first time in nearly two decades, there has actually been net migration to Bendigo. What the statistics show is that significant net migration to Bendigo has been under way over recent years. A balanced mix of young people, working families and retirees are moving there because of the opportunities our city provides. We have had our problems on occasions, and the tragic loss of Mayfair comes immediately to mind. But, most importantly, we have turned the corner and must now plan ahead and develop new strategies to take Bendigo confidently and prosperously into the 1990s.

In this Appropriation debate, I want to broadly outline the strategic development plan which I believe can take Bendigo into the 1990s. It is a plan which maximises our economic potential and takes full advantage of development opportunities in industry, tourism, agriculture, education, defence, construction and the environment. It is a 10-point plan and I am confident that it can be achieved. With its achievement will come a stronger and more vibrant Bendigo economy than we have known for many decades.

Let me detail the key aspects of this plan. First, Bendigo urgently needs a revamped, more highly powered and better resourced local development committee. The new committee will require some element of planning powers and the full cooperation of local government organisations in the area. Work is already under way on a possible new structure for such a committee and I am fully optimistic that State government funding of at least six figures will be approved for such an organisation.

The second part of the plan relates to education. Over recent months I have been arguing strongly for the relocation of the Latrobe University School of Agriculture to the Bendigo College of Advanced Education. There are strong grounds for such a transfer and I believe it will take place. The location of the School of Agriculture in Bendigo offers direct benefits in the shorter term and will provide the potential for further developments in the areas of research, salinity programs, food processing, industry extension services, and so on, into the future.

Point three of the plan involves the appropriate preservation and recognition of Bendigo's unique goldfields heritage. When I run into people who have visited Bendigo while on my parliamentary duties around Australia, they always comment on Bendigo's magnificent buildings. According to historians, we have the finest collection of goldfields buildings, streetscapes and mining technology anywhere in Australia. We need to better preserve this heritage and then, having put in place appropriate conservation strategies, aggressively market our heritage as the major plank of our tourism strategy. My proposals for the redevelopment of the View Street precinct, in conjunction with plans now under way for World Heritage recognition of the goldfields region, will not only make Bendigo a better place in which to live but also immensely strengthen our national and international tourism effort.

The fourth key element of the plan concerns the tanning industry. For more than three years I have been working towards the establishment of a fully-fledged, high value added, export oriented tanning industry in Bendigo. With the final feasibility report, which has been funded through the local government development program, on this subject soon to be released, I am hopeful that in the near future we will see a firm commitment made to the establishment of such an industry in Bendigo on a substantial scale. It is, I think, a matter of major national concern that of the 10 million to 15 million sheep skins which are suitable for wool-on tanning each year in Australia, only two million to three million are tanned in Australia, with the balance being exported in a crudely preserved form. There is an opportunity there for Bendigo, and Australia, and I hope that we can take it.

Point five of the plan calls for the construction of a Commonwealth office centre in Bendigo. Again, this is a project on which I have been working for some years. In this Budget, funds were approved for the purchase of a site for such a centre. Work is proceeding rapidly and I have indicated to the Minister that I would like plans to be submitted to the Public Works Committee in May next year, with a Budget appropriation for construction to be announced in next year's August Budget. I am fully confident that this timetable can be achieved, which will bring with it at least $6m worth of construction activity to the local economy.

Good transport links to Bendigo from Melbourne are essential to our future industrial and tourist development, and so point six involves the continuing reconstruction of the Calder Highway. In this Budget, $1.3 billion has been allocated to roads and I am delighted that over the next two trienniums until 1995 some $70m has been allocated to continuing improvements to the Calder. I can say with absolute confidence that by 1995 the vast majority of the Calder will be either double-laned or duplicated highway.

Point seven involves the responsible development of the Bendigo goldfields. It is something of an irony-a tragic irony-that at a time when Australia is producing more gold than at any other time in our history, Western Mining Corporation Ltd has withdrawn from, and effectively locked up, the Bendigo goldfields. It is imperative that a limited number of other reputable goldmining companies be allowed access to the lucrative Bendigo fields so that we can maximise employment opportunities. With proper management, Bendigo can sustain gold mining and, at the same time, conserve the best examples of our goldfields heritage.

The defence industry is vitally important to Bendigo's economy. With the Bendigo facility of Australian Defence Industries winning around $100m worth of work from the new Anzac frigate project and the Army survey unit at Fortuna in line for a new $2m printing press and printing room, the future is sound. Point eight of the plan requires an ongoing commitment by government to the location and development of these enterprises in Bendigo. I am pleased to say that such a commitment has already been forthcoming.

Point nine concerns the environment. I have already explained how proposals for the redevelopment of View Street and World Heritage recognition of the goldfields will significantly strengthen our economic base. Both proposals will also enhance our living environment. Our efforts in salinity research, revegetation and waste recycling are already commendable. By building on these efforts, utilising government and private sector resources in conjunction with strong community involvement and support, we will be able to ensure that Bendigo is at the forefront of environmental change in Australia. With the right commitment and strategy, we can be in a position within just a few years where people from all around Australia will visit our region to see at first hand the right way and the best way to reverse land degradation and recycle industrial and household waste.

The final point in the 10-point plan looks well into the future. In 2001, Australia will celebrate the centenary of Federation. In many ways, this will be a bigger event than the bicentenary of European settlement. Bendigo played a key role in the development of Federation-through the evolving political processes of the goldrush era and through the work of one of the Constitution's most notable founding fathers, Sir John Quick, who lived in Bendigo. Within the next year, we need to establish a high level working party to develop a strategy to ensure that Bendigo plays a major role in the centenary of Federation. It may well be that Bendigo could become the site of Australia's first constitutional museum and, in so doing, guarantee us high visitor and tourist levels throughout the latter part of the next decade, leading up to 2001.

When the 10-point plan I have enunciated is considered alongside other major projects presently under way in Bendigo, such as the Chinese Museum, the Capitol Theatre, the Linear Park, the new kitchen for the Bendigo Base Hospital and the development of a master plan for Bendigo senior secondary school, there is no doubt that Bendigo has the opportunity and the potential to enjoy a vibrant and prosperous next decade. Let me also stress that the proposals I have outlined are not mutually exclusive. They should be viewed in conjunction with ongoing efforts to attract new industry to Bendigo and to improve continually our quality of life by providing new services for our families and our elderly population. It is clear that achievement of this plan will require local cooperation and a commitment to common objectives. The potential rewards are indeed significant and will mean not just a stronger, more broadly based economy offering better opportunities and more jobs but also an immensely richer environment in which to live and spend our leisure time. I certainly commend that plan to the House.

On a more general basis in relation to the Appropriation Bill, I take up some of the comments made by the previous speaker, the shadow Minister for health, the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack). In his contribution the honourable member criticised quite stridently the system of national health care delivery in Australia, the Medicare system. I want to take up a couple of points he mentioned. He said that waiting lists did not exist in the last year of the Fraser Government in 1981-82 and leading into 1983. That statement is not true. It is a false statement. In fact, as many speakers in this House would know from recent debates on this matter, waiting lists have been an inherent element in Australia's health system for the past three decades. If we go back to the Gorton Government in the 1960s, we find reports commissioned at the time on the problem of waiting lists in Australia's hospital system. They have existed from the 1960s, they have existed under Liberal governments, under Labor governments, under the Fraser Government, and they exist now.

The recent inquiries that have been undertaken by various State and Federal authorities into the question of waiting lists have not concluded that Medicare is the cause of those waiting lists. What they have concluded is that the ageing of our population and the rapid changes in technology-for instance, those allowing cataract and hip operations, which certainly were not available on the same scale or for the same cost in the 1960s and 1970s-have led to a big increase in demand for operations of that type. In relation to Medicare, the honourable member for Tangney is out of step with public opinion. When this Government introduced Medicare in 1984 surveys done by Australian Nationwide Opinion Polls Pty Ltd (ANOP) showed that around 52 to 53 per cent of the Australian population supported the Medicare system. I am pleased to say that surveys done late last year and early this year have found that almost 70 per cent of the Australian population now supports the Medicare system. In other words, more than two-thirds of Australians-more than two out of every three Australians-believe that the Medicare system is a good system of health delivery in Australia. I guess most pleasing about that survey work undertaken by ANOP was the fact that 93 per cent of Australians surveyed in relation to Medicare expressed their approval of the efficient and courteous way in which Medicare processed health claims. In other words, there is not only a high degree of satisfaction with Medicare in the community, there is also a high degree of satisfaction in relation to Medicare's efficiency and the service it provides over the counter.

The honourable member for Tangney also failed to mention that during the period of the Fraser Government, if I remember correctly, in seven years we had seven different health schemes. The Fraser Government could not ever decide on a scheme which was suitable for Australia. They averaged a change once every year and, as I have said, waiting lists were just as much a phenomenon of the health scheme in the 1970s as they have been in the 1980s. Recently an eminent professor of medicine from Harvard University visited Australia and what he had to say about the Australian health system was totally positive and supportive. He described our health system in glowing terms and said that to see a vibrant, positive, cost-efficient health system people should visit Australia, because that is where one of the best health systems in the world is located. He said that our system was much better than the system in the United States.

In response to an interjection the shadow Minister said that the Opposition did not support the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal. I would be interested to hear in this House the policy of the Opposition in relation to this Tribunal and all the other wage and policy setting tribunals that exist in Australia. We have seen in recent weeks the Opposition toing and froing over the pilots dispute. One minute it believes the pilots should be part of the centralised system, the next it believes they should be outside the system, consistent with the Opposition's already announced industrial relations policy. The Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal is there as an umpire. It has made a tough decision. I am not happy with the decision-I think it is a tough decision-but the Tribunal has been set up to be an independent umpire and if a tribunal is set up to be an independent umpire I think it is incumbent on all the parties to accept the umpire's decision.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I opened my remarks in this debate by referring to the substantial Budget surplus this Government has delivered. I mentioned that it was $9.1 billion. It is a surplus which is equivalent to 2.5 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP). It will not only be the third consecutive Budget surplus, but it will also be only the third surplus in the 37 years for which comparable records are available. As I indicated previously, it contrasts absolutely and dramatically with the situation left to us by the Liberals-a prospective deficit of $9.6 billion. The important feature of the surplus is that we have achieved it without increasing the level of taxation. That is the easy way to record a Budget surplus, and what is pleasing about this Budget surplus is that it has been achieved through producing smaller government, better government, by improved targeting of programs, and by restraining the growth in outlays.

I see the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) smile when I mention that this has been achieved without increasing tax levels. If the honourable member would like to look at the average level of taxation as a proportion of GDP in this Budget, which is 26.2 per cent of GDP, he will find that it is absolutely identical to the level of taxation which applied in 1981-82 and 1982-83 under the Fraser-Howard-Hewson government. It is exactly identical: 26.2 per cent of GDP. So we have turned around that $9.6 billion in the red to $9.1 billion in the black without increasing taxes. We have done it by cutting programs that are not necessary, by better targeting of programs, and by taking all the tough decisions in the national interest that the Opposition never had the courage to do for the seven years of the Fraser Government.

We have got spending down now to its lowest level in 16 years, and if spending priorities do not change in the future we can say that in next year's Budget we will have outlays as a proportion of GDP down to their lowest level in more than 20 years-in fact since the 1950s. That will be an achievement. That surplus contributes to the national savings. It indicates that this is a responsible Budget which will improve the living standards of Australians. It will allow us to repay debt and over time it will reduce inflation, our trade deficit and interest rates, and I commend it to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to follow the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby) and I look forward to responding to the various specific allegations he made about the Budget. I want to open by making reference to an article last week in a South Australian newspaper, the Adelaide Advertiser. In just one small paragraph there was recorded the fact that the honourable member for Kingston (Mr Bilney) and the pretender to Kingston, Senator Haines, had shared a meeting at the Flinders University campus. Senator Haines, as she is wont to do, had successfully captured the imagination, if one is to believe the Advertiser, of the students present by referring to the honourable member for Kingston and to the Liberal Party's candidate as having Tweedledum and Tweedledee policies. That ran counter to the remarks made a moment or two ago by the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby) and to the remarks that I want to make as well. It has been too easy for Senator Haines to suggest that there is a great deal of familiarity and similarity between the Government and the Opposition, when we stand for very different perspectives on the economy. There are times, of course, when what we say is the same, because we are both called-whether as the Government or the Opposition, whether as the Australian Labor Party or the Liberal and National parties-to be accountable to the electorate. Senator Haines manages to avoid that sort of accountability.

SPEECH.PARA: Because of the measures of accountability that we face there are times when it may seem that we are whistling a similar tune-we here in opposition having a knowledge of the fact that we will one day be in government and therefore called to deliver what we promise, and the Government because it is in government. But Senator Haines makes mischief when she suggests that there is little difference between the Government and the Opposition. There is a real difference as shown in the debate we have had on the Budget Papers and in the attitudes portrayed by the Government and the Opposition. Speech after speech in the last 10 days of sitting-including the speech by the honourable member for Bendigo-has revealed that difference in attitude. Speech after speech on the other side of the House has had about it a measure of self-congratulation: `Look at what a good job we have done. Here we are handing down a Budget surplus of just over $9 billion. Look at what this lot opposite did-unable to produce anything other than an alleged Budget deficit'-conveniently, I note, of $9 billion.

Those opposite show no semblance of contrition for the fact that in producing a Budget surplus of $9 billion they have trebled this nation's debt, placed us in hock overseas to at least three times the level when they came to office.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are talking about Elliott and Elders IXL.

—The real difference in attitude is indicated by the fact that time and time again I have heard honourable members on my side of the House-Liberal and National Party members-concede that the Fraser Government was not pure in its economic management and that it made mistakes. But I have never heard anyone opposite do likewise in respect of the Labor Government. Last night I had to sit in my office and listen to the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear) deliver a speech which was an exercise in self-congratulation that suggested that all economic wisdom had been vested in the Australian Labor Party.

SPEECH.PARA: It is true that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) inherited a Budget deficit. Let us not argue about the level of that deficit. He inherited that deficit from the Liberal and National parties when they had been in government through the worst drought that the nation had ever seen. It is also true that the Budget Papers handed down indicate a surplus budgeted for by Treasurer Keating-but in face of a growing overseas debt and world commodity prices better than we have ever experienced before for our export goods. It has been too easy-and the honourable member for Bendigo just did it 30 seconds ago-to try to blame private investment in Australia for much of our overseas debt. It is too convenient for the Treasurer and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to come in here and imply that much of the present run-up in overseas debt is as a result of excess expenditure by the private sector and so imply-state, in fact, in the case of the honourable member for Bendigo; but I will use the term `imply' in the interests of the Press Gallery-that John Elliott is more to blame for our overseas debt than is the Prime Minister, Bob Hawke.

The truth is that the combined borrowings of local, State and Federal governments in Australia during the period of the Hawke Government exceed $100 billion. Much of that money has been borrowed on-shore. Much of it has been acquired even in the form of Aussie Bonds, so drying up the resources available in Australia and forcing those who need to borrow for private sector development to go off-shore for their borrowing demands. Why? In Australia under this Administration there has been no encouragement to save or to be productive.

I am grateful to the honourable member for Bendigo for doing me the courtesy of remaining in the House for much of this part of the debate. I suspect that the electors in Bendigo and my electors in Wakefield find themselves awfully confused. Even people in the electorate of the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support (Mrs Kelly), in Canberra, are probably confused about just what is happening to the economy. Electors around Australia hear the Government talk about a surplus while the Opposition talks about a growing debt. They say, `How can we be $9 billion better off on one side and over $100 billion worse off on the other side? Who is telling the truth?'.

I use a very simple analogy to explain what the Budget is all about. I am not an economist; so I use what I call my farming analogy. I would not mind if the honourable member for Bendigo would give me 30 seconds to run through it. Running the Australian economy is just like running the farm. Currently in Australia too much is coming in the farm gate in the form of imports-in farming terms, bringing in too much superphosphate, seed, chemicals and lambs for fattening-and too little is going out in the form of finished product. Every month this nation stumbles backwards to the tune of $1 billion to $2 billion. That is the cost of a new Parliament House every month. We stumble backwards economically because we are exporting less than we are importing.

Meanwhile the Treasurer says, `I have produced a Budget surplus of $9 billion'. How can that be? It is just the same as the farm housekeeper saying, `I am going to balance the farm household budget even though the farm is going broke'. The farm housekeeper, just like Treasurer Keating, says, `I will put up the rent for everybody who works on the farm and lives in the house'. He or she puts up the rent. As a result of that exercise the farm household budget-the Government Budget, housewife Keating's Budget-will be in surplus.

That is what is happening. But the nation and the farm continue to go deeper into debt even though the Government Budget is in surplus. That is the sad reality. Housekeeper Keating has very successfully made the farm household Budget-the Commonwealth Budget-pay. How? By putting up the tax take. What has happened during this Government's period in office? From 1983 to 1989-90, total Commonwealth tax revenue has gone up by 105.7 per cent. Let us come to terms with that. In some areas-for example, company tax-we have had a rise of something like 162.8 per cent in tax. All of this is additional tax revenue generated that has made it possible for the Government to proclaim a $9 billion surplus. But while the Government has done that, the nation-the farm, if you like-continues to go deeper into debt because it keeps importing more than it exports.

The only solution to the dilemma is to encourage productivity-to produce more to export-or change our standard of living. The Opposition has consistently called for increased productivity. There is no other way out of this quite uncomfortable and seemingly invincible problem facing our economy.

Three weeks ago I was fortunate enough to be on a panel that had to select a Nuffield farming scholar from South Australia. A member of the electorate of Barker, Mr Brenton Smart, was the successful farmer. I was there not as a politician but as a member of a panel. Mr Smart, a farmer from the south-east of South Australia, was asked-by another panel member, I must hasten to remind the House-`Mr Smart, what do you think is wrong with Australia and what would you do about addressing our economic difficulties?'. Mr Smart said, `When I first went on to my property and I was deepest in debt and the bank manager was breathing down my neck the only solution to the problem that I had was to get up earlier in the morning, come home later at night and come home tireder'. He said, `I think the problem that Australia faces in 1990 is that too few of us come home tired enough'. Now that is not a very palatable solution to the problem, but he is probably dead right. We are simply not productive enough. One will find on this side of the House not a cry for people to work for less-though that misrepresentation has frequently been made by those opposite-but a cry for people to be more productive and to produce eight hours work for eight hours pay. Tweedledum and Tweedledee, Senator Haines? I hardly think so.

The Liberal and National parties have said there are some very simple solutions to the problem of encouraging Australians to be more productive. We have announced policies outlining those very solutions, but in fact those policies have received but scant regard from the press gallery. Let me take two of them. First, we have said that if we are going to have a more productive economy we ought to encourage Australians to get on with producing goods and with developing properties, farms and small businesses. We have said, quite rightly, that the capital gains tax that did not apply when we were in government and has now been introduced by Treasurer Keating is nothing but a burden on the productive sector of the economy. There is no encouragement for Australians when everything they do that makes their farm or their business more valuable will also put them into a more intense tax bracket. So we have said, `Let us bring in a tax which is nothing more than a speculative gains tax. If you buy a business or a farm and sell it in under five years you will incur some form of speculative gains tax. If you sell it in one year it will be at 100 per cent; two years, 80 per cent; three years, 60 per cent; and so on until after five years no longer does a person incur a speculative gains tax for having produced a more productive and more efficient business'. That is one area where we have said we will encourage Australians to get on with making a more productive Australia.

In another area, we have said, `Let us not discriminate against the employee; let us make sure the employee is encouraged to be more productive by offering share ownership schemes'. So we have proposed in our policy that employees be encouraged to become shareholders in the enterprise in which they work. It is an incentive for them to be more productive; an incentive to see that more goods go out of farm Australia's gate than come in. It is just what we need if we are to turn around the present disastrous balance of payments deficit that we face this financial year and that the Treasurer's Budget Papers indicate we will go on facing. Yet he offers no solution. Solutions are being offered here, Senator Haines. Hardly a Tweedledum-Tweedledee scenario.

What do we see in the Budget Papers? We see a proposal guaranteed to be the very carrot that would attract urban Australia; a proposal with which you are very familiar, Mr Deputy Speaker, because of your interest and commitment to the area-a proposal to encourage Australians to be more environmentally sensitive. We saw the Prime Minister on the boundary of my electorate, if you please, announcing a proposal to spend $520m planting trees, tidying up salinity and sorting out soil erosion in Australia. That proposal is budgeted for in these Budget Papers. I am not opposed to that, but if we talk about what is happening to our nation in this Budget debate, let us keep that proposal in perspective too. We have $520m not only to plant one billion trees but in addition to sort out the River Murray salinity and tidy up some soil erosion as well.

I welcome the proposal but frankly it is nonsense in terms of what it can do. Do you know, Mr Deputy Speaker, that at Woolpunda, a place on the River Murray in my electorate, there is currently a Commonwealth funded salt interception scheme to sort out some of the problems caused by the natural inflow of salt into the River Murray? That one proposal, that one project, not even large enough to have captured the imagination of the Australian press, will cost $29.9m. That is the cost of one salt interception scheme on the River Murray. The $520m is not designed solely for the River Murray; it is designed to plant trees and sort out soil erosion as well. It is simply a drop in the ocean. I am indignant about the proposal not because I am anti-environment-quite the contrary; we need to turn the economy around so we have some money to spend on the environment, and that is essential-but as an irrigator. I am conscious that the members of this Government, if you please, claiming to be the people worrying about the environment, are also the people who had the bare-faced audacity to rub out a scheme which was designed to encourage irrigators to use water carefully.

There was once tax relief for water conveyancing. That tax relief for installing better forms of water conveyancing meant that River Murray irrigators particularly in South Australia went about doing away with their flood irrigation systems and installing instead low throw sprinkler and dripper systems so that every tree had apportioned to it the water it needed. So successful was that change by individual growers, encouraged by no more than tax incentives, that the Commonwealth-engineered drainage scheme at Noora proved to be 50 per cent over-engineered. And what did this lot do? They rubbed out that tax concession. Do they really care about the environment, or do they only care about dangling in front of the electorate the sorts of carrots that will capture the electorate's imagination if the electorate does not have the sort of information it needs?

If I wanted to sort out Australia's environment, I would go about encouraging every individual Australian, by tax incentives, to do something about the environment. We have seen it work. Once we captured the imagination of Australians they started to recycle paper to the point at which they tell me paper recyclers are embarrassed by the volume of it. We do not need enormous daubs of money; we need a new motivation in Australia to sort out the environment and a new motivation to sort out the economic difficulties we face. The solution to Australia's problem is principally that Australians simply want to be more productive-in Brenton Smart's terms, simply that Australians come home feeling a little more tired or, if I may, in Ian McLachlan's terms, simply that Australians get up in the morning wanting to go to work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lamb Mr A.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Often in debates I follow the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) and I was surprised at some of the things he had to say. I have not heard many people on the Opposition blatantly attack business as he did during his speech. He said we are in trouble with our burgeoning foreign debt. He knows as well as anybody in this chamber that two-thirds of the foreign debt is due to the private sector and he attacked it for that burgeoning debt. The point is that he has no confidence in the private sector's business judgment and business acumen. He knows that people borrow because of their expectations of profits in the future, for expansion of their business, for confidence in themselves that they will be able to take on more employees. But, no, he damned his Party's former bedfellows, its former traditional support base which has deserted the Liberal Party, because they have got more confidence in this Government as more legitimate and competent economic managers.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member talked like a jilted lover. He lashed out nastily at big business because it has confidence in those on this side of the House and not in those on the other side. If Opposition members want to get back its love and affection, it is about time they spelt out their tax policies and economic management policies. During the great farcical cavalcade a few weeks ago we saw the recycled Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) travel around Australia, but he did not give one word of encouragement or explanation to the business sector or anyone else. It is no wonder that the Opposition will not be handed the reins again.

The honourable member for Wakefield admitted that he was not an economist. I am not surprised, having heard what he said today, that that is so. The honourable member has something in common with his leader. He also is not an economist. The honourable member fell into the trap of trying to compare Federal Government economic management and the fortunes of Australia as a nation with a single business or household entity. He referred to his own farm. I do not know whether he was saying that he managed it badly or whether he was just displaying his ignorance. He forgot that there are millions of players who all have different ideas and different methods of running their businesses. Even farms must borrow to expand, just as Australia borrows to expand. The nation's books must be balanced over years. The honourable member would have averaged out his income over years rather than take one specific financial year on which to base his judgment of his own capabilities.

The honourable member talked about the growth in tax collections. The honourable member's argument falls down because he spoke as though each individual was paying more tax. He blithely cited figures showing more tax going to the Government, as though the same number of people were paying it, but that is not true. Of course, collections have grown. More people are at work; in fact, 1.5 million more people are at work. We have reduced unemployment from 10.3 per cent when the Opposition was in government to 6 per cent. People are paying less tax, but more people are paying tax. We now have a fairer system. We have put an end to the rorts that the previous Government cultivated. We have a wider tax base. The biggest reason why we have a surplus of $9.1 billion is that 7,500 to 8,000 people per week are leaving the dole queues and going into jobs. The great performance, the great success, the great social justice achievement, of this Government has been in increasing employment opportunities.

I had to laugh when the honourable member entered the environment debate. I do not doubt his sincerity in his commitment to the environment, but he had better get his ideas right. The Government in this Budget has encouraged the recycling of paper by announcing the removal of the sales tax on recycled paper. The Opposition did not do this when it was in government. I doubt whether it even crossed its mind that one way of encouraging the use of recycled paper so that we chop down fewer trees and there is less deforestation is to have that tax incentive.

Two major themes have been developed during speeches by Opposition members in this Budget debate. They say that Government economic management is questionable. Questionable? Employment is growing at a rate which is far ahead of that of comparable countries. While inflation is still too high, and the Government recognises that point, it has stabilised and it is still 3 1/2 percentage points less than the rate that we inherited. Is our economic management questionable because of our growing foreign debt? I have covered that point. I never thought I would hear an Opposition member attack business and blame it for our foreign debt.

Let us turn to the matter of high interest rates. Contributions to the debate on this topic come from the Opposition, from our hostile critics outside the Parliament, from well meaning analysts and even from some journalists. There seems to be an ability on their part to forget that the economy is now deregulated. Some still think, write and argue in past terms and understanding about the money supply and how it is controlled. In other words, when comparisons are made about interest rates, people should be very careful to compare apples with apples. Interest rates in a certain economic climate should be compared with those in a like economic climate at another time, unless adjustments are made. People are still talking about tight economic policy in the old terms. We have market pricing of interest rates rather than a juggling of figures by a particular government. We once controlled credit in this country through statutory reserve deposits and liquid and government securities, and through the buying and selling of treasury notes. Of course, we still do the last, as part of the rationing process. Having regard to the very brief history of Australia's deregulated economy, it is obvious that, without a restriction on credit to curb demand, there will be much higher levels of interest rates than before for a similar response.

The Opposition believes in a deregulated economy. It argued for it, but it did not have the guts to introduce it. The consequences are apparent: now that we have adjusted to a deregulated economy, to curb demand, interest rates will have to remain high because we do not have the restriction on credit that we used to have. Only meaningless nonsense comes from the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you read the Reserve Bank report? That is not what it says.

—I will come to that in a moment. Credit is available if one can afford it. Business needs it and, if it can pass it on, it does so and is doing so. Perhaps that is better than the wicked, thoughtless recession that would come about if we relied on a hard restriction of credit, as occurred in the past.

SPEECH.PARA: Obviously, government cannot rely on monetary policy alone. This Government does not do so. We have in place a successful accord, a wages policy which has kept inflation due to wages under control, which has kept disputations down and, therefore, has kept costs to business down. We also have a very tight fiscal policy. We have the lowest level of government spending as a percentage of gross domestic product for 16 years. For the fourth successive year we have reduced the level of government spending. In the absence of that, interest rates would have been much higher. We have not heard from the Opposition where the cuts will be made if it intends to have a tighter fiscal policy. It does not have a wages policy. We can only conclude, without those supporting arms of economic policy, that interest rates under a Liberal-National Party government would be far higher than they are under this Government, at a time when we must curb demand and, at the same time, increase production to satisfy that demand.

The Opposition has also said that we have to tackle savings in this country. Part of the farce of the travelcade by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) was to put forward, off the top of his head, an ill thought through policy about taxing only the real component of interest earnings, and then turning around and allowing business to claim only the real costs of borrowing as a tax deduction. Of course, what is included in the non-deductable and deductable items of expenditure by business, after allowing for inflation, varies according to whom one speaks to in the Opposition. There seems to be no agreement whatsoever among Opposition members on that point.
About a week ago the pretender to the Treasurership, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), contradicted the Leader of the Opposition. He said:
Let me put the record straight on two key Opposition tax proposals flagged by the Leader of the Opposition. We are not wedded to it, either, and I don't have a preconceived view.

Already we see a shifting away from this commitment-as we predicted would happen-to tax only real interest earnings and to allow business to claim only real interest costs as a tax deduction. The Opposition is already backing away from this policy. It will not hit the deck because big business and small business will scream until the Opposition drops this policy. In fact, there is a story going around my electorate about the Leader of the Opposition. How does he get a small business going under his proposal? Give him a large one.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The debate is interrupted in accordance with sessional order 101a. The debate may be resumed at a later hour and the honourable member will have leave to continue his speech when the debate is resumed.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. I remind the Prime Minister that before the pilots strike began on separate occasions he threatened the pilots by saying, `You go out this time and it's war' and, `If they want war, then there will be war'. I ask the Prime Minister to explain how he expected that these kinds of statements would cause the two parties to come together.

—As usual the Leader of the Opposition finds it impossible to state a position accurately. Let me state the position accurately as follows: I said at the outset, as I have said all the way through, Mr Speaker, that I pleaded with the pilots to operate within the system. Before I said anything else I asked them to operate within the system. That is what everyone else in the community does-operates within the system. I pleaded with the pilots to do the same thing. I then said, `If, against the plea that I make on behalf of the Government, and I believe the people of Australia, you are going to claim for yourself a very special position, and if you are going to say it is all right for everyone else, for those who service your plane, those who make the plane safe to fly, all those men and women who do operate within the system and exercise restraint which has brought about this enormous growth in employment in this country, but not for you, from your privileged position, where you have got an average salary of $80,000 a year for eight hours at the stick, and you are asking for an increase which is equal to the average wage and salary of working men and women around Australia, then I am saying to you, not just on behalf of the Government but I believe on behalf of the people of Australia, that's not on and we will not cop that and we will fight that'. Now that was not declaring war on the pilots. The war had been declared by the pilots on the people of Australia.

—If this Opposition wants, in its miserable way, to align itself with those avaricious people, and resort to all sorts of tactics as the Opposition did yesterday, including this horrible fearmongering about unsafe aircraft, if the Opposition wants to get on side with the pilots, that is all right with us. Indeed, it does not surprise us. The Opposition should be on side with them because after all the pilots of Australia are working according to the Opposition's industrial relations policy.

—Mr Speaker, I congratulate you on your appointment. Is the Minister for Social Security aware of a recent call by the Brotherhood of St Laurence for bipartisan support on policies for the support of children? Can the Minister tell the House about progress in relation to social security policies directed towards children?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the call by the Brotherhood of St Laurence which said that the Government's real advances in building a more secure and adequate system of income support for low income Australians were too important to be caught in the crossfire of political conflict. The Brotherhood of St Laurence went on to acknowledge that for the first time in this country's history we have a system of guaranteed minimum income for children, and it added that the Opposition ought to openly acknowledge the merit of such reforms. That system of a guaranteed minimum income for children is built around standards of adequacy of 15 and 20 per cent of the combined married pension rate.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has committed itself to maintaining those standards of adequacy through indexation and adjustment. This means that the Government's Budget move to increase pension rates not only to meet but exceed 25 per cent of average weekly earnings will benefit not only pensioner families but all low income families. Rent assistance increases mean that by September next year all low income families will be able to receive up to $35 a week in rent assistance, more than double the maximum of $15 a week available in December last year. Families with three or more children will be eligible for up to $40 a week, more than 2 1/2 times the amount payable last December. The Government will index those levels of rent assistance from March 1991.

The Opposition has so far refused to commit itself to index rent assistance and has refused to commit itself either to set the standards of family payments to maintain a guaranteed minimum income for children or indeed to index the real value of those payments. The only commitment that I am aware of that the Opposition has been prepared unreservedly to make is to slash a billion dollars off the social security budget. The Brotherhood of St Laurence questions whether the Opposition intends to pay for tax breaks for high income earners by scrapping the Government's welfare reforms. As the Brotherhood of St Laurence notes, it and other welfare agencies are waiting to hear just where the Opposition stands. Five hundred thousand families and more than a million children are now benefiting from the Government's assistance, and they, according to the Brotherhood of St Laurence, have a right to an answer too. In conclusion, the Government is as anxious as the Brotherhood of St Laurence that those very low income families in Australia ought to continue to have the security of a commitment on the part of the Opposition to support those increases and the indexation of the real value of payments for low income families.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Prime Minister confirm that builders labourers excavating the Myer redevelopment site in Adelaide have obtained wage increases of up to 30 per cent outside the Government's guidelines without the approval of the Federal or State industrial commissions, giving them an equivalent annual wage of up to $88,400 per annum, which is in excess of the average salary of a Boeing 767 aircraft captain?
—I can neither confirm nor deny it. I have no knowledge of the subject.
—Can the Treasurer explain to the House how the Commonwealth plans to use the record Budget surplus to repay debt? Can he provide specific details of the debt repayment program for 1989-90?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Debt Commission met today to finalise debt repayments from the $9 billion surplus. As I indicated in the Budget Speech, the Government said that every cent of the surplus would be used to repay debt and that will be so. The program is to retire $1 3/4 billion of foreign currency debt through maturities and economically attractive early calls, redeem around $2 billion of Australian savings bonds, redeem at maturity treasury bonds of about $3.3 billion, run down the stock of treasury notes on issue, and redeem additional treasury bonds and foreign currency liabilities prior to maturity.

ANSWER.PARA: This program, again, will dramatically change the Commonwealth debt outstanding, which honourable members will have seen from the Budget Papers is forecast to have fallen by half in the last three or four years. Of course, this implies a huge saving in public debt interest costs. Part of the continuing story of success in fiscal policy is the decline in public debt interest, which was one of the fastest growing components of the outlays and is now one of the fastest declining components. This contrasts, of course, with the performance of conservative governments in the past, the once so-called prudent managers who never repaid any debt, could never manage a Budget surplus and had outlays to their highest record in Australian history. This will be the third year in a row that the Labor Government has retired both domestic and overseas debt.

If we could procure the Commonwealth debt from foreign holders of debt-if we could procure it-we could in fact wipe out the Commonwealth's foreign currency debt with this single Budget surplus. That is, the Budget surplus of $9 billion would be enough to discharge that foreign currency obligation on the part of the Commonwealth. So again I make the point: this contrasts completely with the position of the former Government. Between 1975 and 1982-83 total net overseas raisings were $4.5 billion, but between 1983-84 and 1988-89 this Government has actually repaid in net terms a total of $1.5 billion of the Fraser-Howard debts. The general improved management of the Commonwealth's fiscal account and the surplus and the repayment of debt contrast starkly with the practice by conservative governments over the last 20 or 25 years, and again indicate how the whole nonsense about some increased risk of default can never be an issue, when the Commonwealth could actually wipe out its foreign currency debt obligations with one Budget surplus.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. In the light of expert evidence to the contrary, will the Prime Minister admit that his remarks comparing airline pilots to bus drivers were confrontationist, inflammatory and stupid?
—This is schoolboy stuff.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As someone behind me interjected, honourable members on the other side of this place are really into schoolboy stuff. The confusion of those on the other side of the House on this matter is quite understandable, because they are increasingly embarrassed by the fact that what is happening in this country is a reflection of what the disaster for this country would be if we were to have in place the industrial relations policy which Opposition members advocate.

—The babble and rabble from the other side is perfectly understandable because what we see in action now is the policy of the Opposition. In regard to the question that was asked by the honourable member for Mayo, if some people working somewhere in Adelaide outside the system have got a 30 per cent increase, that is not something that honourable members opposite should be surprised about. They should simply say, `That is what our policy would deliver'.
—This is your policy in operation.
—Order!

—Honourable members know what happened to the Builders Labourers Federation. Opposition members say that if someone operates outside the conciliation and arbitration system and gets a 20, 30 or 40 per cent increase, that is a matter to be acknowledged with pride by the Opposition because that is its policy in action. In regard to the pilots and the complete misrepresentation involved in the honourable gentleman's question, what we are concerned to say to the domestic pilots of this country is this: do not take the view that there is some mystique about you which entitles you to have a position different from that of the rest of the community. Of course, people who fly our domestic airline routes have a very considerable responsibility.

—If honourable members opposite would like a rational and impartial exposition of the point I was trying to make, I suggest that they read Mr Oakes in today's Bulletin. Mr Oakes says in today's Bulletin-he gives us a rap across the knuckles at times if he thinks we deserve it-that the point is right; there are other people in the community who have great responsibility. Let us take the case of an aeroplane. The man or woman who finally flies that plane has a very great responsibility for the lives, the safety and the welfare of those in it. But so does the man or woman who trains for five years, through an apprenticeship, to become a maintenance engineer. The person who services and maintains the aircraft and has a commitment to the quality of his or her work undergoes at least a five-year apprenticeship. If that man or woman servicing the aircraft does not do his or her job properly, the lives and the safety of the pilot and the passengers are at risk. But that man or woman who trains for many years to equip himself or herself to become a mechanic, in whose hands the very lives of the pilot and the passengers will be placed, has not said, `Because I have a responsibility which entails the lives of the pilot, the hostesses and the passengers, there is something about me that says I will take myself outside the whole of the organised work force and use my power to get a 30 per cent increase'.

ANSWER.PARA: The simple point I am making is that responsibility is not the exclusive preserve of people who work eight hours a week for $80,000. Responsibility is also very much in the hands of the people who service those planes. If honourable members opposite continuously want to identify themselves with the pilots and say, `It is fair that these people should get, by way of a 30 per cent increase, what these other people are getting on average per year', that suits us fine. It is logical for honourable members opposite to say-and they should do because the pilots are their surrogates and they are pursuing Opposition policy-that they are protecting the pilots. That suits me fine. Let the Liberal and National parties be the protectors of the avarice of the pilots against the responsibility of the rest of the Australian workers. That suits us fine.

TALK.START.PARA: —Talk about juvenile logic!
—Order! If the honourable member for O'Connor interjects again, I will have to deal with him.

—Congratulations, Mr Speaker, in more ways than one. Can the Minister for Housing and Aged Care inform the House whether the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal (PBRT) is a disaster for community pharmacy, as the Pharmacy Guild of Australia has claimed? What measures, if any, is the Government proposing to ensure the supply of appropriate medication for the Australian community?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the decision of the PBRT needs to be put into context. This is an independent process of the PBRT. I understand that over 600 submissions were put to the PBRT for its consideration of the remuneration for pharmacists dispensing items under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS). The Tribunal's determination is now fixed under the National Health Act, but there is scope for discussion of a number of recommendations in that report. As was evidenced last night, a number of honourable members do not seem to understand the difference between a determination and a recommendation. As the Prime Minister said, this was established under the legislation of the previous Government.

ANSWER.PARA: A number of issues and recommendations are available for the Government to discuss with national pharmacy bodies. The first issue relates to the structure of the retail pharmacy industry; the second issue relates to the essential pharmacy allowance; and the third and very important issue relates to developing a professional role for pharmacists over and above the role that they already fulfil in the dispensing of drugs under the PBS.

To put this matter into further context, it is important to realise the history of this matter. In April or May of this year, some honourable members will remember, the Government and the Pharmacy Guild of Australia were involved in negotiations to put a joint submission to the Tribunal. At that time the Pharmacy Guild embarked upon a campaign of industrial action-a fear campaign in some parts of Australia-directed particularly at pensioners, saying that pensioners would be the next to have to pay. Not only do pensioners not have to pay-that decision has been quite clearly confirmed in this Budget-but also on that occasion the Pharmacy Guild of Australia rejected an offer by the Government that was probably half to a third as bad in its effect as the decision the Tribunal has now delivered to it.

Members of the Opposition and those in pharmacy have to look at the decision that was taken then in the context of what they face now. They must realise what action they perpetrated in the community and the situation they are in. They must realise that for a long time the Government had a very high level of goodwill towards this industry-a level of goodwill that is quite clearly shown by the fact that we are now prepared to go back and enter into discussions with the Guild and other national industry bodies to resolve some of the problems that affect them. It has to be realised that many people in the industry, particularly the hotheads, who rejected that decision have something to answer for.

I hope that this time many of the moderates in the industry and many of the pharmacists who contacted us when they were looking towards an amalgamation incentive, when they saw that the Government was offering them indexation, a 10 per cent mark up and a much higher dispensing fee than has been set by the Tribunal, will recognise the reality. Tomorrow I will be meeting with the Pharmacy Guild of Australia and I will also be having discussions with the friendly societies, the Pharmaceutical Society of Australia, and unions of workers associated with that industry. I hope that cool heads, reason and reality will prevail.

In relation to the other element of the question, the supply of medication, I can say quite categorically that Australians wherever they live need not fear any loss of access to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme by any action of the Government on this matter. The pharmaceutical benefits scheme, as we all know, is very much underrated and very important. We all need to protect it. There are problems associated with the overuse of drugs and the inappropriate use of drugs. We need to protect the scheme so that it can go on playing its role in providing for the aged, the chronically ill, those on low incomes, and in fact all Australians, the world's best and latest pharmaceuticals at the least cost to the Australian public. The Government will not allow any problems associated with this current situation to interfere in that security for all Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister said on radio 3AK on 21 August that `you could learn to fly in seven hours'. In the light of comments by Captain Wayne Cairns on AM this morning that on that basis we should be able to get a pilot into the right hand seat of a 737 overnight, can the Prime Minister tell the House how many commercial airline pilots have been trained in Australia since he made that stupid statement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Here is the fourth question today from the Opposition which is yet again a demonstration of the total chaos that rules within its ranks on this issue. As the Treasurer says, `What a knockout question'. There have been four pathetic questions. I do not know how many commercial pilots have been trained in Australia in this period, so I will not attempt to guess an answer. If the honourable member really wants to know I suggest that he address the question to the relevant Minister, who will take steps to find out the answer to this profoundly important question. It really is something which is earth shatteringly important!

ANSWER.PARA: The problem is this: the Opposition simply now is caught on the horns of its own dilemma. The simple fact that we have here, which every commentator is coming to realise, is that the Opposition is nailed. It is nailed with the situation that the pilots are operating according to the industrial relations policy of the Opposition. That is what is happening. Opposition members cannot make up their minds. At the end of last week the Leader of the Opposition came out and said he supported what the Government had done to deal with this dispute.

TALK.START.PARA: —With the RAAF.

—There were no qualifications; the Leader of the Opposition supported it. They cannot make up their minds. They say that the pilots should have the right to opt out of the system. What have the pilots done? They have opted out of the system. What does the Opposition then say? `We will introduce a Bill in the House'. To do what? To deal with people who are within the system and to impose more penalties on them. Has anybody ever heard of anything more stupid? They say first of all to the pilots and to anyone else who will listen, `Opt out of the system. That's what our policy encourages you to do'. The pilots opt out. What does the Opposition then say? `We will introduce legislation to impose more penalties within the system'. That is very logical! It tells the pilots to get out, they get out, and then the Opposition will do something more within the system. The fact is that not only are the pilots not in the system, they are also no longer in a situation of an employment relationship. They have resigned. In a situation like that, the policy of the Opposition is absolutely irrelevant, as is the whole of its industrial relations policy.

ANSWER.PARA: On the question of seven hours training, one was making the point-and it relates back to the previous answer I gave-that to actually learn to fly an aeroplane takes that order of time. Of course, no-one, including myself, said that after one has learnt to fly an aeroplane one can then hop into the cockpit of a 727. No-one is saying that, but in terms of training I am saying that those who service these planes go through a very long period of training to acquire their qualifications as mechanics and engineers. The people who maintain and service these aeroplanes are ignored in this situation. If those people have not got the training, the commitment, the integrity that is necessary, then the planes the pilots fly and in which passengers fly will simply not be safe.

The time has come when the pilots have to understand that they are not going to hold the country to ransom, they are not going to wreck the wages system, they are not going to ruin the Australian economy on the basis of some mystique that they want to attach to themselves. They are important people. They have a fundamentally important job to do, but so do many other people, including the people who put those planes into the air. The time has come, and the pilots must understand that the time has come, when neither this Government nor the airline industry nor the Australian economy is going to be held to ransom by people who want an increase which is equal to what those who put their planes into the air get paid for the whole year.

We do not want the pilots to keep on like this. I repeat now what I said at the very beginning of this dispute. I plead with the pilots to say, `Okay, we've made a mistake. What's good enough for the rest of the Australian community is good enough for us'. If they will make the simple statement that they recognise that they are not uniquely different from other Australians, then we can come back to a situation where their legitimate claims can be dealt with within the system. There is full opportunity for significant increases in wages-the 6 per cent plus that is available under the system, including negotiations for increased productivity. Is there anyone in Australia who suggests that there is not significant room for productivity increase? Is anyone really saying that Australian pilots uniquely in the world need to work only eight hours a week at the stick? Of course there is room for these people to work longer hours, and if they work longer hours then there is room for significant pay increases. But there is not room for significant pay increases when these people simply say, `We won't work within the system. We'll hold a gun at your head and demand a 30 per cent increase on top of the $80,000 a year we get for working eight hours a week'.

If they think they can go on like that, they are wrong. I do not want them to go on like that. I want a situation where they will go back into the system and negotiate with their employers. If they do that, there is the opportunity both for significant increases in remuneration and for significant increases in productivity-significant increases in productivity which not only will redound to their benefit in terms of increased remuneration, but also will redound to the benefit of the airline traffic-using public of Australia. If they get those significant increases in productivity, that can operate as a bulwark against further increases in air fares in the near future. In other words, the productivity increases that can come from the pilots working a reasonable number of hours can be shared both by the pilots and by the public of Australia who fly in their aeroplanes.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support. Recently I had the opportunity, through the courtesy of the French Government Railways, to inspect and travel on the TGV, the fast train from Paris to Lyon. In view of an Australian consortium's proposal to build a very fast train to connect Sydney, Canberra and Melbourne, what is the Federal Government doing to facilitate the introduction of this exciting new mode of travel, especially regarding government equity and participation in the project, environmental safeguards and avoidance of adverse sociological consequences?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the question asked by the honourable member for Hotham. I think he and all honourable members would be aware that the Government has indicated its support for the concept of a very fast train development. In the last few weeks we have made a reference to the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure so that members of the Parliament will have the opportunity to examine a number of issues relating to that proposed development which are of concern not only to the Parliament but also to the Australian community.

ANSWER.PARA: Everyone is aware of the fact that in December of last year the joint venturers had completed their concept report, which indicated the prospects that could be associated for them and for south-eastern Australia generally with the development of that particular proposal. They are now in the process of completing a three-year feasibility study at a cost of almost $20m to examine the commercial viability of that particular proposal. Not only the Commonwealth Government but also the State governments have indicated in-principle support for the concept. We have indicated that we would be prepared to assist and cooperate, because we support the concept of that development, to the extent that may be necessary. In the process of doing that, we will take any necessary steps that could be designed to protect the community interest.

The Prime Minister and other members of the Government have indicated that this is a particularly exciting concept. Those people who are of the opinion that it simply represents some type of new transport development or link between Sydney and Melbourne seriously understate the significance of it. The Prime Minister has indicated that it is probably the most important private sector venture or investment project which has been undertaken in Australia since the Second World War. It could well be the most important venture of that kind which has ever been undertaken in Australia. It is not just a proposed transport development; it is a total transport land development package. That has been made perfectly clear by the joint venturers. Those people understand that companies such as Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, Elders IXL, TNT and Kumagai Gumi are all companies of substance. They are significant developers and investors in Australia. The project has the capacity to remake the pattern of urban and industrial development and transport and communications in south-eastern Australia. But we have also indicated that we will not underwrite, at the Commonwealth level-nor do I think the States would underwrite-any financial commitment towards that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nor are they expected to.

—The Prime Minister reminds me that they are not expected to. We have also indicated that we will expect appropriate guarantees from the joint venturers that we will not be expected in any way to financially underwrite that project or to commit any public funds to it.
