In the process of preparing our continuing response to it, we will make sure that environmental considerations are given adequate attention as well. I thank the honourable member for the question. It is an important and exciting concept and we look forward to its continued development.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Is it a fact that the examiners of airmen in the Civil Aviation Authority are members of the Australian Federation of Air Pilots (AFAP)? Have these officers pledged not to train, upgrade or approve to fly foreign or domestic pilots recruited by the airlines to break the present strike? In this case how does the Minister propose to achieve certification for new pilots?

—I thank the honourable member for this question, which just goes further to indicate that the Opposition is simply in bed with the pilots. What we are seeing from the Opposition is a series of questions which simply shows no interest in resolving the dispute but an interest in making political capital out of it. As far as I am aware, the airworthiness examiners are members of the AFAP. In that respect, they may or may not be adhering to instructions from the AFAP. As far as I am aware at this stage they have not been put to the test.

—I direct my question to the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories. I refer to the growing concern throughout the Australian tourism industry regarding the damage caused by the pilots dispute, particularly in relation to loss of earnings, the effects on jobs and the reputation of Australia as an international tourist destination. What action is the Government taking in relation to this matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The present position is that the Australian Tourist Commission is working closely in conjunction with overseas operators to assist them as they try to disengage, with a minimum of damage, those tourists who plan to come to Australia. They have also been cooperating with overseas operators to ensure that they are fully informed about the present situation in Australia. There is a Tourism Advisory Council meeting planned for early September, at which leaders of the industry will be discussing what options are available to minimise the damage which is being caused on a daily basis to Australia's tourism industry. There can be no doubt in anybody's mind that tourism is the most significant victim of this airline stoppage.

ANSWER.PARA: In terms of the statistical material that is available, some 25,000 to 35,000 overseas visitors travel in Australia on domestic airlines each week. The estimate made by the Bureau of Tourism Research is that if the number of visitors dropped by one-third over August, Australia would lose over $100m in foreign exchange for the month. If the dispute had the same impact on arrivals through to December the figure would almost double, to about $180m for the month. It is more difficult to get an accurate figure in respect of domestic travel. It makes up about 80 per cent of tourism travel in Australia. Some authorities within the industry have put the loss as high as $70m per week in that area.

I need to indicate to the House that in discussions which involve the Australian Tourism Industry Association, the Australian Hotels Association, the Australian Federation of Travel Agents, and the Inbound Tourist Operators Association, there is a common resolve that the damage that is being done on a daily basis to the tourism industry will be met with all the capacity that the industry can mount. Already major hotels have stood down casual staff and, by the end of the week, they will be standing down permanent staff. All those associations have asked me to indicate to this House and the people of Australia that we are examining as closely as we can, on the best legal advice obtainable, what action can be taken on behalf of the industry to bring the pilots and the Pilots Federation to their senses.

TALK.START.PARA: —Stop him fanning it.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting.

—I am trying to provide the House with information as objectively as I can. Being objective I should also point out to the House that last night the Canberra Branch of the Socialist Workers Party passed a motion supporting the pilots and today we have had five questions and one silly interjection from the Leader of the Opposition.
—Why do you not try to work in the national interest?
—Rather than the Leader of the Opposition being a mealy-mouthed apologist for the pilots, why does he not have the guts to get up and say that he supports them?
—Order! The Minister will resume his seat until the House comes to order. The Leader of the House will cease interjecting across the table. I call the Minister.

—I hope that when those opposite realise the resolution and determination of the tourism industry not to allow that industry and its work force to be hijacked, they will abandon the use of terms such as `confrontationist' and `inflammatory'. Those were terms that were thrown around in this House yesterday.
—Talk to him.
—Order! If the Leader of the Opposition continues to interject I will have to take action against him.
—Hear, hear! Put him out.
—Order! The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs does not help anybody by his interjection. I call the Minister.
—Mr Speaker, if I can claim your indulgence, on behalf of the Leader of the Opposition, I do not mind interjections. I just wish they were a little more intelligent.
—Order! The Minister will answer the question.

—I will finish on this point: there has been a very serious attack by one very narrow section of the work force on Australia's most important earner of foreign exchange and it must be dealt with seriously. The course that is being undertaken-I make no apology for being deeply involved in that course-is not one that can be undertaken lightly or with any sense of joy. I just wish and hope that those pilots who have been so grievously misled will realise, in the next few days, that their economic future, like that of all Australians, is bound up in the development of our economic base and tourism is a major aspect of that. In order to keep the Opposition informed, all this information will come to the shadow Minister on a daily basis. I hope that that will enable him to improve the standard of performance of his colleagues.

—My question is to the Prime Minister. In light of the answer to the previous question, what advice has the Prime Minister received as to the likely impact of the continuing pilots dispute on the Budget's forecast and figuring?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received no advice on the likely impact of a continuation of the pilots dispute on the Budget figuring, but I would say this to the shadow Treasurer: if he has any influence on the Opposition-he may have-I wish that he would bring home to his colleagues the appropriateness of the strength of the Government's stand on this issue. I wish that those opposite, including the shadow Treasurer, would make up their minds where they stand. They have done nothing in this Parliament this week other than be apologists for the pilots. It is understandable, in a sense, that they should do that because the pilots are acting strictly in accordance with their policy.

ANSWER.PARA: However, as my colleague the Minister who has just resumed his seat has said, the realities of this start to emerge very clearly when we see the unity ticket that is developing-a very strange unity ticket-with the pilots, the Opposition and the socialist workers alliance of Australia. It is not very strange when one thinks about it because, in terms of philosophy and position, when those opposite were in office they wrecked the Australian economy. The pilots are trying to do it now and the socialist workers of Australia have a philosophical commitment to the wrecking of the Australian economy. In one way or another all Opposition members are wreckers, potentially or philosophically, of the Australian economy. So it is not strange that the socialist workers, the Liberal and National parties and the pilots are all in one grizzly bed together.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: LASER TREATMENT FOR SKIN LESIONS: MEDICARE BENEFITS

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Community Services and Health aware of concerns in the Australian community in relation to the provision of Medicare rebates for vascular skin lesions, commonly known as port wine stains? Can he advise the House of the current position?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that considerable concern has been expressed by various groups about the application of Medicare benefits to laser therapy for vascular skin lesions, otherwise known as port wine stains. To date the laser therapy treatment for port wine stains has been restricted to the head and neck for Medicare benefits purposes. This was done on the grounds of overseas evidence which indicated that the results of this form of therapy on other parts of the body were less than satisfactory. However, the latest laser technology does permit effective treatment of port wine stains on other parts of the body. Having accepted this new evidence, I have approved a recommendation of the Medicare Benefits Advisory Committee (MBAC) that Medicare benefits be extended for the removal of port wine stains from any part of the body. This change has been made retrospective to 1 February 1989. That was the date on which the restrictions were introduced.

ANSWER.PARA: As regards other severely disfiguring skin lesions treated by laser therapy, for the moment these will be restricted to the head and neck. That continuation of the restriction is in line with the best medical evidence provided by the Medicare Benefits Advisory Committee after detailed consideration of these other disfiguring lesions. Where treatment of other severely disfiguring skin lesions on areas of the body other than the head and neck is performed for clinical and not simply cosmetic reasons, applications can be made to the MBAC in individual cases.

Technology is changing rapidly and there are likely to be advances in the coming months-for instance, original machines are being replaced by new machines-and some of the benefits are yet to be determined. For all those reasons I have requested the MBAC to review the whole question of laser therapy for vascular skin lesions in 12 months time so we can keep it under review.

DEBATE.TITLE: QUALITY OF SERVICE PROVIDED BY DEPARTMENT OF SOCIAL SECURITY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present the Government's response to the report Fairness, Courtesy and Efficiency? A Report on the Quality of Service provided by the Department of Social Security. The report was prepared by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs and tabled in this House on 25 May 1989.

SPEECH.PARA: Terms of Reference

I referred an inquiry to the Committee in February 1988. The terms of reference were to examine the effectiveness of methods used to provide information on entitlements to social security clients-and the effectiveness of the Department of Social Security in providing face to face contact with its clients. The Committee was also asked to examine any proposals to enhance awareness and take-up of entitlements by persons who qualify for assistance under the Department's programs.
Background

The background to this inquiry is one of enormous change in the social security system since 1983. In that time, the levels of assistance provided through the Department's programs have been significantly increased. At the same time, social security outlays have declined as a proportion of the Budget and as a share of gross domestic product. These achievements have required enormous policy and legislative reforms and administrative and systems changes within the Department of Social Security. At the same time, the functions of the Department were being significantly broadened beyond its traditional income security role by programs such as family allowance supplement, the child support scheme, Newstart and the jobs, education and training program.

Change in an organisation the size of my Department is difficult. The Department has 16,500 staff in 300 locations serving the needs of a diverse client population of around 4.2 million throughout the length and breadth of Australia. Total payments to clients of $20 billion in 1989-90 represent 23 per cent of all Commonwealth outlays. The size of the administrative task is immense-in 1987-88 100 million payments were made. It was in this context that I referred the inquiry to the Standing Committee. It is essential that information provision and client access to services be effectively integrated with the rapid changes occurring in the Department.

In recognition of the task faced by the Department, the Government has given the highest possible priority to administrative reform within the Department. In recent years there have been very significant advances in the way the Department of Social Security has provided clients with access to its programs and services. The Department has vigorously adopted new technologies and innovative administrative practices. It can be proud of its achievements. In fact, many of the matters raised in the Committee's report and its recommendations are already in place or are being addressed. In some cases alternative strategies to those suggested have been developed. These are assessed as producing better results or being more cost effective. To implement all of the Committee's recommendations would require a total additional amount of $40m. This represents some 7 per cent of current running costs. I will table a detailed response to each of the Committee's recommendations at the end of this statement.
Use of Technology

At the outset this Government recognised the need for the social security system to be supported by modern, efficient computer operations and endorsed the stratplan program. With the implementation of stratplan completed last year, on time and within budget, the Department now operates one of the largest computer networks in the country. It is probably the most advanced social security automatic data processing system operating anywhere in the world. This advanced technology has resulted in the significantly more effective and helpful administration of social security programs.

The introduction of this technology has allowed for the integration of the Department's major payments systems through the introduction of on-line benefits processing. On-line benefits processing has a strong client focus and is resulting in improved service to clients through the decentralised network of the Department's regional offices.

On-line benefits processing will improve service to clients by allowing speedier processing of claims, more accurate and faster answering of queries and simultaneous updating of all related benefits when there is a change of client circumstances. The system can also monitor progress of outstanding action. It ensures a close client focus-common processing actions for all benefits mean more efficient and effective resolution of client queries.

The flexibility afforded by the new technology makes possible innovative policy development and program delivery as well as much more effective and pervasive control of payments, ensuring that only those who are eligible under the Social Security Act receive them. The Department has looked to new technology to enable vast improvements to be made to its written communications with clients. This area received special attention by the Standing Committee. The Government recognises the magnitude of the task-each year the Department of Social Security sends out over five million letters and eight million review advices. These notify clients of changes which may affect them and request information if their circumstances have changed.

The Department now uses laser printing technology to produce simpler, more straightforward advices personalised to each client's circumstances. The advices incorporate the principles of good forms design and plain English. The Department will be using this technology for all its computer printed correspondence and forms. An on-line letters and advices project is at an advanced stage of development. It will convert all of the Department's standard letters to laser production by mid-1990 and the phased conversion of computer produced advices by mid-1991. The size of the task is demonstrated by the fact that there are over a million variations of computer produced advices.

The Department's computer network has also provided new opportunities for distributing information to staff. An on-line information system allows staff throughout the Department to have easy access to up to date information affecting the eligibility of clients. This system has become an essential element in the delivery of internal information. Importantly it facilitates more consistent and accurate decision making across the Department.
Restructuring of Management and Decision Making

Major areas of reform of direct relevance to the report include an expansion of the role of area offices and the devolution of functions to allow more effective day to day management-including community consultation and information provision-at the area office level. The result will be improved decision making based on the needs of local clients and staff and better management. An important outcome of the strengthening of area offices is the area based review system. This provides for independent decision makers in area offices to review and, where appropriate, quickly change decisions affecting clients made in regional offices.

The Government established in November last year the Social Security Appeals Tribunal (SSAT) as an independent determinative body. The SSAT has as members welfare workers, doctors and lawyers drawn from their various communities. The national convener of the SSAT advises me on difficulties and anomalies identified by the Tribunal through its work in hearing appeals.
Reforming Policy and Legislation

No review of this Government's reforms can overlook the wide ranging implications of the work of the Social Security Review in assisting us with the reform of policy and legislation. Its most recent work has dealt with the crucial area of retirement income policy-work which culminated in my recent statement and Budget announcements. Issues relating to families and children, sole parents and the unemployed have also been dealt with and we are now turning our attention to the remaining matter dealt with by the review-disability payments. The new directions which are flowing from the review are having major impacts on legislation, policy, programs and procedures.

An important barometer for the Government of the effectiveness of the Department's administration is the Social Security Advisory Council. This body of experts in the social security field provides me with advice on issues relating to the administration of my portfolio as well as important input to social security policy.

A major task being undertaken at present is the complete review of the Social Security Act. The revised legislation will provide a vastly more coherent legislative base for the administration of social security programs. It will ensure that the law is as easy to understand as is possible with large, complex Acts, is internally consistent and is accessible to both staff and clients. These developments together with the other advances made by the Department of Social Security in recent years provide a sound basis on which to build even greater efficiency, effectiveness and integrity in the administration of my portfolio.
Lifting the Standard of Service

In 1989-90, the Department is working to achieve better client access to services, information and entitlements; to improve communication with staff; and to take full advantage of the opportunities the changes I have mentioned give to increase productivity and enhance the work environment. The delivery of programs by the Department of Social Security is central to the achievement of the Government's social justice objectives. Those programs are central to fair income distribution. We are committed to ensuring that all people have full access to payments they are entitled to.

The Department is now implementing a package of measures announced in the 1989-90 Budget to lift the standard of service to clients-including training for public contact staff; development of the decentralised office network, particularly in rural areas; the establishment of an area office based information service for pensioners; and special measures to improve access for Aboriginal and Islander parents.

When the Chairman of the Standing Committee, the honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe), presented its report to the House, members of the Committee spoke of the dedication and commitment of staff in Social Security offices. I want again to put on record my own appreciation to the staff of the Department. Let me say that without their dedication and professionalism we would not have moved so far down the path of achieving social justice for all Australians.

The Committee has performed for the Parliament a very valuable service in doing the work and producing this report. The area of service has been a major area of priority for the Government in the current financial year. Any examination of this year's Budget will indicate the range of initiatives that the Government has undertaken in the area of improving client services in this Budget. Those initiatives have coincided with and had the benefit of the information provided by the Committee and the Committee can rest assured that in this response-including the attachment but in particular in the Budget Papers-the Government has taken account of the work carried out. I table the Government's response to each of the recommendations in the Committee's report and seek leave to have them incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
FAIRNESS, COURTESY AND EFFICIENCY/A REPORT ON THE QUALITY OF SERVICE PROVIDED BY THE DEPARTMENT OF SOCIAL SECURITY
House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs
GOVERNMENT'S RESPONSE
Recommendation 1
Response
The Department of Social Security actively encourage Regional Office Managers to produce supplementary information regarding their local office and related services. (para 2.27)

The Department's Regional Managers are actively encouraged to involve themselves in community outreach and in the production of material which is helpful in the local situation. These activities are being assisted and supported by the newly appointed Area Outreach Officers whose role includes:
* direct assistance to Regional Managers with their particular regional outreach endeavours; and
* assessing and evaluating the Department's information strategies and products.

In late 1988 the Department carried out an audit of Regional Public Relations. A number of recommendations were put forward as a result of the audit. Among them was the recommendation that the Department develop a national Public Relations Plan and that the Plan include standards of involvement for Area Outreach Officers as well as a system for monitoring and evaluating public relations activity. Implementation of the Plan will further enhance and develop the Department's strategy in this area.
Recommendations 2, 3 and 4
Response

Community consultative committees be established to meet at regular intervals in order to facilitate the exchange of information and concerns between the Department of Social Security and the Community. (para 3.23)
Such committees be established at Area and Regional Office levels. (para 3.23)

One function of Area Managers and Regional Managers is to establish consultative arrangements with welfare organisations and client groups. The newly appointed Area Outreach Officers now assist in this process by:
* initiating and generating interaction with various agencies and bodies on an area or locality basis;
* establishing links with key people who work in community agencies and organisations relevant to the Department's sphere of interest (including trade union, employer and training interests); and
* arranging forums and other activities with consumer groups to enable clients to contribute to policy, administration and service issues.
A position of Community Liaison Officer be established in each Regional Office to facilitate communication between community agencies, the Department and its clients. (para 3.25)

Trials of community consultative arrangements have been operating in Victoria over the last three years or more. In addition, the Department has been discussing with the Australian Council of Social Service (ACOSS) a proposal for a pilot involving the establishment of a number of Area-based consultative committees. A report on the proposal will be prepared for the consideration of the Social Security Advisory Council.
As noted in the report, Regional Managers and Social Workers already seek to facilitate communication between community agencies, the Department and its clients at the regional level.

With reference to the recommendation to establish a Community Liaison Officer in each Regional Office, Area and Regional Managers and Social Workers already provide effective consultation at the local level. In addition, it is considered that the objectives underlying this recommendation can be achieved more effectively and at much less cost through Area Outreach Officers.
Recommendation 5
Response
A senior staff member at the Administrative Service Officer Class 3 level or above is available at the counter at all times. (para 4.14)

Developments have overtaken this recommendation. Under the Regional Office Job Redesign Agreement made with the unions, ASO4's will handle the more complex cases at the counter (e.g. full interview for new claims) and in the field (e.g. complex misrepresentations). Other public contact work at the counter and in the field will be undertaken by staff at the ASO3 level.
These features of the Regional Office Job Redesign Agreement have already been introduced in many offices and should be operational by the end of the year in all of them.
Recommendation 6
Response
The staff selection process include application of secondary selection criteria, one of which is the requirement for a high level of interpersonal skills. (para 4.14)

This recommendation is already under active consideration. The Department has proposed to the Public Service Commission that it trial secondary selection criteria for the recruitment of staff to the Department. A high level of interpersonal skills is one of the criteria proposed.

The Department is keen to use these criteria because they provide obvious advantages in obtaining staff who have an interest in, and capacity for, assisting clients. These interests and skills are not tested adequately in the current selection procedures for the APS. Discussions are continuing with the PSC and the unions with a view to adopting secondary selection criteria.
Recommendation 7
Response

The Department of Social Security support its staff adequately by giving them appropriate interpersonal skills training at all levels in the organisation and as soon as possible after entering the Department. (para 4.14)

Within its resource capacity the Department conducts courses for staff in all aspects of public contact including interpersonal skills training. The initiatives recently announced in the 1989/90 Budget address this recommendation by providing additional resources for training, especially in the areas as of interpersonal skills and conflict resolution.

This matter is being pursued in the Structural Efficiency Principle discussions with the unions to ensure that staff receive adequate training before being requested to perform public contact functions.
Recommendation 8
Response
Staff do not assume public contact duties until they have been employed in a Regional Office for an extended period, preferably six months. (para 4.14)

In the re-structured offices following Second Tier Wage Agreement Job Redesign this is most unlikely to occur. However, it is not possible for all staff to be excluded from public contact duties in the first six months of their employment in a Regional Office particularly if public contact is seen to include contact by phone.

For those who have been employed elsewhere in the Department, the six-month rule may not be appropriate. For those who have been recruited recently, the Department would aim not to have them assume full public contact duties until it was sure they had the necessary skills to deal with clients effectively and the necessary technical expertise. Generally, it could be expected that this would take six months.
Under the Second Tier Wage Agreement the Department has upgraded the level of staff who will have public contact. Counter and field enquiries will be handled now by ASO3s.

This was done because the Department recognised that it is important that public contact staff in Regional Offices have the training and experience to make decisions and process client enquiries from initial contact through to the assessment of the eligibility of claims.

Under the Structural Efficiency Principle, the Department is looking to revise the duties of staff at the base level so that such positions would be regarded as in-training positions. Its proposals in this regard appear to be consistent with the aim of the recommendation.
Recommendation 9
Response

The Department of Social Security include, as part of its staff training, information on the background to Departmental policies and the political and social context in which the Department operates, including information on the labour market. (para 4.14)
The Department has sought to include information on the background to Departmental policies increasingly in its technical training when new policies are announced by the Government.
The Department runs an intensive one-week program for managers designed to give them an appreciation of the broader context in which the Department operates.
The induction and other training courses of the Department include information on the Department and where it fits in the wider context.
Recommendations 10 and 11
Response
The Department of Social Security expand its use of toll free services to provide either a national or State based permanent facility. (para 4.22)
The permanent 008 facility to comprise two elements, one a `help desk' for staff and the second an information hotline for clients. (para 4.22)
For many years the Department has had a policy of accepting calls on a reverse charge basis or calling clients back where a client is calling from outside the `local' call area.

In addition, the Department has 008 services in most offices where they are needed. Currently 86 Regional Offices have 008 services installed. In line with recent legislation, the Department is developing these services and a further 13 are on order. It is expected that 008 services will be available in all Regional Offices where they are needed by the end of September 1989. ``Reverse charges'' and ``call back'' arrangements will continue to be available for circumstances not met by the 008 service.

The Department has maintained special purpose telephone enquiry services since late 1984 when an Assets Test ``Hotline'' was established in all States. Since that time 008 information services have been used in connection with major policy statements by Government-including Budget/Economic Statements and specific initiatives, such as Family Allowance Supplement (FAS). Over the last two years hotlines spread over six locations have run almost continuously. The Department has found the use of 008 lines to be generally cost effective, easily accessible and a direct method of client contact. In addition, statistical monitoring of calls received has provided the Department with useful feedback on client attitudes, information provided and potential problems as well as for planning and co-ordinating future enquiry services.

To date the telephone enquiry services have been State-based because of technical and resource considerations. While there is some variety in the operation of each service there is general consistency in hours of operation and the extent to which the availability of each service is advertised. The Department has established a single national hotline based in Sydney to coincide with a major family payments advertising campaign during July/August 1989. The results of this campaign will be carefully monitored with a view to examining the full implications of establishing a permanent national 008 facility serviced from one or a number of locations and accessible from all areas of Australia.
The Department recognises the utility of ``help desk'' facilities for staff. With 16,600 staff, it is difficult to establish an effective service.

The concept is being developed with the devolution of functions to Area Offices. Expert Benefits Administration Units in devolved Area Offices provide ring-in policy advice services for Regional Office staff. As well as providing phone advice, expert policy staff visit Regional Offices in their Areas on a regular basis. Staff are given the opportunity to select in advance areas for discussion and review. Seminars for OICs are held which provide additional information to key staff-particularly in connection with Budget and other initiatives.
Regional Office staff can obtain advice also from specialist policy areas in State Offices. These arrangements are particularly active in Areas where devolution is yet to be completed.
Officers from the Area and State Office Benefits Administration and specialist policy units in turn have access to advice from nominated specialist staff in the Department's Central Administration.
Comprehensive assistance including phone advice to staff on procedural and other matters is also available from the training units in State Offices and all Area Offices.

Regular conferences of Area, State and Central offices benefits experts are held to ensure that at the local level those on whom Regional Office staff rely for expert advice and guidance are fully informed and up to date on new policy developments.
Recommendation 12
Response
The Department of Social Security investigate the conduct of its Field Officers in order to assess the extent to which the guidelines are infringed. (para 4.35)

The Department's Field Officers are expected to maintain high standards in their work and are assisted by guidelines and training. Input from welfare organisations can play a useful role in the training of the Department's field staff. Some initiatives have already been taken along these lines and managers at State and Area levels are being encouraged to extend them.

The Department also investigates every complaint about field staff behaviour and, where necessary, takes disciplinary action. Unsubstantiated allegations made by welfare groups such as the Welfare Rights Unit in Melbourne, coupled with a refusal to provide relevant client details to the Department so it can establish what actually occurred, hinder the Department's efforts to minimise problems in this area.
Recommendation 13
Response
Letters of advice left by Field Officers incorporate:
* the reason the Field Officer called;
* the option of having the interview at home or in the Regional Office; and
* advice to the effect that the client has the right to have a friend, advisor, interpreter or advocate present during the interview, wherever it may be held. (para 4.35)

The Department's national `Advice of Visit' card advises the client that an officer of the Department had called but did not find him/her at home. All visits to clients by Field Assessors are of a routine nature i.e. they are being made as part of normal Departmental review arrangements which seek to establish the correctness of current payments. As the Committee knows, the Department's risk analysis approach means that cases can come to notice for review in a number of ways. To identify the background to the selection in correspondence prior to commencement of the interview would cause unnecessary distress to a client and create an impression that the Department expected the outcome to be a reduction in fortnightly rate (even cancellation) and an overpayment. The view is taken that any procedure which could give rise to such impressions should be avoided.
The `Advice of Visit' card advises the client that:
* the Field Assessor will call again at a particular time and date; or
* he/she should ring the nominated contact officer to arrange a mutually convenient interview time.
When the client rings the contact officer, he/she can request that the interview take place in the Regional Office.
Clients often prefer to be interviewed in their homes since the atmosphere is more comfortable and they are more likely to have any material that they need close at hand.

Interpreters and advisers are already used as part of the interview process when required. The Department is currently developing a Field Assessor pamphlet which will advise clients of the role of Field Assessors. It is intended that the pamphlet will be given to all new clients as part of the pre-grant information package and be left with the `Advice of Visit' card.

The availability of an interpreter and the right to have an adviser present will be dealt with in that material. The presence of advocates at interviews is not supported. The Department strives to ensure that interviews do not develop into adversary situations. Having other people present in an advocacy (as opposed to advisory) capacity would negate these efforts.
Recommendations 14 and 15
Response
All new clients be given, as a matter of course, a pre-grant interview, during which their rights and obligations are clearly outlined. (para 4.44)

These recommendations could be based on a misconception of the Department's practices. Existing procedures provide for all people who visit an office of the Department to apply for a benefit or pension to be interviewed and given information about their rights and obligations.
All clients re-applying for benefits after a period of 12 months without social security support also be given a pre-grant interview. (para 4.44).

However, where, for instance, a person has claimed benefit previously and is well aware of requirements, the contact with such a person need not be of long duration. A streamlined interview process is used in such situations to reduce the amount of time a client needs to spend with the Department's interviewing officer.
Recommendations 16 and 17
Response
The Department of Social Security ensure that regional Offices are equipped with the following:
* play areas and toys for children;
* toilet facilities for clients; and
* a television set and/or video cassette recorder placed strategically in the waiting area. (para 4.51)
The Department of Social Security offer clients the option of private interviewing facilities prior to asking any personal questions. (para 4.51)
The Department has gone some way towards meeting these recommendations.

Play areas, toys and television are already provided in a number of Regional Offices. It is intended to provide more television sets as resources allow. The provision in Regional Offices of activity packs for children is being trialled by a number of Area Outreach Officers.

It is the Department's policy to ensure toilet facilities are available on all premises. These facilities are being provided progressively as office accommodation is upgraded or offices are relocated. However, there are constraints. The Department leases its office space and there are difficulties in terms of both cost and suitability of available accommodation.
Private interviewing facilities are available in all offices. Staff will be reminded that clients are to be given the opportunity to be interviewed in private.
Recommendations 18, 19 and 20
Response
The Department of Social Security implement a revised set of standards for the content of letters to clients. As a minimum, these standards should include that letters:
* are always dated and include the name of a contact officer;
* are forwarded to the client prior to termination of payment;
* set out the calculations on which the level of payment/termination of payment has been based;
* include a simple, personalised explanation if payment has been altered or terminated;
* advise alternative avenues of income support, where possible and/or avenues of appeal; and
* are accompanied by a translation in a preferred language where applicable. (para 5.15)

The Department has looked to new technology to enable vast improvements to be made in its written communications with clients. Necessary work is now well advanced towards the production of advices using laser printing technology, including the conversion of the Department's standard letters to laser production under a project called Online Letters and Advices.

The standard that letters should be dated is already being met and some also include contact telephone numbers, advice of avenues of appeal and of alternative types of income support available. The Department will move as quickly as possible to give effect to these recommendations.

Advices of termination are produced and issued to clients as soon as the Department is aware of the event which precludes further payments. In many cases, this occurs before the next payment is due. In other situations the date of the event is known in advance and this knowledge is used to give clients early warning. Supporting parents are advised, for example, one year and again at 3 months before his/her last qualifying child attains the age of 16 years.

With reference to the calculations used in arriving at rates of payments, existing advices cater for this where a payment is granted or varied. The progressive implementation of Online Advices will further enhance capacity to incorporate more detailed information, and to allow more flexibility to tailor letters to suit individual cases. This will also satisfy the Committee's recommendation that a personalised explanation be included if payments are altered or terminated.

It is not proposed to implement the suggested standard that letters be accompanied, where applicable, by a translation in a preferred language. The use of qualified translators to provide this service for even the most frequently used foreign languages in all of the Department's Regional Offices could not be justified. However, the Department does include on the reverse of its computer produced advices a message in several different languages.
The Department of Social Security develop a single application form for all clients. (para 5.24)
The application form comprise a number of streaming questions which indicate the most appropriate form of payment for which the client might be eligible. (para 5.24)

The concept of the use of a generic claim form for the major pensions, benefits and allowances is under active development but is by no means simple to implement or operate. The introduction of the Person Data Update System will provide an opportunity to develop the concept. Plans are in hand to pilot a generic claim form. The pilot will allow for a qualitative assessment of the effectiveness of various options. Legal aspects of a generic claim form will also have to be taken into consideration.
Standardised processing of new claims, regardless of the payment claimed, will be necessary in future because of the online environment.
Recommendation 21
Response
Initial application forms be evaluated at Determining Officer Level.

It is Departmental policy that Determining Officers should always be available to assist with new claims. In many Regional Offices Determining Officers also perform the Streaming Officer function. In this situation new claims are evaluated by the Determining Officer. In other offices, the skill levels and experience of staff allow this function to be performed at a lower classification.

Straightforward new claims normally receive a counter contact interview. The length of the interview is determined by the amount and nature of the information required. The Department considers it is more efficient and cost effective for those simple new claim interviews to be performed by lower classified officers.
Recommendations 22 and 23
Response
The Department of Social Security ensure that the wall chart is updated on a regular basis, and immediately major changes are announced. (para 5.32)

The wall chart is revised twice a year in line with CPI and rates of payment changes. The format and production are now being integrated with other Departmental information products providing details of rates of payments including leaflets, the pocket rates card and the desktop rates card. This is the result of an overall review of the Department's promotional material.
The wall chart be distributed as soon as possible after amendment, and in any case no later than two weeks after major announcements. (para 5.32)

The Department, in conjunction with a graphic design/consultancy group, is developing an integrated approach to its entire range of information products. This will ensure consistency of style, graphics, level of language and technical information in the information material produced for national distribution. At the same time, the distribution procedures for information products are being improved to ensure that all changes to policy and programs are communicated to clients and agencies as quickly as possible.
Recommendations 24, 25, 26 and 27
Response

The Department of Social Security establish a consultative process with specific expert welfare bodies (for example the Sydney Welfare Rights Centre) as an essential element of the process of examining its manuals. (para. 5.38)
The Department of Social Security continues to produce manuals and amended pages in hard copy, any updates to be forwarded to welfare agencies immediately changes are made on-line. (para 5.38)
In any case, the Department of Social Security provides copies of its manuals and the Social Security Act and amendments free-of-charge to recognised welfare agencies. (para 5.38)

Some changes to the manuals have been made taking into account comments from welfare bodies such as the Welfare Rights Centre (Sydney). However, given the large number of amendments made to the manuals each year, it would be impractical to seek input on most proposed amendments. It must also be borne in mind that the manuals are intended to provide guidance to Departmental officers-they are not prepared specifically to assist welfare groups.

While it is the intention to move towards the concept of a fully automated office environment with a major reliance on online reference material, there are no plans at present to dispense with paper copies of the Department's policy manuals.
The Department will continue to issue hard copy amendments as quickly as possible after the changes are made to the policy manuals on the online database.

The recommendation to provide, free of charge, copies of the manuals, the Social Security Act and amendments to these documents cannot be accommodated as this action is contrary to Government charging policy.

As indicated above, at this stage policy manuals are to be retained in hard copy to complement online versions. If at some future date the Department decides to move to a totally online environment for its policy manuals and other internal reference documentation, the question of providing major welfare agencies with `appropriate support and software' will be examined.

If, in future, the Department of Social Security does decide to move completely to on-line manuals, the Department must also look to providing major welfare agencies with appropriate support and software. (para 5.38)
Recommendations 28 and 29
Response
The Department of Social Security's Corporate television Unit be expanded to enable concentrated production of general client information, in addition to current training material. (para 5.42)
The Department of Social Security, in conjunction with the Braille and Talking Book Library, proceed with a trial program for the production of audio cassette tapes. (para 5.44)

The majority of programs produced by the Corporate Television Unit aim to enhance the internal communications of the Department. While most internal programs are distributed to all staff, they are particularly targeted at Regional Offices so that public contact staff are kept up to date on changes that affect social Security recipients.
The Unit also produces programs for internal training purposes covering a wide range of topics: for example, Telephone Skills, Induction Training and Aboriginal Liaison Officer Training.
The Unit already produces programs aimed at particular community groups. These include:
* ``Aboriginal Community Video'' in an Aboriginal language and in English for remote Aboriginal communities in North-West Australia;
* ``Perhaps Social Security can Help You'' made for community groups and public contact staff;
* ``Social Security Information Video'' made in three local languages and English for Torres Strait Island communities;
* ``The New JET Program'' made for community groups; and
* ``a program on the reciprocal Social Security Agreement with Italy, made in Italian and English for Italian community groups.

In the 1988-9 financial year the Corporate Television Unit produced 24 programs in total. Within resource constraints the Department proposes to increase the number of programs produced by the Unit for community groups.

In addition, an extensive study is well advanced into identifying and meeting the needs of clients with literacy problems. 1990 is International Literacy Year and the Department is taking a proactive approach to meeting the needs of people who experience difficulties owing to their literacy problems. Associated with this, an information package incorporating the use of audio tapes is being trialled at offices in NSW and the NT using audio playback equipment installed in the Regional Office. The audio information includes details relating to basic eligibility, the procedures for obtaining benefit and the rights and obligations of clients. Printed information is being reviewed with greater use of graphics and symbols in place of text wherever possible.

The production of audio cassette tapes is already under way with pilot projects in both New South Wales and Victoria. The target audience for these is people who are visually impaired or blind. It is expected that this will develop into a national program in 1989/90.
Recommendation 30
Response

The Department of Social Security investigate the potential of the Central Australian Aboriginal Media Association's Radio Station 8 KIN FM and Imparja Television for the production of appropriate social security material for broadcast through these outlets. (para 6.10)

This is already being done. The Department is currently working with Imparja to produce a video on FAS, targeted to Aboriginals, particularly those living in remote areas. The video is part of a campaign to promote FAS which will also include picture stories, posters and stickers.

The Department has prepared advertisements for use on CAAMA radio alerting Aboriginal communities to the FAS products and the Department will continue to develop ways of using both CAAMA and Imparja and other media of this kind to assist in reaching this target group.

The Government is committed to providing adequate access to DSS services for Aboriginal people and people in remote areas. A number of innovative services to Aboriginal communities were announced in the 1989/90 Budget. These include:

* a doubling, from 6 to 12, of the number of Remote Visiting Teams. These teams consist of two officers, a benefits expert and an Aboriginal Liaison Officer, who provide intensive assistance to remote area people in claiming and maintaining their entitlements.
* The establishment of an interpreter service to help the Department communicate with Aboriginal people whose first or only language is not English.

* The establishment of the Support Network for Aboriginal Parents (SNAP). Departmental officers will work primarily with Aboriginal women's groups, first to ensure that DSS entitlements are claimed and maintained and, second, to assist parents in their efforts to acquire greater home-making and economic skills. This scheme is designed primarily to achieve the Government's pledge with respect to child poverty in respect of Aboriginals.
All of these initiatives are biased heavily in favour of Aboriginal clients' preferred method of communication-face-to-face personal contact.
Recommendation 31
Response

The Department of Social Security's Regional Office Managers and Aboriginal workers promote a higher profile and easier access to their services throughout their areas of operation by seeking to appear regularly on Aboriginal radio and television programs. (para 6.10)
This is accepted in principle. The Department will ensure that all officers concerned are equipped with media skills and provide training for this purpose.
Recommendation 32 and 33
Response
The Department of Social Security consult with the Office of Multicultural Affairs and the Public Service Commission regarding the proposed cross-cultural communication training course. (para 7.9)

The Department of Social Security make a commitment to include cross-cultural awareness courses in its training programs for public contact staff and commence such courses at the earliest opportunity. (para 7.9)

As part of the 1988/89 Budget initiatives in the migrant services area, provision was made for the Department to engage a consultant to develop staff training packages in cross-cultural awareness and communication. This training will be provided systematically to all Regional Office public contact staff and to all Section, Regional and Area Managers.
The consultant began work on the project in May 1989 and will complete the development of the packages by November 1989, with implementation continuing throughout 1990.
The Department consulted the Office of Multicultural Affairs and its training consultants during the initial planning phase of the project in September 1988.
The 1989/90 Budget builds on these initiatives by providing additional resources for training in cross-cultural awareness.
Recommendation 34
Response

The Department of Social Security encourage greater use of the telephone interpreter service through training programs and by installing conference telephones in at least one interviewing room in each Regional Office. (para 7.12)

The Committee may not have been aware that the Department does not need to use TIS to the same extent as in the past, primarily because of the introduction in January 1989 of the Telephone Information Program (TIP). TIP was a 1988-89 Budget initiative which has been proving very successful. (Further details on TIP are provided in comments on Recommendation 36.)

In addition, the Department has produced a training video entitled ``Communicating Through Interpreters'' which provides, among other things, comprehensive instruction for Regional Office staff in the proper use of interpreters and of the Telephone Interpreter Service (TIS).

Most Regional Offices have been provided with dual handsets to enable proper access to TIS. It is Departmental practice, however, to use TIS only in situations where a Departmental interpreter or bilingual staff member is not immediately available and generally to assist with simple enquiries. TIS is not suitable for use in more complex interview situations.
Recommendations 35 and 36
Response
A stock of application forms be available in both English and major community languages. (para 7.16)
Where a client has nominated a language, communication with that client be in both English and the preferred language. (para 7.16)

The Department has given a lot of attention to the usefulness of providing claim forms in a range of community languages. However, market research recently commissioned by the Department has shown that such an approach would not necessarily meet the needs of non-English speaking background clients (who have varying degrees of literacy in their own languages); nor is it desired by many such clients or their intermediaries.

In addition to legal considerations, there are obvious practical difficulties and resource implications involved in producing, distributing, storing and regularly updating forms in a range of languages.

A more effective approach to assisting non-English speaking background clients in this area is currently being trialled and evaluated by the Department. This involves the use of form completion aids which provide instructions in the client's preferred language on how to complete Departmental claim forms.
To assist in the planning and provision of interpreter services, the client's preferred language is now asked for on all pension and benefit claim forms.

Written advices to clients now regularly include ``language blocks'' advising clients in a range of languages to contact the Department's Telephone Information Program (TIP) if they require information and advice in their own language about the contents of the correspondence.

TIP is particularly useful for people who cannot easily get to a Regional Office because, for example, they are working during the day, they live a considerable distance away or they have family commitments which keep them at home.
TIP operates five days a week during office hours with different languages rostered throughout the week. Callers from anywhere in Australia can contact the service for the cost of a local call.
Recommendations 37 and 38
Reponse
The Department of Social Security investigate the possibility of running advertisements, similar to those which have appeared on SBS, on the ABC and other selected television stations. (para 7.23)
Regional Office Managers be encouraged to develop the use of local specialist media. (para 7.23)
The Department is a major user of ethnic press and electronic media outlets to publicise and provide information on its programs and services.

All major ethnic community newspapers are regularly provided with translated Ministerial media releases. Advertisements and articles providing information on, and explanations of, DSS payments and programs are prepared by the Department's media liaison personnel and regularly feature in the ethnic press.

Ethnic and community radio stations are used in all States to provide Social Security information to migrant communities, with the Department providing such stations with advertisements and information programs in a range of languages which, in some cases, are presented by bilingual Departmental staff.

Market research conducted last year indicated that ethnic radio is a very important source of social security information for people with a non-English speaking background. This finding has also been supported by evidence provided by Telephone Information Program (TIP) statistics. In general terms, ethnic radio has been reported by callers to TIP as a major source of referral.

More specifically, numbers of calls from particular migrant communities have consistently shown significant increases in periods immediately following the broadcast on ethnic radio of social security information in those communities' languages. The Department is keen to use this medium more to provide information to migrant communities and is examining ways of developing a more systematic approach to its use.

The ABC has advised that where the Department has community service notices (as opposed to advertising) it will place them in its schedule, provided the content and quality of production are given clearance by the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations.
At present community service notices are run during the day and sometimes late at night. They are not shown during peak times.
The Department will negotiate further with the ABC on this matter and attempt to introduce community advertisements where feasible.

In relation to the use of specialist media by Regional Managers, they are encouraged to, and do, use (particularly in country districts) local print and electronic media to respond to community concerns and queries and to provide information regarding DSS programs and facilities. The Area Outreach Officers assist Regional Managers in their media contacts and supplement these activities with direct contacts with local media.
Recommendation 39
Response
The Department of Social Security develop an information outreach program for use in schools and such community organisations as youth refuges and welfare agencies. (para 8.17)

As indicated in response to recommendations 1 to 4, the Department is expanding its local community outreach activities. Regional Office Managers and their staff are using opportunities to establish better contacts with agencies and organisations in their local areas to disseminate information about Departmental programs and services and to encourage feedback from the community on policies and procedures which affect clients.
In particular, consultations with agencies working with young people are encouraged. A national strategy for an information outreach program for use in schools is being developed.
Recommendation 40
Response
The Department of Social Security develop an in-house training module for its client contact staff comprising:
* the technical aspects of Departmental programs available to young people; and
* the economic and social climate facing young people, particularly homeless and unemployed young people. (para 8.17)

The Department already provides training in the technical aspects of programs available to young people-such as the Young Homeless Allowance. The Department is reviewing the content of its current public contact training to ensure that it gives proper appreciation of the economic and social climate affecting young people.
Recommendation 41
Response

The Department of Social Security provide a report to the Minister for Social Security on the Youth Access Project, including details of progress made to address the recommendations made in the Report. (para 8.23)

The Youth Access project ran for a year in Area South (Metro) NSW in 1986/87 on a trial basis and the final report on its achievements was presented to the Minister in November 1987. Many of its findings have been incorporated into policies aimed at young people, notably the Young Homeless Allowance and Unemployment Benefit for under 18 year olds.

The Youth Access project highlighted a range of access problems and misconceptions experienced by young people in relation to the Department. The project addressed the specific needs of young people in one area of metropolitan Sydney. Further work in relation to young people in other settings is being undertaken.
The Department's ongoing information planning and strategies are aimed at remedying the problems identified by the project report and addressing these on a national basis wherever necessary.
Recommendations 42, 43 and 44
Response
The Department of Social Security move quickly to provide staff in Regional Offices with a simple ``user friendly'' computer aid along the lines of the Social Security Enquiry System. (para 9.19)
This project commence with a trial of the modified Social Security Enquiry System in its Regional Offices. (para 9.19)

The Department of Social Security consult with the Department of Veterans' Affairs to ensure that there is minimum duplication of effort in the adaption of similar systems in both Departments. (para 9.19)

The Department is continuing its discussions with the developers of this system. However, the Department saw some limitations in using a standalone system of this kind. The system would need to be modified to integrate it with the Department's existing mainstream systems and client database. The Department is looking at how best this can be done and whether the Social Security Enquiry System is best suited and cost effective for this function.
The Department is well aware of the benefits arising from the use of `expert systems' and has already developed a prototype system for use in the administration of overseas pension payments.

The Department is continuing to study and develop other Decision Support Facilities and is confident that a number of such facilities will be developed to help Regional Office staff with complex aspects of their work.
Discussions are continuing with the Department of Veterans' Affairs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs titled Fairness, Courtesy and Efficiency? is an important report which was tabled in this House some months ago. I should just place on record that the need for an inquiry was brought to the attention of the Committee by the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) on 3 February 1988. The specific terms of reference, which he was involved in drafting for the Committee, were:

SPEECH.PARA: (i) the effectiveness of current methods of providing information to clients and potential clients of Social Security entitlements;
(ii) the effectiveness of methods currently used by the Department of Social Security to provide face to face contact with clients and potential clients; and
(iii) any proposals to enhance awareness and `take-up' of entitlements by persons who qualify for assistance under Social Security programs.

In the analysis conducted by the Committee three key words were used: fairness, courtesy and efficiency. I was somewhat surprised that at no stage in the departmental response or in the statement made by the Minister were any of those words referred to. I think one could be excused for saying that the Minister really has only given himself the opportunity to make yet another statement to the House about his stewardship of the overall direction of Government policy. He has not responded to the essential elements of this report. As the Deputy Chairman of the Committee I find the Government's response and the response of the Department of Social Security to the report somewhat disappointing. I say that in the sense that when one reads the analysis of the recommendations the report contains and then studies in detail the paper which has now been incorporated in Hansard, the Department tends to have taken the view that there is an adversary relationship between itself and the Committee.

In fairness, if virtually all the initiatives contained in the report were already in the process of being introduced, as the analysis suggests, why was the Committee not told? In all fairness, we have a substantial workload on that Committee and if the Department wishes to work with us both sides would be the first to say that we want close cooperation. The language in the response from the Department gives me, as a member of the Committee--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order to correct an error of fact. The Department made a full submission to the Committee indicating the direction of what was in train.
—There is no point of order.

—There is a tendency in the analytical stage of these things on occasions-and this appears to be one-for there not to be as close a rapport between the Committee and the Department as we would want to see. On initial assessment the Government's response to the recommendations of the inquiry therefore seems somewhat cursory and even suggests that the inquiry might have got it wrong. I acknowledge the Minister's comments that the size and administrative complexities of the Department make change difficult, especially for an organisation as large as this one. It is probably the largest organisation in the Public Service, with the exception of the Department of Defence, and therefore changes of the number, complexity and nature we have seen in the last seven years create major administrative problems. I think it is a compliment to the Department and to its staff that in fact it has been able to absorb most of those changes as well as it has in fact done.

SPEECH.PARA: The findings of the Committee report outline a number of problems which we believe the Department has in its interface with the client groups. As well as the diverse mix of personal and social demands which the Department must meet in its role of service delivery to clients, these problems are mainly due to the speed and complexity of change with which the Department and its officers have to deal, often on a day-to-day basis. The Minister has often been heard to boast about the revolution that he has effected in the area of social security and welfare. The Government has introduced a vast number of changes during its term. That is not a deniable fact by any means. But many of these have been welcomed by the Opposition, particularly in the areas of family payments and child support.

This revolution, as the Minister refers to it, has not come without its adverse consequences. It has simply not been possible for many departmental officers to keep abreast of the many changes while trying at the same time to cope adequately with the day-to-day workload, which certainly varies from office to office depending on the suburbs and the areas where people may have various difficulties in relation to unemployment and other benefits. In addition, the recent fast rate of change with regard to social security entitlements has greatly increased the necessity for social security clients to seek information and often advocacy support from outside the Department. This is not necessarily of their choice. It is simply an acknowledgment of a reality that they feel, regrettably on some occasions, some degree of alienation between the person who is there seeking support and the departmental officers who are meant to be helping them. The advice and the information given to the Committee on these matters from organisations such as the Wright centres in both Sydney and Melbourne did emphasise that there was a problem; it was related not just to migrant groups, which often have a language difficulty, but to a range of other groups who on occasions feel some alienation from the system.

Departmental personnel are further constrained by the policy processes which embargo promoting changes until they are announced by the Government itself. This means that regional office staff are often unable to respond promptly to queries with consistent and accurate information. As I said, some of the changes introduced by the Government have been welcomed by the Opposition, but the Government does have a woeful track record in the areas of complex administrative change, the capacity to involve the Department and its officers closely in that change process, and above all, to give them the capacity to be able to explain that change as soon as possible after the event. There have been so many cases-for example, changes to the assets test, and things like that-where there has been considerable confusion among the recipient community as a result of the problems of being able to get advised by the Department. The introduction of the child support scheme, which has had bipartisan support, is an example of the sweeping administrative change that has left departmental workers often inadequately prepared for the onslaught of inquiries and administrative complexities which the system has brought about.

The Government is obviously less than generous in its allocation of extra staff and information services for its office personnel. The vast number of inquiries to my office, and no doubt to many other members, and the tragic story, for example, of a woman who was advised by a departmental officer that she had to pursue the father of her child for maintenance payments before a sole parent pension could be paid and who was in fact bashed as a result, are but sad testimony of the inadequate resources and the inaccurate information which regrettably is on occasions given by officers to clients.

The Opposition, in its support for stage 2 of the child support legislative package, has requested a firm commitment from the Government that more adequate resources for information and staff training be made available. That is completely consistent with this report. The complexities of the system are not aided by the dissemination of inaccurate information by the Minister himself, and unfortunately this is the case. The Government's pensioner newspaper, the Age Pensioner News, for example, contained glaring errors and misled the 1.7 million Australian pensioners to whom this piece of blatant propaganda was sent. Getting wrong the non-taxable income threshold for pensioners is simply inexcusable. Similarly, the excuse of the Department, and presumably the Minister, that the Australian Taxation Office gave them the wrong figures is itself not an adequate response. Pensioners and the groups to which this type of documentation has been targeted have a right to expect accurate information from the Government no matter which department of government is ultimately responsible. Similarly, on the ABC AM program on 31 July of this year the Minister was asked:
Today I understand is the last day when pension recipients can declare their tax file number. Is that the situation?
The Minister responded:
Yes, and it is very important that people that haven't done that as yet make contact with their local social security office or the Department of Taxation as quickly as possible.

The outcome of that particular bit of misinformation is that scores of distressed age pensioners phoned their local DSS offices and the Tax Office as a result of that comment. One DSS officer in Burnie in Tasmania alone received over 80 calls. One has to ask the question: How can officers of the Department be expected to cope with their own workload in addition to having to unscramble premature eggs laid by Ministers or by others in the minds of their constituent client groups, especially when they are based on wrong information?

The Minister's statement refers to the extensive advertising campaign being undertaken at present in various areas of Government policy-undoubtedly related to the next election. But he has stated in his own response here today the amount of resources which are going to be allocated in social security towards that particular result. What one has to ask, however, is whether the information being provided is adequate and whether it is accurate. The examples I have given so far give one reason to suspect that that is not the case. We are very happy that action has now been taken to establish a permanent 008 telephone facility, which will be a tremendous help to clients of the Department. This advertising campaign will no doubt have put the Department under even more pressure with increased amounts of inquiries which it will no doubt generate.

I would like to put on record my admiration for the DSS office personnel, who do work under enormous pressure at the coalface in the delivery of quality service to its clients. The pace of change over recent years occurring within the Department as a result of government policy has brought great pressure on those officers and, all else being equal, I think they have handled the situation as well as can be expected. But as has been brought out on numerous occasions in recent weeks, there is always the difficulty of being able to strike an adequate balance between the capacity of the Department to give the highest level of service possible while at the same time ensuring that the vast majority of taxpayers who are carrying the cost of these services are also getting value for money.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The havoc wreaked upon the Australian economy by the Prime Minister's confrontationist mismanagement of the Australian transport system.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I preface my remarks today by saying that the Opposition is not aligned with the Australian Federation of Air Pilots; neither do we support its action; neither are we supportive of the attitude taken by any other political party in Australia has neither; the cause of this particular dispute that is disrupting Australia today been brought about by any industrial relations policy of the Federal Opposition. The strike and the causes of the strike and the ongoing nature of the strike must be laid firmly at the feet of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and of this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: This particular situation that we have in Australia today is a culmination of what can only be described as nine months of absolute disaster in terms of the administration of transport in Australia. We have seen this year nothing but disaster, and we have seen nothing this year other than the suffering and the hardship and, indeed, the sheer stupidity in trying to cripple Australia's foremost overseas foreign exchange earner-tourism.

I remind the House of some of those areas where we have seen the Government entering into such disastrous paths. Going back to late November-December last year, we had the first inklings that something was wrong in the air traffic control systems of Australia. It is more than eight months since the Sydney Airport disaster started-eight months, and we still do not know what the final deal is with the air traffic controllers. We still do not know whether we will see any improvement in the air traffic control facilities not only in Sydney but in other major airports around Australia. It is now four months since we determined in this House that one of the reasons that the growth in international tourism to Australia had slowed was simply that overseas operators could not get a guarantee of the movement of their passengers through Sydney Airport because of the delays caused by air traffic controllers.

I take honourable members back to some of the debates that we have had over the past eight months about the ongoing problems at Sydney Airport. There is no doubt that if the Government had followed the Opposition's strategy and had gone ahead with the third runway at Sydney Airport, we would not have had the delays that we are experiencing today. Yet the procrastination continues and there is still no evidence that the Government will definitely go ahead with that third runway. I am sure that it will do so after the next election, but in the meantime the suffering continues.

Some months ago many honourable members received a copy of a directive from the Australian Federation of Air Pilots entitled `Deadline 89 Issue No. 3', which set out the situation regarding the oncoming dispute. The Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Peter Morris) was asked a question in this House on 19 May about what he was going to do in terms of planning for this strike. He said nothing.
