If the Government was really serious about trying to get its act together it would have been conscious of an article that appeared in the Australian Financial Review on Wednesday, 31 May this year, which stated that the domestic airlines were gearing up for industrial trouble. If it missed the article in the Australian Financial Review, I am sure it would have seen a headline in the Australian of Wednesday, 7 June this year, which read, `Pilots play down talk of strike', but the strike was on, and nothing was done.

I suppose the real question we should ask the Government is: Why was nothing done? Is there not some sort of hidden agenda behind this whole terrible exercise that Australia is being subjected to at the moment? Is not the real story behind this strike a number of issues? Is not the real story about this strike, firstly, that the Prime Minister had every intention of making this strike a major election issue? Is it not true that the Prime Minister hoped that he could break the back of the pilots early in the piece, then go to the electorate and say, `Here I am, the world's greatest environmentalist; here I am, the world's greatest supporter of the ethnic community; here I am, the world's greatest industrial relations expert'? Perhaps the second part of that agenda was that if the country is in absolute chaos, the Prime Minister would still have the opportunity of calling an election based on the theme, `Who is running the country?'. That must be considered.

The second part of the agenda is undoubtedly that there are certain personnel within the airlines who want this strike. Next year Australia will enter an era of airline deregulation. There is no doubt that Australian airlines at the moment are not properly equipped to handle any sort of competition. We have been stifled by a two-airline system for years. The airlines have structured themselves into a very comfortable situation which means that if there is competition in the market, under the present regime they will find it very hard to compete. Is not the third part of the agenda the fact that the pilots realise what will happen when deregulation occurs and they, too, want to be in a position of strength so that they can negotiate when that reorganisation takes place?

The Prime Minister and this Government took the blunderbuss approach when one classic word should have been at the forefront of trying to deal with the pilots. That word was `negotiation'; the simple fact of being able to talk to each other. We have cut off that option or, rather, the Prime Minister and the Government have cut off that option. It seems absolutely amazing to me that in Question Time today the Prime Minister put on his Rambo gear again, and went hell for leather, blasting everybody he could lay his hand on. A question was asked of the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories (Mr Holding), who gave a very considered reply. It seems rather strange that the Minister responsible for tourism could give us figures outlining the absolute disaster that is being wreaked on that part of the economy, yet the Prime Minister's answer did not concern what was happening to the tourist industry or to the economy in general. He just wanted to blast away.

The sad part of the whole situation is that Australia could be shut up for months. We do not want that. The Government, because of its very narrow industrial relations system, is bringing Australia to the verge of economic disaster. As one cynic I was speaking to this morning said, `Well, it's really a Government plot to boost tourism to Australia, because when the economy finally collapses and the Australian dollar drops below 50c, we are going to be a very good bargain'. What will that do to Australia if that is allowed to happen?

In discussing a matter of public importance yesterday I gave a litany of the costs of the strike to the tourist industry. We should update those figures today because, as the Minister said, everybody is suffering. That is the point about the tourist industry: everybody does suffer, and that is sad. I do not know how many honourable members watched the rugby league match last night between the Brisbane Broncos and Cronulla. It was interesting that there were only 16,000 people at the game. Usually, in excess of 10,000 people travel from Brisbane for those interstate games. They were not there last night. The sporting industry is suffering.

Mr Deputy Speaker, you will be interested to know that the Perth basketball team, which was playing the Newcastle basketball team, yesterday travelled from Perth to Auckland, back to Sydney and then from Sydney to Newcastle to play the game. I think you will be interested to know as well, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the hockey championships to be played in Tasmania last weekend were cancelled. There is not one section of the Australian community that is not being affected by this action of the Government.

I refer the House to the recent statement from the Australian Travel Industry Association. It said it was very concerned that at the moment $19 billion worth of new tourism plant is currently under construction or about to be commenced, and that that new development is in jeopardy. I will cite some figures from the Boeing report on the development of tourism in Australia. Let us say that, of that $19 billion that is being committed for new development, only about $11 billion has actually been committed, and that that is the money that is in real jeopardy. Do honourable members know what that does? That takes out of the economy $5.5 billion worth of building works, $3.9 billion worth of furniture, fittings and equipment, $600m in consultancy fees, and $1 billion in land and associated costs. It also brings earthworks to a halt. If that development does not go ahead, we would expect to lose 2.77 million cubic metres, or 277,413 tip-truck loads, of dirt. What will that do for the trucking industry? What about the fact that 2.31 million cubic metres of concrete presently is not being able to be poured? What about the 242, 377 tonnes of reinforcement, the 3.26 million square metres of carpet, the 243,670 showers, the 1,562 lifts, and the 915,600 square metres of curtain materials?

The Government can boast quite proudly to some of its union colleagues that because of the attitude it is taking, 183,750 beds are in jeopardy, as are 367,000 bedside tables, 105,000 desks, 105,000 television sets, 9,262,052 glasses, 115,000 telephones, 1,010 bars, 2,530 beer taps, 79,000,000 bars of soap, 115,000,000 towels washed per annum, and 80,000,000 sheets washed per annum. This is the biggest industry that we have in Australia. It is the biggest growth industry in Australia. This industry is going to the wall in a hurry, yet the Government is not prepared to allow the pilots to talk to the airlines. The Government is prepared to put this country's future development at risk. It is prepared to put the jobs of the young people of Australia at risk, purely because it wants to back a failed industrial relations system. The sad part is simply this: the stand-downs have already started in the hotel and hospitality industry and we may never ever get those jobs back. This weekend the airlines are going to decide the future of 22,000 employees in that particular industry.

If you go home tonight, Mr Deputy Speaker, I hope you get a hire car driver who will tell you about what is happening in this particular city. The one I had the night before last, which was Monday, had one non-parliamentary job all day. He has just invested $200,000 in that particular company. He is going out of business fast.

What about the money that is being put into the promotion of Australia by this Government, and rightly so, for tourism. That is being wasted. We are going to have to spend more, the Minister tells us today, to try to retrieve the situation overseas. What about the money that has been invested by State governments in providing the tourism training infrastructure? What is going to happen there? Why are we training these people when this Government, because of its action, is doing its ultimate to wreck this industry? There is no doubt that it is attempting to wreck this industry if it continues to take this stupid line that is being taken now. What we are saying is that people must talk. The last thing that we want is another repetition of what the Prime Minister did yesterday in relation to our question about the negotiated settlements between Qantas Airways Ltd and its captains of the new 747 aircraft.

It was quite obvious from the Qantas press release that was issued last night that that deal had been agreed upon. It was an interim arrangement, but the deal had still been agreed upon. Yet the Prime Minister went to town once again and really took the big stick to the international airline pilots. If I were a member of the international airline pilots organisation whose members so far have acted very responsibly indeed, I would have been upset with his attitude too. The last thing that this country can afford to happen at the moment is for the Qantas pilots to go out on strike. But if we are going to continue to have that attitude of the Prime Minister we could well have a strike on our hands and that is the last thing that we want.

The Opposition's simple appeal is this: this Government is sending our economy to the brink; this Government at the moment must be fully responsible for what it is doing to the tourist industry. All the Opposition says is this, `For goodness sake, let's take the high ground, let's get the pilots talking to the airlines, let's cool everybody down, let's try to get some sense back into the situation and save Australia'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset I flatly and absolutely refute the terms of this matter of public importance, which are:

SPEECH.PARA: The havoc wreaked upon the Australian economy by the Prime Minister's confrontationist mismanagement of the Australian transport system.

What a ludicrous and ridiculous matter of public importance. What a ludicrous and ridiculous topic. Every honourable member sitting on the Opposition side knows that that is absolutely untrue. They do not believe a word of it. If they do then they are even more naive than I would believe them to be. The fact is, of course, that the last thing that this Government wants is to have a dispute with the pilots. What is even more important is that we preserve this economy and that we do not allow concessions to wage claims which would destroy the economy. Of course, that is totally forgotten or ignored by the Opposition.

Let me just come to some of the things that were ridiculously suggested by the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) in opening this matter of public importance. He suggested that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) wanted to have a dispute with the pilots for political reasons, so that we could call an election on the basis of resolving the dispute. What a ridiculous suggestion, an absurd suggestion which is hardly worthy of reply. As though the Government would delight in causing strife to travellers, to the tourist industry and to others. Of course, the reality is that the last thing the Government wants is that. But what the Government is concerned to do is to ensure that we have a proper wages policy in this country; that we have an economy which can have some chance of recovery and will recover with a proper wages policy, not of course with a wages policy which would apply if this Opposition were in government.

What, in fact, this matter of public importance is about is a further demonstration of the fact that this Opposition has no political principles whatever. It will simply seize every opportunity to try to maximise political advantage, even if its means diminishing or trying to diminish the attempts of the Government to resolve a dispute. It has no compunction at all, no qualms at all, about jumping into bed with the pilots. Members of the Opposition are shameless, political harlots in bed with the pilots, and they know it. They have no principles whatever. They are quite prepared to say, `Just resolve this. We'll go off and get discussions going', as though that is some sort of industrial relations policy. What an industrial relations policy.

Just get the parties talking, that is what they say. That is what the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) was saying yesterday; what the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) has been saying; what the spokesman in the Senate, Senator Chaney, has been saying. They have been saying, `Just get the parties together and try to get them to resolve it'. Well, of course, that is what they did for years and years. Under the now Opposition, that is what they did. That is how they resolved their industrial disputes. Of course, what happened was that they built up a tremendous level of wages and conditions which are, as they say in their own journal, `the envy of the rest of the world'. The pilots have the best conditions of pilots anywhere in the world. That happened because of what the Opposition allowed to happen under the industrial relations policy which applied under the Opposition policies for the decade that it was in government in the post-war period with the two-airline policy applying. That is what has brought about the conditions the pilots now enjoy.

There was just this simple, `Go off and resolve the damn thing and forget the cost'. There was no wages policy to apply, no framework to apply. That is still the policy of the Opposition. It still has not learned anything. It is still sitting there advocating a policy which says, `Just go off and negotiate and everyone should do this-not just the pilots; everyone should do it. Opt out of the system. Go off and get a voluntary agreement. Go off and decide what your wages and conditions should be. Let all those with strong bargaining strength get out there and screw the economy for all they are worth for their own personal aggrandisement at the expense of everybody else'. That is what the Opposition policy is. It is right here-all about the voluntary agreements and the opting out. There is no suggestion that there should be a wages policy framework; no suggestion that people would have to get the approval of the Commission. They simply go out and do what the pilots are doing, and the Opposition is still saying that right now.

Well, the pilots are not just saying, `We want to negotiate'. They are saying that, but they are also saying-and the Opposition totally forgets that they are saying this-`We want to negotiate outside the wage fixing principles'. There is a big gun at the head of the airlines outside the wage fixing principles. That is the basis upon which they want to negotiate. That is the only basis upon which they will negotiate. The Opposition is saying that that is okay. Its members are absolute wreckers. They are people who are quite prepared to destroy the Australian economy in the hope that they might then get back on the government benches. They are an absolute disgrace. They have no political principles whatever; they were a shameless lot of political harlots who have no right to be in government in this country. I would have thought surely, after all this time in opposition, that they might have learned something.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker: The Minister has twice referred to the Opposition as harlots and I ask that he withdraw on this occasion and that he cut it out. He can sit down while I am talking, too. I think it is totally unnecessary and it is untrue, about as untrue as the rest of the things he is saying. I ask him to withdraw.
—There is no point of order.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, on a further point of order: Are you ruling that `harlot' is a parliamentary word?
—I said there is no point of order. I am calling the Minister.

—I have taken exception and I have asked the Minister to withdraw the word `harlot'. It is an outrageous word to be used in here. He has learnt it from the Treasurer. But if he thinks he is going to replace him, this place will go further down. I ask the Minister to withdraw that word.
—There is no point of order. I call the Minister.
—Well, we have got a new standard in this place.
—I call the Minister.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, as I was saying, this Opposition has disgraced this Parliament and disgraced the nation by its behaviour in this matter, since--
—On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker: I believe that it is incumbent on you as Deputy Speaker to give a ruling when a point of order is raised with you.

—I have given a ruling. There was no point of order. In effect, you are seeking an explanation of my earlier ruling that there was no point of order. As the term was used generally and was not applied particularly, I ruled that the term was in order. Had the term been used particularly I would have ruled it out of order.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, on the point of order: I put it to you that the term `harlot' is an unparliamentary term, even if it is claimed to have general application. In itself, the word `harlot', used in the context in which it has been used in this place, is unparliamentary.

—I am happy to consider the honourable member's comment. In the context in which the Minister has spoken I am not ruling it out of order, but I will consider the comment made by the honourable member for Curtin.

—As I was saying, the Opposition has shown, quite clearly, that it is in support of the pilots in this matter. It has not in any way condemned the pilots. Despite the opening remarks made by the honourable member for Fadden, there has been no condemnation of the pilots. Yesterday the honourable member for Flinders really condemned them. He really got stuck into them and flayed them. He really belted the pilots with a big handful of fairy floss. He said, `The Opposition does not have much time for the pilots'. That was the extent of his condemnation. The pilots reeled in anguish from this tremendous verbal attack by the honourable member for Flinders-a hopeless effort. He went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: They have a double-barrelled shotgun pointed at the head of this economy and they have already pulled one of the triggers.

That was it. The pilots are still recovering from the shock of that attack. Of course, no-one else from the Opposition has condemned the pilots either. Senator Chaney, the spokesman for the Opposition on industrial relations, was asked on the Face to Face program:
Do you have any sympathy for the pilots?
He said:
I have sympathy with the whole of the Australian workforce which is-I mean, the pilots are at the very high paid end, and so you don't spend a lot of time wasting sympathy on them.

So he really belted the pilots too. He showed that he was terribly annoyed with them. This is the extent of the criticism from the Opposition. Of course, it is understandable on two grounds: firstly, honourable members opposite want an enormous industrial conflagration-they want to see conflict and mayhem because they think that will advantage them-and, secondly, philosophically they support the pilots because it is their policy. The pilots are doing what members of the Opposition say they should do. They have spelt it out time and again in their industrial relations policy which, as I was saying, is a policy for voluntary agreements and opting out. Of course, that is what the pilots are trying to do. The Government is saying, `We will not let you opt out because we know that that is a totally destructive industrial relations policy. If we allowed you to opt out we would get a whole host of other people with strong bargaining power who would do exactly the same'. We would get opting out by a vast array of groups in the country which would mean that our wages policy would be in shreds and this economy would be in ruin. That is what happened when honourable members opposite were last in government and, in large measure, that is why they went into opposition. They still have not learnt anything about that.

It is understandable that the Opposition supports the pilots, because the pilots are doing what the Opposition wants them to do. It is as though the pilots picked up the Opposition's policy and said, `The Opposition says we should be opting out and making a big wage claim. Don't worry about the wage fixing principles; just reach an agreement with the employers. They are in a nice position. They can afford to pass on the costs, as they have done time after time in the past, and we will just go ahead and do as we did before'. From the way the pilots are performing at present it is as though they have a script from the Opposition. There has been no condemnation from the Opposition. The honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) reached scurrilously low grounds. He raised safety scares to try to frighten people about the alternative arrangements that are being set up. Yesterday the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) accused me of being a strikebreaker because we used the Royal Australian Air Force. Of course, that is exactly the pilots' line; that is what they are saying. As I have said, everything members of the Opposition do and say indicates that they are simply in bed with the pilots. Their remarks fit in with that absolutely. There has been no condemnation of the pilots or support for the kind of action that they are taking. Members of the Opposition are trying to disrupt the alternative arrangements that have been made. Of course, a few days ago they started off saying, `We generally support the Government', but then they thought, `Hell, why don't we try to make some political mileage out of this', and off they went. As I have said, it is understandable because of their philosophical basis. They are highly supportive of what the pilots have done.

The Government has taken a highly principled stand in this dispute. The Government is taking a stand against the pilots because that is the only thing the Government can do. The Government, in doing that, is supporting the airlines. Ansett Airlines of Australia, not being owned by the Government, is capable of working out its own industrial relations policy. I assure honourable members that it is finding this as hard as Australian Airlines. I noticed yesterday that the honourable member for Flinders condemned us for supporting the cancellation of the award. Of course, that was what the airlines, the employers in the airline industry, wanted to do. They believed that that was the best thing to do. Ansett, East-West Airlines Ltd and Australian Airlines wanted to do that. Members of the Opposition are saying that we should not support the airlines by cancelling the award. Again this is a demonstration of how they are in bed with the pilots.

I reiterate that nothing could be more important for the Government now than resisting this claim by the pilots. Union after union and the Australian Council of Trade Unions have said, `We could not live with a situation in which this highly paid group gets a large wage increase'. If they get it others will get it. Of course they will seek to claim it. We will have industrial disputes and large wage claims all over the place. Wages will skyrocket and the country will be pushed into stagflation. We will not allow that to happen. Of course, honourable members opposite know that that is what will happen under their policies. They have learnt nothing about wages policy. Everything they are saying and doing now demonstrates that.

Finally, the actions taken by this Government to ensure that there is a service for the travelling public in this country ought to receive the strong support of a decent, principled opposition which is capable of taking some sort of statesmanlike view and helping the nation in a time of need. But no; all it has done is seek to undermine us by raising scurrilous safety allegations which have no basis in fact. Members of the Opposition simply have no standing in this place and the people of Australia should see them for what they are. They have learnt nothing about economics or industrial relations and, worst of all, they have learnt nothing about political principle. They can rest assured that in no way will the people of Australia put them back in charge of this country for a long time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Anybody listening to the speech just delivered by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) would have been shocked to hear him commence by denying that this Government is responsible for the havoc and the chaos that exist in the Australian transport system at the moment. Anybody listening to the Minister's speech would also have been shocked to hear his attempts to pin the blame for this pilots dispute somehow or other fairly and squarely on the shoulders of the Opposition parties. I remind the Minister that he is in government and he is in charge of these things. His Leader, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), has inflamed those pilots into the action that they are taking today. He knows that and he knows that we are not responsible for it; we have no association with the pilots. He also knows that the reason he is taking these actions is not for any great political principle or ideology; it is simply because he wants to try to protect that sweetheart arrangement that he has with those harlots in the Australian Council of Trade Unions to ensure that members of this Government get re-elected next time around. If it was fair enough for the Minister to use the term that I have just used, let me use it against honourable members opposite because that is the new rule that we have in this House.
—I just ask the honourable member for Gilmore whether he is using the term in a particular sense or in a general sense.

—I use it in no more direct a sense than the sense in which it was used by the Minister himself. The honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull), who led this debate on behalf of the Opposition, discussed the particular arrangements surroundings the aviation industry at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: As honourable members on this side of the House would know, it is not only the aviation industry which is in chaos; it is not only that industry which has been put in a state of disaster and disruption as a consequence of the mismanagement of this Government. If we look at any area of the Australian transport system we will discover that it is in a state of chaos. Look at roads: there have been more than 30 per cent reductions in road funding since this Government came into power. Look at our coastal shipping industry: the Government is refusing to allow increased efficiencies by refusing to lift cabotage. Look at our waterfront: the reforms that are being proposed there are being denied the Australian public by this Government. Look at the inefficiencies, the costs, the rorts and the expenses that are going on there, all because of this Government's very close arrangement, its very close deal, with the ACTU and the trade unions in those industries.

As a consequence of the pilots dispute we have seen a great hypocrisy, a double standard. We have seen over these last couple of weeks the way the Government has reacted. In Victoria over the last few days a huge industrial disputation has been going on. The waterfront employees have been on strike for about a week. We have had massive losses to the Victorian economy as a consequence. That strike has spread beyond the waterfront, of course, and is affecting all levels of industry in Victoria, costing the economy of Victoria and consequently the economy of Australia a great deal. Where is the Prime Minister on this subject? Why is he not speaking out? For goodness sake, there is a tremendous amount of waste, a tremendous amount of cost and inefficiency on the waterfront and through other industrial disputes in Victoria at the moment. But we do not hear the Prime Minister speak out at all, not a whisper.

When it comes to somebody who is not affiliated with the Australian Labor Party (ALP) and the ACTU we hear him speak out. We see him vigorous. We see him making decisions and taking action and being bold and strong, a hero. That is the double standard. In the course of one week the Australian Federation of Air Pilots had its industrial award scrapped. In the course of one week the Government has allowed the application of civil law so that airlines and tourist operators who are affected by the pilots dispute could sue those individual pilots who are causing the dispute. In the course of one week we have seen the Government bring in the military to be strikebreakers. Yet while all of this decisiveness and action from the Government is going on we hear not one word, not one whisper, from our heroic Prime Minister, who is trying to get into bed, as the Minister has put it, with his colleagues in the ACTU. We see a double standard of mammoth proportions.

We have seen over the last little while another example of that double standard. The Government has been talking about reform on our waterfront, and it is on that point that I want to make a few remarks now. Let me go back over the history of reform on the waterfront. We will see just how slowly this Government can work when it is dealing with its mates in the trade unions. In September 1984 the Government implemented the Webber inquiry, which looked into improved efficiencies in the waterfront area. It took two years to make its report. At the end of two years recommendations were brought down. The Government decided, `We cannot move too fast; we are talking about our mates here. Let us have another inquiry'. So we had an Inter-State Commission inquiry, which took 2 1/2 years. At the end of that inquiry the Government entered into a process of negotiation. It will be six months from the announcement of those recommendations of the ISC before the Government will make any decisions as to what it will do-another six months. When those negotiations are complete there will be a further period of three years for the implementation of those recommendations, if any are to be picked up at all. So after eight years we may finally see some reform on the waterfront.

When it comes to actions in the aviation industry, when we are dealing with someone not affiliated with the ALP, it all happens in a week. That is the double standard that is so eagerly portrayed by this Government. In addition, the chaos on our waterfront is being perpetuated by the fact that the Government is having these negotiations carried out by a body called the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority. That body is not made up of people who use the waterfront, the importers and the exporters, the people one would think would have a vested interest in what might be going on there in terms of reforms and efficiencies. No, we do not include those sorts of people. My goodness, they are not one of us! This Reform Authority is made up of people from the Government, the Waterside Workers Federation, that well known reforming body, and the stevedores. Out of all that, what sort of reforms do we expect to get? We will get no great reforms from that Authority because those people have a vested interest in maintaining the status quo. When it comes to the ALP and its ACTU mates I am afraid that reform just does not happen.

If we compare the way this Government has dealt with reform on the waterfront with the way reform on the waterfront has taken place in Britain, we see surprising differences. Reform on the waterfront in Britain took a total of three months earlier this year. There was an Act of Parliament, some industrial disputation that petered out after a couple of weeks, and reform was implemented virtually over a period of three months. Yet under this Government reform here is going to take eight years. That is the sort of action we see.

The Opposition also notes with some alarm the Moody's Investors Service Inc. report which only yesterday downgraded Australia's creditworthiness by one notch. Moody's highlighted the lack of reform within our tranports system as being one of the reasons why it had downgraded our creditworthiness. Moody's report refers to the continued slow pace of structural adjustment which makes Australia ill positioned to weather the next downturn in the global business cycle without further large increases in foreign debt. It continues:

The rating agency also pointed out that the downgrade reflects several other considerations. The first is the persistence of structural weaknesses imbedded in Australia's domestic and international position, such as intransigent rigidities in the local labour and transport markets. These constrain international competitiveness.

Moody's knows it, the people in the industries know it, the people around Australia know it because they are all feeling the pinch. They are feeling the pinch from a government which is doing nothing to attack the real causes of concern within our transport industry. Whether it is the pilots in the aviation industry, whether it is the air traffic controllers, whether it is the people on the waterfront, whether it is people in our coastal shipping services, this Government is not doing it. As a consequence, we are being downgraded from a country with a good credit rating, which we had some years ago before Labor took charge of the whole show. The Business Council of Australia has estimated that the Government's intransigence in terms of reform on our waterfront is costing the gross domestic product of Australia $4 billion per year. That is a greater cost to this economy than what is going on with the pilots dispute.

The cost to the economy is in this Government's mismanagement of the transport system. The cost to this economy is in this Government's determination to stick to age old Labor principles. It is costing tourist operators and the average Australian a tremendous amount. We have chaos in our transport system. It is wreaking damage on every single Australian. The Minister should not kid himself that Australians are not being hurt by this because I can assure him that they are. They will get no relief until we have a government which is determined to implement real reform in our transport system.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter of public importance put forward by the Opposition is a piece of hypocrisy and a nonsense. None of the debate put forward by the Opposition this afternoon has outlined the history of this dispute or, indeed, dealt with it in any substance. It has been a sham, a debate where those opposite have heaped abuse on the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) and also on the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). Nothing of substance has been put forward by the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: It is worth outlining the history of this dispute. From September last year the Australian Federation of Air Pilots made it quite clear that it intended to obtain a substantial increase in wages. It also gave notice that it would review its position when the no extra claims commitment expired in June of this year. In that period the pilots held a 24-hour stoppage for mass meetings; they commenced planning for extended industrial action. Indeed, they gave a name to it, the Deadline 89 campaign. The Federation served a log of claims on Australian Airlines and commenced negotiations with Australian Airlines. As part of these negotiations, Australian Airlines indicated that it could negotiate only on an industry approach, not in isolation from other operators. Australian Airlines indicated that it wanted to address productivity issues and other concepts and conditions of employment. The Federation of Air Pilots subsequently withdrew its log of claims. In July this year it served on all domestic operators a pay claim of 29.47 per cent. On 1 August the Federation said that its claim was not negotiable and it was not interested in working within the wages system. On 7 August the Federation's approach was rejected by the airline companies, who made it clear that they would maintain an industry approach to achieve a common outcome on wages and conditions of employment. Negotiations by the parties continued without change.

The dispute was notified to the Industrial Relations Commission on 4 August, and stop-work meetings were held on 9 August. Hearings were held in the Industrial Relations Commission on 10, 11 and 15 August when the Commission directed the parties to confer within the framework of wage fixing principles. It called on the Federation to cease industrial action. The parties met again on 17 August and the Federation reiterated its intent to negotiate directly with companies outside the wage fixing system. The following day the Federation introduced its 9 to 5 work rule. The Industrial Relations Commission heard applications to cancel the awards, and on 19 August the Commission cancelled the awards for a period of 12 months. That is a brief outline of the history of this current dispute.

It is crystal clear that the Federation was absolutely resolved that it wanted to be outside the wage fixing system. This is despite the companies' plea for it to remain in the wage fixing system. This is despite the companies' commitment to the national wage case principles. This is despite the commitment of all other unions and wage earners to the accord, and despite the wishes of the Hawke Labor Government. The Federation has spurned all calls for responsible negotiations. Now it must live with those consequences. The Federation has forsaken the rights of its pilots. It has forsaken the protection offered by the wage fixing system.

Against that background it is also very alarming to read that the Opposition's policy, as outlined by Senator Chaney in yesterday's Australian Financial Review, is on all fours with the Federation of Air Pilots' current campaign. In yesterday's Financial Review Senator Chaney said:
It is central to our own policy that the best way to conduct industrial relations in this country is for direct employer-employee negotiations at the enterprise level.

That is the same policy as those of the McLachlans, the Costelloes, the Stones, the Copemans and the Kemps. This is the policy that is advocated by the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) on behalf of the legal profession and others. This is the same policy that the Liberal and National parties had in 1981-82, when we lost 249,000 working days every month. Senator Chaney, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, prefers to sit on the fence. He wants to have two bob each way. He advocates an increase in the penalty provisions of the Industrial Relations Act. As the Prime Minister said during Question Time, Senator Chaney's initial policy was to support the Pilots Federation outside the wage fixing system. Now he wants to amend the Industrial Relations Act to introduce these penal provisions to have them operate within the system. He is having two bob each way.

Let us take a closer look at the Liberal and National parties' policy. The current pilots dispute is an example of the Opposition's industrial relations policy in action. Among other things, the Opposition's policy calls for secret ballots before strikes. The Opposition's policy calls for employers and workers to opt out of the wages system of this country. The Opposition's policy says that employers and their workers should negotiate directly on wages and conditions to create voluntary agreements, and its policy says that all such agreements should be a base for more flexible and efficient working practices.

Let us measure the Opposition's policy against the current pilots dispute. Firstly, I refer to the call for secret ballots before strikes. Before the current dispute went ahead the Pilots Federation held a secret ballot. The Opposition says that employers and workers should opt out of the wage fixing system. The Australian Federation of Air Pilots made it quite clear that it wanted to pull out of the wage fixing system. The employers and airlines successfully obtained an order to cancel its award. The Opposition demands that the courts should be used to enforce such voluntary agreements. Not only did the airlines resort to court action but also there is now the threat that tourism operators and other Australian businesses will be forced to take action against the pilots for compensation worth millions of dollars for the enormous damage that those businesses have suffered as a result of the pilots strike.

The Opposition says that all employment agreements should be based on more flexible and efficient working practices. Everyone now knows that the airlines are doing their best to negotiate fresh contracts of employment that will include provisions for vastly improved productivity by the pilots. Why, therefore, is the Opposition refusing to back the airlines in this dispute? This dispute has not been caused by the airlines; it has not been caused by the courts. This dispute has not been caused by the Government. This dispute is an example of the Opposition's collective bargaining policy in action. In other words, it is a policy for industrial chaos. Honourable members should ask Sir Peter Abeles, Rupert Murdoch or any airline traveller in this nation what they think of the Opposition's industrial relations policy. They will tell of their disgust, anger and contempt concerning the Opposition's industrial relations policy. They will say that they want this dispute fixed as soon as possible. They want the pilots back at work. They want air travel in Australia back to normal.

Let us examine the role of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) in this whole debacle by the Opposition. On 25 August in an interview on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio program AM he said:
It's a classic case where you've got to go beyond the employer and employee fight and look after the national interest and the Government is correct.

He then goes on to say in this chamber and other places that he is not trying to score political points on this issue. But living in the fairyland that he does he now says that the airline pilots and the other unions would not make claims under the Opposition's industrial relations policy. What a fairy floss, feather-headed idea of an industrial relations policy. In his speech last Wednesday week in this chamber he, like the Federation, rejected the central wage fixing system. He said:
. . . we will establish the mechanism for voluntary agreements which employers and employees can discuss and settle by themselves.

The Opposition has no concern for wage fixing. It has no concern for control of industrial relations. It totally supports the Federation's policy in respect of this dispute. If this country were to concede or give in to any claim outside the wage fixing system, then all of Australia would suffer. It is a price that the Australian people cannot afford to pay. It is a price that this Government cannot afford to allow to be paid. The pilots must come to the negotiation table. As the Prime Minister indicated in Question Time today, there are procedures and practices now available for the pilots to pursue their claim within the ambit of the accord and to take account of productivity and other issues that they feel they should be rewarded for.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. The debate is concluded.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Kerin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to introduce new legislation to enable a levy to be collected on the sale of goat fibre. Funds from this levy are to be directed specifically into research for the betterment of the goat fibre industry. Associated with this Bill is the Goat Fibre Levy Collection Bill 1989 which allows the levy moneys to be collected and provides for their forwarding to the Australian Special Rural Research Fund. The funds will form a sub-account within the Australian Special Rural Research Fund which is dedicated to goat fibre research. The participation within the Australian Special Rural Research Fund ensures a Commonwealth contribution to goat fibre research while avoiding the expense of a separate statutory authority which would not be justified for an industry of this size.

The goat fibre industry comprises mohair, cashmere and, more recently, cashgore sectors. Those industries have made an increasing contribution to Australian export earnings, and export earnings are expected to approach $10m this year. In addition, there are the associated products of meat and hides from goat slaughter and the export of live goats.

These goat industries have been expanding and frequently complement the traditional pastoral industries of sheep and cattle production as they use resources which would not otherwise be fully utilised. This is particularly the case with some weeds such as thistles and blackberries which could require chemical control if goats were not used. A small expanding industry such as goat fibre production offers many promising opportunities for research in the area of animal production, fibre harvesting, marketing, economics and processing. However, the industry has limited capacity to organise and fund the required research. Despite this, the goat industry has made considerable effort to support research projects. This has been undertaken by a number of independent voluntary funds and some Commonwealth funds from the Australian Special Rural Research Fund. While the industry has identified research priorities, programs have rested on a precarious funding base with limited capacity to expand to meet the needs of an emerging industry. A more substantive, ongoing and coordinated research program is required if the needs of this industry are to be met. This is particularly the case as this industry is export oriented and so must meet the vagaries of international markets and compete with producers in a range of countries, some with a long history of fibre production and others with newly emerging industries.

In December 1988, with the support of the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow), I convened the national goat fibre workshop. This workshop comprised representatives of the various goat fibre industry groups who were supported by brokers, buyers, the fibre testing sector and research groups. At this workshop, the grower organisations recognised the benefits of a coordinated research program encompassing all goat fibre organisations. The degree of support for such a unified research effort was reflected in the subsequent request that I received from the four goat industry grower organisations. They requested that the Commonwealth enact legislation to collect a statutory levy of 1.5 per cent on the gross value of sales of goat fibre. This rate of expenditure on research will be amongst the highest of any Australian agricultural industry. In addition, the industry contribution will be substantially greater than the Commonwealth's maximum contribution of 0.5 per cent of the gross value of production in the industry. The willingness of the various sectors of this industry to work together and make a significant contribution to sponsoring change and improvement is reflected in the fact that they have suggested that an appropriate maximum rate for this research levy should be 5 per cent of the value of fibre sales.

The legislation provides for the initial levy rate of 1.5 per cent and the maximum rate of 5 per cent as requested by the industry. Provision is also made for any recommendations from the goat industry organisations to be taken into account prior to altering the operative rate of the levy. Initiating the levy on 1 January 1990 will allow the accumulation of some funds before the beginning of the 1990-91 financial year. This should allow research objectives to be assessed and individual research projects to be funded from the commencement of the 1990-91 financial year.

The goat fibre industry will benefit from an industry-wide research program which is administered by a professional research administration organisation, namely, the Australian Special Rural Research Council which was established by the Rural Industries Research Act 1985. In addition, the industry will have the benefit of a guaranteed Commonwealth contribution to the research effort. Initially the industry levy is expected to raise around $150,000 with an additional Commonwealth contribution of around $50,000. The Special Research Council will, therefore, be able to implement a goat fibre research program of around $200,000 annually. I believe this industry desires to make a substantial commitment to research and that the potential benefits for both the industry and Australia will justify the research effort. Because of this I believe the Commonwealth should provide the supportive mechanism as well as a financial commitment to this research. I commend the Bill to honourable members and present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Beale) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Kerin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to provide the machinery necessary for collecting the levy imposed by the Goat Fibre Levy Bill 1989. This Bill should be read as one with the Goat Fibre Levy Bill 1989 and is to also come into operation on 1 January 1990, the same day that the Levy Bill becomes operative. The Bill specifies the liability of purchasers and receivers under the scheme, outlines penalties for non-compliance and provides appropriate powers of enforcement. There are no financial implications other than those covered in the second reading speech for the Goat Fibre Levy Bill 1989. I commend the Bill to honourable members and present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Beale) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Staples, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr STAPLES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Housing and Aged Care)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Bill before the House amends the National Health Act to increase the maximum general patient contribution for prescribed drugs supplied under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS) from the present $11 to $12. The increase in the general patient contribution from $11 to $12 is estimated to achieve savings of $10m in 1989-90 and $17m in a full financial year. The Bill provides that the increase take effect from 1 October 1989.

Honourable members will note that the Government has continued to support those in need by maintaining both free pharmaceutical benefits for all pensioners and the concessional beneficiary rate of $2.50. In addition, the Government has retained the provision of free scrips for the chronically ill under the safety net provisions. Individuals or families who record 25 scrips in any calendar year receive all additional scrips free of charge.

The Bill further provides for the annual indexation of the general patient contribution in line with the March quarter `All Groups Consumer Price Index'. The annual adjustments will occur on 1 August to coincide with the issue of the PBS schedules. This amendment will thus link the general patient contribution rate to the rate of inflation to address the rapid growth in the costs of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme through increased prescribing of high cost drugs.

The increase in the maximum general patient contribution is one of a number of measures that the Government has taken to restrain the growth in expenditure of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme in the past 12 months. In 1988-89 this expenditure under the scheme increased by only 8.5 per cent over the previous year. The changes to patient payments announced in the Budget are consistent with the Government's desire to maintain the viability and effectiveness of the scheme with assistance targeted to the most needy. As other changes to the scheme announced in the Budget do not involve amendments to the National Health Act I shall not discuss them in this debate. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Beale) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: (Budget Debate)
Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lamb Mr A.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Hawke Government came to power in 1983 the unemployment rate was higher than 10 per cent and the government deficit was more than $9 billion. Now the unemployment rate is lower than 6 per cent and the Government is in surplus by more than $9 billion. Those facts speak for themselves. The Hawke Government has provided not only stable economic leadership but also a strong foundation for the future. Building that foundation has taken courage and it has not been easy. The Budget surplus, with a tight wages policy, will help contain interest rates and increase employment, making life easier for our families. When people come up with quick fixes and easy solutions, which is what the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) tried to convey during his $1m extravaganza cavalcade around the capital cities of the nation a month or so ago, I wonder about the economic management of our country and fear what would have become of our future if the Hawke Government had taken that easy way out.

SPEECH.PARA: Today, with sustained economic growth, high levels of employment and stable economic management, more people are sharing in the gains. I made the point that tax collections have increased, but this is because there are more people paying tax in a fairer way; the individual is paying less tax. The Minister at the table, the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support (Mr Robert Brown), who is an author of many books, treatises indeed, on economics, agrees with that point. When one sees the shift away from sole parent benefits, away from the unemployment queues and the dole and into jobs, 7,500 to 8,000 people a week, one thinks of the savings in expenditure and the increase in tax that come about to give the turnaround in the Budget that we have. All of these things add up to responsible, responsive government. The alternative easy way out peddled by the Opposition would have provided no long term benefits; in the end it would tear apart all that we have worked for.

The outstanding feature of this Budget is its impact on social justice. While the Opposition concentrates on whipping up antagonism against the needy, this Government gets on with dispensing social justice. While the Opposition loosely talks and carps about the small number of cheats that may or may not exist-it certainly cannot prove it-on our welfare programs and turning the public against the needy in a most cynical vote-catching exercise for the middle ground, the middle class, middle income vote, this Government has been getting people off supporting parent pensions and off unemployment benefits, and into the work force through training and employment programs. While the Opposition talks of cutting back $1 billion to $5 billion, if it is to take the advice of the Business Council of Australia, in essential programs of health, education and welfare, this Government has been about restructuring government spending. As government spending as a percentage of GDP in this country has dropped to the lowest for 16 years, the percentage of the Budget devoted to social justice programs has increased. We spell out our programs. We are still waiting for the Opposition to have the guts to get up and spell out where it is going to make the cuts. Is it to be the pensioners who will feel the knife? Is it the students? Is it those who have not been able to get a job through no fault of their own? I wish that Opposition members would stand up and be clear and honest with the people.

Nowhere are the Government and the Opposition more contrasted than in our concern for, and their rejection of, the aged, the sick, the young people and young families. We reject totally what the Opposition represents, what was represented by the Leader of the Opposition's tour-a poll-driven exercise. The strategy of this Budget is not geared to votes; it is geared to social justice. It is to restore equity, access, rights, fairness, to ordinary men and women of Australia. That is no idle boast. The strategy was put in place way back in May 1988, when with the Budget came a catalogue of the Government's achievements and then further social justice programs in the Budget of 1988, the April statement of this year, and now the centrepiece of this Budget. We have a detailed strategy, consistent with desirable end points. As I said, it contrasts with the Opposition's gaffes, contradictions, apologies, and what was noted for what it did not say rather than what it said in explanation of its policies. Labor, indeed, over its time in office, has been true to its traditional base, and that is an increasingly widening base. It is true to its objectives-and all this in what can only be described as tough economic times.

There is more to retirement than money; but income security is an important found- ation stone of retirement. The Government has given detailed consideration to pension, taxation and superannuation measures affecting senior citizens. I was proud to be a member of the task force of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on retirement incomes that went around the country and was part of the detailed government process of consulting extensively with older people and interested organisations. The result is Australia's first comprehensive national retirement incomes policy. The Government has already announced that the date of indexation for pensions will be brought forward by 12 weeks in three stages. It has also announced that the pension income test free area would become 100 per cent tax free by July 1990. Our commitment to pensioners includes more than $1 billion extra each financial year. The Hawke Government will meet and exceed for the first time that I can recall a pension entitlement in excess of 25 per cent of average weekly earnings.

We have also introduced the first social justice strategy for young people, a comprehensive $100m package of initiatives for disadvantaged young people. That will be over four years covering accommodation for the homeless, income support, labour market assistance, education, health and access to services. I say a thankyou there to a former university acquaintance of mine, Brian Burdekin, for bringing down the report which formed a substantial basis for the development of that social justice platform.

The honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale) was scathing about the number of training programs for the unemployed, especially youth. That shows that he misunderstands the scene completely. He wants one program to suit all people. He does not understand the many reasons for being unemployed. They vary from person to person. The needs of the short, the medium and the long term unemployed are different. The needs of unemployed women and youth and men can be different. Not once in his verbose flowery speech did he indicate any understanding or put forward an alternative. Of course, it is hard for Opposition members to put forward an alternative when they had such a disparaging and disgraceful record on unemployment when they were in government.

To sum up: If people want fairness and equity in Australia, they will support the Government's social justice programs. If they want to hurt people, they can support the Opposition in its denigration of needy people. Or as one person put it: `If you support the Liberal-National Party coalition, does that mean that you are an accomplice to their political crimes against the needy, the deserving and the vulnerable?'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In addressing the Appropriation Bill before the House today, I wish to concentrate my remarks on the science portfolio, for which I have responsibility as spokesman for the coalition. At the risk of stating the obvious, to the science community, the treatment of Australia's science and technology effort in the 1989 Budget held no surprises. All the news, so far as there had been any news in the first instance, was broken last May. The science and technology statement of 9 May, though initially well received, came to be viewed with increasing cynicism. Even the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) considered the statement to be `intellectually shallow', and he conceded that at best the statement represented just the first step in clawing our way back to something approaching a respectable scientific base in this country. Despite being touted as the $1 billion scientific statement, it soon became evident as the hype and rhetoric of the occasion gave way to close analysis instead, that the Government had managed to find only an extra $78m of new money a year for our science and technology community.

SPEECH.PARA: By way of contrast, I note with interest that Australia's sporting community won an extra $100m over four years in this year's Budget. This is $40m more than the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) called for in its Cabinet submission of last November as the base figure necessary to maintain, and only maintain, its level of research activity. Perhaps the increase in funding to sport was deserved, but I remain to be convinced. In any event, the increase in funding to sport is a telling comment on the balance of influence within the Cabinet.

At the broadest level, despite the small increases in science funding over the last year, Australia's research effort continues to compare very poorly with that of other nations of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD). No matter how the Government promotes its modest initiatives, no matter how much it seeks to deflect criticism of its approach to science and technology, the truth of the matter is that research in this country, on a comparative basis, is at an extremely low ebb, if not the lowest ebb in our history. Of the 19 OECD nations cited in the science and technology budget paper, Australia ranks sixteenth in regard to its research and development expenditure as a percentage of gross domestic product (GDP). Our other major trading partners spend twice as much as we do on research and development. Only Ireland, New Zealand and Spain spend less than the 1.2 per cent of GDP which is the percentage we allocated to research and development in 1987-88

Moreover, what ought to compound our concern is that this proportion is a decrease in the upward trends of previous years. In 1986-87, for example, we spent 1.25 per cent of GDP on research and development. In a corresponding period in the 1960s we spent 1.33 per cent of GDP. In short, we are sliding backwards. To make matters worse still-despite the well-publicised reluctance of our business sector to engage itself in research and development-the Government has provided nothing by way of compensatory support. That is to say, while in 1981-82 the Government provided funds equivalent to 0.75 per cent of GDP for research and development, it now provides only 0.72 per cent support.

All of this is against the backdrop of the collapse of all of our assumptions about the basis of our national prosperity. If there is a certain inconsistency evident in all of this, look at the treatment of CSIRO in this year's Budget. The CSIRO's appropriations for this financial year have been inflation adjusted; that is, its funding will keep pace with anticipated inflationary growth of around 6 to 7 per cent. Assuming the organisation achieves its predicted external earnings target, the CSIRO still has to deal with other factors which have cut deeply into its operational budget. Amongst these are past reductions in appropriations, budgeting shortfalls, salary increases and efficiency dividends, none of which CSIRO was compensated for in this Budget.

Despite this the Government's expectations for the CSIRO have increased in recent times. In its attempts to reconcile development policy with environmental considerations the Government is increasingly calling upon the resources of the CSIRO. Such was the case of the Wesley Vale pulp mill dispute. So it is too with concerns about climatic change, and so it will be increasingly in the future. More and more is expected-indeed, demanded-of CSIRO while fewer and fewer appropriations are made available to CSIRO in a climate of falling private sector investment in research and development.

I noted with interest in the recent CSIRO report entitled Pulp Mills: Modern Technology and Environmental Protection, that the research team concluded that if the Government wanted a rational assessment of the impact of pulp mill effluents-and one presumes that it does-then it would have to create the research base in Australia necessary to carry out the essential baseline studies. I cannot stress strongly enough that whilst CSIRO is being bled to death our core knowledge is being depleted at an alarming rate. We do not have the baseline knowledge necessary to make objective, informed, rational decisions in regard to the environment as we try to balance development against protection of the environment. The reality is that, by political necessity alone, the Government eventually will be drawn to reassess the role of CSIRO in Australia's environmental and developmental future.

Let me now seize on an example which, better than anything else, encapsulates the dilemma the Government has on its hands and which will affect very markedly industry on the one hand and the environment on the other. I refer to the disastrous reductions in the insect taxonomy section of the Division of Entomology within CSIRO. Honourable members will be interested to know that the Australian national insect collection was established in 1928 and since 1969 has been declared part of the National Estate under an Act of Parliament. It is curated by scientists in the taxonomy section of the Division of Entomology. The collection contains over eight million specimens. It is the largest collection of Australian insects in the world.

Insects are the most dominant form of terrestrial life in Australia. There are about 200,000 species. By contrast, there are only 2,000 species of higher land animals and birds in Australia and 20,000 species of native plants. That gives honourable members some idea of the predominance of insects.

By way of a broader contrast still, insects outnumber humans by a ratio of two million to one. There are 10 million different insect species. Many of these are still unknown in terms of their classification to taxonomists. Part of the task of the Division of Entomology is to develop an understanding of the interactions of these insects with animals and plants, a task critical to the management of Australia's environment. If we do not understand the ecosystem and the effect man's ecosystem has on it, then we cannot make rational decisions about protection of the environment.

The insect collection provides the resource, the data base, for environmental research. It has been at the basis of work done on biological pest and weed control programs. The results of this research have been significant in reducing our dependence on pesticides and other chemicals. The insect collection has also contributed to genetic research, animal behaviour, ecological studies and other areas of national interest. Specifically we need to know how to use and control insects, particularly in agriculture. Many agricultural pests and weeds are controlled by insects acting as biological control agents. In this application too, the expertise needed to identify species and sub-species-for example, the screw-worm fly in cattle and sheep-is vital for the survival of a $300m livestock industry. Even more importantly, the insect taxonomists at CSIRO play a critical role in identifying insects and worms brought into this country on foreign transports which might prove a threat to our agricultural industry. Recently on a Middle East ship they identified a particular type of fly worm which could have devastated our sheep and cattle export industry. In this sense the insect collection really possesses an economic value to our nation.

The problem is that, in the very substantial reduction of funding for CSIRO, programs that cannot be justified on a short term economic return basis are being jettisoned. In regard to environmental research it is not easy-in some cases it is impossible-to quantify the economic return for baseline research. But the insect collection can be justified, leaving aside the environmental considerations, because of its economic value to the nation. Without this knowledge our livestock industry would be rendered extremely vulnerable.

The study of insect life-insect biodiversity, as it is referred to-in a particular habitat can provide indicators of the environ-mental health of a particular area. Changesor decreases in biodiversity-in numbers and types of beetles, moths and insects-signal environmental problems. Given this, a knowledge of biodiversity can provide ready signals of the state of a particular habitat. It does it so much better and far quicker than the study of large animals. Insects have short life cycles of up to 10 days and hence can provide very accurate indicators of sudden environmental changes. A study of changes in ant numbers can provide very accessible and reliable data as to the effect of mining waste disposal.

One of the areas in which a study of insect biodiversity has been important in establishing baseline research has been in Kakadu National Park. That is, insect taxonomy expertise is essential if we are to develop a database for baseline environmental conditions which will then enable us to make rational decisions about courses of action. No longer should we need to make these sorts of decisions on political or emotive grounds. For example, insect taxonomy, or biodiversity studies, can tell us about the health of rainforests, whether they ought to be preserved, and what areas can be safely harvested. It can tell us about the state or condition of our crops.

I have recently had the pleasure of a long discussion with Professor Ed Wilson, Professor of Biology at Harvard, Pulitzer Prize winner and special adviser to the Bush Administration on the environment, on the issue of insect biodiversity. He tells me that the issue ranks fourth after toxic waste, climate change and ozone depletion as the public's main environmental concern. The Congress is soon to legislate on this very issue, providing for an institute to focus research on biodiversity. In the United States, private research and charitable funds such as the McArthur Foundation and the Pew Charitable Trust have invested millions of dollars in developing America's biodiversity research effort.

In this country the business of serious-minded environmental and agricultural research is lost on the Government. We are going in the opposite direction to the United States. Unfortunately, the capacity of CSIRO to maintain its existing research effort-forget about adding to it or expanding it; we are talking about maintaining the present research effort-has been totally jeopardised by the failure of the insect group to give evidence of immediate financial returns. Because the taxonomy group draws heavily upon appropriation funding from the public purse-funding directly from the Government-it is vulnerable to closure. External funding for the group might well cater for field trips for the officers, but it cannot, by the nature of the group's activities, directly support its continued operations. Accordingly, the standing of the taxonomy section within the Institute of Biological Resources is jeopardised. Because it cannot pay its way in an immediate sense or attract external funding to the extent demanded by the Government, the staff who administer and curate the Australian National Insect Collection are being squeezed out.

The expertise in two critical areas of environmental and agricultural research is being lost forever. The development of biological control programs is reliant upon the expertise of taxonomists. So, too, is the future of rationally based environmental research. It is with much regret that I advise the House that three of the taxonomists in the Division of Entomology are to go-that is, three out of a group of 12 research and experimental scientists. One is a research scientist, a specialist in ants, given to building baseline studies essential to environmental research and providing important quarantine advice. Another, again a research scientist, is a specialist in an area concerned with identifying parasites capable of controlling aphids, particularly those such as the Russian wheat aphids. The third is an experimental scientist who has expertise in the control of plague locusts and grasshoppers. They are all critical to the body of research expertise which underpins our environmental research core capacity as well as the health of our agricultural industries.

How many times do I have to impress upon this House the twin disasters that will affect the future of this country: on the one hand, the environment, and on the other the agricultural industries. There is no equivalent expertise in this country, if not the world, to the insect taxonomy group within CSIRO. If those people go, and they have been so informed, their experience is irreplaceable. This will be only the beginning. Owing to reductions in Government support for CSIRO, the institute funding the taxonomy group has been forced to cut its funding still further. More research projects are to be terminated. As a result, another two to three positions will be lost. In short, the Government intends to cut savagely by 50 per cent our taxonomy expertise within the CSIRO.

The driving force behind this is not a rational assessment of the worth of a particular research project. The driving force is the Government's reluctance to commit appropriate funds to research. I am sick to my back teeth of mealy-mouthed members of the Government coming into this chamber, wearing their concern about the environment on their sleeves, but when baseline research is disintegrating in front of them they remain silent; they remain mute. There is no excuse for any member of the Government-those who beat a well worn path up to Kakadu and pronounce their concern about the environment and pontificate back in their electorates-to allow CSIRO to fall apart in this way. If we lose the invaluable insect collection in this country we will pay dearly for it in terms of the environment. As for agricultural research, that too is at risk. We will lose the only experts in Australia able to identify the very difficult pests coming into this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Put a figure on it.

—We have a $300m livestock industry at risk now. Let us hear from the Government. Let us see whether there is anybody there who really will take up, with genuineness, the problems that are afflicting CSIRO, with particular concentration on the insect taxonomy group. Australia will be the loser from this short sighted administration of Government funding. Quite frankly, the collapse of our own indigenous insect biodiversity research capacity will haunt us, both environmentally and economically, for many decades to come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lavarch Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The 1989 Budget provides grants to Queensland of nearly $4.5 billion. As specified in Budget Paper No. 4, Queensland will receive in the 1989-90 financial year some $2.4 billion in general revenue assistance, $1.5 billion in specific purpose grants, and well over half a billion dollars in both general and specific capital grants. This is a huge amount of money to be paid to the State and one would think that normally it would be well spent and applied to essential services such as education and health for the benefit of the people of Queensland. However, I am afraid it is money which the Queensland Government is incapable of administering in accordance with any basic standards of accountability and honesty.

SPEECH.PARA: The actions of the Ahern Government, its Ministers and its instrumentalities can lead only to the conclusion that the Commonwealth should play a larger role in imposing conditions on the grants it makes to Queensland. The Commonwealth, of course, does have power to make specific purpose grants. The grants are tied to those purposes and conditions can be placed upon the nature of those grants. Normally untied grants are just that. That is, they are made to the State and the State can decide within its own budgetary priorities where the money should be spent. Unfortunately, Queensland, through maladministration, corruption and the bad practices identified in the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct, has placed itself in a situation where it is not worthy of the implicit trust which should follow the making of such a large financial contribution.

I believe that the Commonwealth Department of Finance should investigate whether Commonwealth grants to Queensland have been misused and applied for political patronage of the National Party, its donors, its supporters and its members. Evidence of maladministration and misuse of funds, including Commonwealth funds, is overwhelming, as is evidence of Premier Ahern's shallow commitment to tackling the issues of accountability and cleaning up the entrenched rorts which are characteristic of the Queensland National Party.

The clearest recent examples of the misuse of Government funds relate to the actions of the Queensland Industry Development Corporation, the QIDC. This body was established as a development financier, with lending emphasis placed on those projects which offered increased growth and employment. Indeed, there has been employment and growth-employment of National Party cronies, who have been given jobs with the QIDC, and there has been growth in the asset bases of other National Party cronies by way of loans through the QIDC. In terms of general employment growth or strengthening of the Queensland economy through the activities of this financier, I am afraid the evidence is far less clear. Of course, it has proven simply to be a vehicle to give the National Party support in its electoral areas and also to launder funds, if you like, through government means, into the pockets of its friends.

One may think that these were practices of the Bjelke-Petersen Government and that the new Ahern Government would be going down a different path. Unfortunately, quite the contrary is true. Under the Ahern National Party Government the practices of political patronage have become more entrenched rather than removed. For instance, one has only to look at the governing board of the QIDC. The Chairman of the board is Mr James Brennan. Mr Brennan came to the board with no great reputation as a financier or banker, unlike the person he replaced on the board.
