Mr Brennan's apparent qualification is that he is the Darling Downs Zone Vice-President of the National Party. The gentleman he replaced was Graham Tucker. Mr Tucker was forced to leave the position as Chairman of the QIDC because of pressure applied by the Queensland Finance Minister and the Queensland Government. When pressed on the reasons for his removal, it was explained that he was unsuitable for the job. However, it is interesting that now it has been revealed that only a few days prior to his forced resignation, the board at the time passed a resolution of confidence in Mr Tucker as Chairman.

Other members of the board include Mr Donald McDonald, a senior vice-president of the State National Party, and Mr Bill Roberts, a Barambah electorate councillor of the National Party, and also a director of Keldeal Pty Ltd, the company which provided the corporate veil for the funding of the abortive `Joh for PM' push. These are the gentlemen who are the senior members of the board of the QIDC.

I do not suppose it is any wonder, with these gentlemen running the show, that the funds of the QIDC have been grievously misused. Some examples of this that have been placed before the Queensland Public Accounts Committee, before that body's inquiry into the QIDC was muzzled by the Queensland Government, include the well-documented and well-known examples of misuse of disaster relief funding which have been raised in this House on many occasions by the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice); in particular, the very poor practice, in fact malpractice, of the State Primary Industries Minister, Neville Harper.

Many examples are available of the misuse of these drought funds. For example, one property which received drought funds, ironically enough, exhibited the champion fatted cow at the Townsville show. That is how badly dealt with that property was by drought! Other examples concerned the extension of a sugar cane quota on a farm through disaster relief funding, the purchase of extra dairy quotas and the extension of a farm-again, using funds which supposedly go to primary producers who have been hit, and hit hard, by natural disaster. Some examples are already the subject of a Commonwealth Department of Finance investigation. There are plenty more examples which the Commonwealth could investigate before extending funds to Queensland.

Another example concerns a $340,000 loan to a friend and supporter of Premier aspirant Russell Cooper. This money did not relate to any growth or employment creating scheme, which was the charter of the QIDC; this money was to help out the person with his divorce settlement. There was the curious example of extra pay and conditions being granted to one John Muntz, an employee of QIDC, after intervention by Geoff Muntz. Of course, Geoff Muntz is the Queensland Minister for the environment.

Apart from these clear examples of patronage and cronyism, the QIDC is in a poor state financially. It is heavily engaged in the practice of borrowing short and lending long. This is the same sort of practice which led to the downfall of the ill-fated Rothwells Bank in Western Australia. Last year the Queensland Government was obliged to inject $18m of extra capital into the QIDC from general Treasury funds. These funds were largely supplied by general Commonwealth assistance to Queensland.

Faced with this overwhelming evidence of malpractice within the QIDC-malpractice which was very clearly brought to people's attention through some limited inquiries by the new Queensland Public Accounts Committee-what was the response of Premier Ahern? Was it to go down the path of accountability and to be the new broom? Far from it. The Public Accounts Committee in Queensland was prevented from conducting further investigations into the QIDC. A majority vote of its members-all the National Party members-led to the inquiry being quashed. This was opposed by the Liberal and Labor Party members of that Committee.

There are other grounds why the Commonwealth should seriously consider imposing more conditions on the payment of grants to Queensland. One of those is the gradual, but nonetheless seemingly inevitable, watering down of the new accountability checks and balances recommended by corruption commissioner, Tony Fitzgerald. As a principal reform of the way in which government should be run in Queensland, Mr Fitzgerald recommended the formation of the Electoral and Administrative Review Commission, known as EARC. The legislation creating this Commission was drafted under the direct supervision of Mr Fitzgerald and he also agreed to play a limited consultative role in the implementation of this new Commission.

The Queensland Government's response to this recommendation was not to embrace it or adopt it; through a campaign of misinformation about the Commission's true powers, and then through a simple rejection of the accountability process, the Queensland Government, under Premier Ahern, has walked away from this administrative watchdog. Mr Fitzgerald gave his opinion of the Queensland National Party's commitment to accountability when he resigned from his position when the Queensland Premier announced on 9 August that the powers of the EARC would not be accepted.

Ironically, yesterday's leadership spill in the National Party was not brought about because people were concerned at the watering down of the Fitzgerald process or the accountability process; it was brought about by a dispute over daylight saving. What did the two aspirants to the premiership have to say about this process? They were not interested in accountability. Indeed, probably even more worrying was the fact that Premier Ahern sniped at his two opponents by saying that they were opposing his administrative reform package. So the people who were opposing Mr Ahern's weakened and watered down reform package were those who were challenging him. They were not challenging him because they wanted a strong package; they wanted a weaker package. It is absolutely amazing that this Government is still desperately trying to cling to power. I do not suppose that is particularly surprising when one realises that the aspirant for Premier, Mr Russell Cooper, was quite extraordinarily involved in the QIDC to obtain a divorce settlement loan for his friend and supporter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nothing will save them.

—Nothing will save them, as the honourable member states. Against this background I pose the question: Can the Commonwealth Government keep pouring money into Queensland when it is squandered and misapplied? Certainly Commonwealth untied grants are not applied adequately to the essential functions of a State government, such as education and health, as Queensland consistently spends less on these services than the national average and is, quite often, the poorest spending of all the Australian States. The record of the Queensland Government in the field of administering and applying Commonwealth grants has been appalling.
—It will be defeated at the next election.

—As the honourable member suggests, that Government will shortly be defeated at the next election when a Labor government will be elected. Fortunately the Fitzgerald process and the reforms which that gentleman has suggested will be implemented, but until that occurs I believe that the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) and the Commonwealth generally should be looking long and hard at grants made to Queensland to ensure that they are made under specific conditions of accountability so that the sorts of rorts which have been the history of the Queensland Government are not allowed to continue at Commonwealth taxpayer expense.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The previous speaker in this debate, the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Lavarch), concentrated all of the 15 minutes he took to make his speech on discussing issues of State politics relating to his home State of Queensland. It is a pity that people are elected to represent, as he is, marginal seats in the Federal Parliament and then devote the whole of their time to a discussion of State politics. All I can say is that eventually, after the next election, a career option for him may be to enter State politics where he can carry out his desired profession to the full because that is clearly his sole interest.

SPEECH.PARA: I have no comments to make on what is happening in State politics in Queensland. It is not my business or of any particular concern to me because I am from South Australia in the first place and, in the second place, as a member of the Commonwealth Parliament I am a little more interested in national affairs and Commonwealth affairs than the provincial affairs of the State of Queensland, even if members of the Australian Labor Party may not be. After all, at this time in our history in Australia, compared to comparable nations we face something of a national economic crisis. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) conceded that two or three years ago when he went on a Channel 9 program and said that we faced the economic equivalent of war.

So we were facing a war two or three years ago, but we are not doing anything to win that war. Gradually we are being pushed further and further back in the battle, and the Budget that was brought before the House a couple of weeks ago was just another concession in what the Prime Minister described as that war-another loss of ground. That document did none of the things that a government should be doing at a time of economic crisis. The Government should be taking steps to improve the competitiveness of Australian industries. As members who travel overseas will know only too well, at a time when other countries are addressing issues of competitiveness we are not. Even in so far as we take any steps in Australia to address the issue of competitiveness, we do so in a much slower, less imaginative and less productive way than is taking place, for example, in the United States, Canada, the European Community and other Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries. We are falling behind and the test of the Budget had to be whether it addressed these things.

As has been discussed already in this debate at some length, the Reserve Bank of Australia and Moody's Investors Service have simply underlined how the Budget and the Government's general economic strategy is failing to address the real issues that we face; indeed, the Government has an economic strategy which people ought to understand is little more than illogical nonsense. After all, we all know that Australia has a massive balance of payments deficit and a burgeoning foreign debt. The Government argues that that is caused by excessive demand. It says that we purchase or demand, if you like, 6 per cent more than the economy can actually supply. The Government argues that it will deal with this by crushing the life out of demand and then we will not demand so much. The only way to crush the life out of demand, which is the Government's strategy, is to reduce living standards. The Government is doing everything it can to reduce living standards through the device of forcing up interest rates.

The reality-Moody's is the latest organisation to point this out-is that that sort of economic strategy is voodoo economics. The quick fixes that were tried in Britain by the Wilson Government and in other parts of western Europe, such as by the Mitterrand Government when it first came to power, included devaluation and pushing up interest rates. Those tools have always failed because they have avoided addressing the fundamental issues of the economy. It is voodoo economics because if interest rates are forced up in order to reduce demand and to solve the balance of payments problems, one of the consequences is that the exchange rate is forced up, keeping the Australian dollar, in our case, at a higher rate than it would otherwise be if interest rates were not so high. If the Australian dollar is kept at a higher rate than it would otherwise be, one of the obvious consequences is an increase in the price of exports beyond what they might be and a reduction in the price of imports. If the price of exports is increased and the price of imports is reduced, then that encourages a blowing out of the balance of payments deficit. That is exactly why the high interest rate strategy that the Government had pursued since the New South Wales State election-it temporarily went through a low interest rate strategy in order to bolster the Labor Party's chances in that election-has failed. It has failed and the Budget Papers confess that it will continue to fail because they estimate that we will have a balance of payments deficit in this financial year of over $18 billion.

It is also a policy which, in a human sense, is fundamentally discriminatory because obviously the people who bear the heaviest burden of this policy are those who depend the most in their daily lives on borrowing money and who are therefore affected the most by high interest rates. Naturally small businesses which depend on borrowings rather than equity capital for their investment are severely handicapped by having to pay business rates of anything up to 24 per cent. But I guess the people we should all feel the most sorry for, and the people who ought to be brought back into this Parliament as a central point of debate, are home owners, in particular young home owners, who have seen home affordability decline as a result of rising interest rates for seven consecutive quarters. The last figures produced by the Housing Industry Association and the Commonwealth Bank of Australia for the June quarter of this year showed that home affordability in Australia had fallen to its lowest level since records were kept.

If home affordability is destroyed, we are creating two Australias: the Australia of those people who were able to purchase homes in previous generations-let me say in a party political sense under the Menzies and Fraser Governments-and those young Australians who have to purchase homes now and simply cannot afford to do so. Honourable members should remember that they are confronted with the worst home affordability figures since records have been kept. So we are creating two Australias-the one Australia of home owners and older people, and the other Australia of young families who are forced into the rental market or onto queues for public housing. The Government is pursuing on the one hand a policy of voodoo economics for younger people which will not work and, on the other hand, a policy which destroys one of the basic aspects of Australian society-the capacity of ordinary Australians to own their own home.

The Government's come-back in this Budget is to do something for home owners. I can see that it tosses a bone to home owners by providing some additional rent assistance-not a great deal, but some-and $15m of extra funds for the mortgage and rent relief scheme. But it does not provide anything for young people who go out to buy their first homes. In this Budget funding for the first home owners scheme is reduced by more than twice the amount of money that is provided for the mortgage and rent relief scheme-it is reduced by $32m-and funding for the first home owners scheme in nominal terms, let alone real terms, has declined every year since 1984, when the first home owners scheme was introduced.

I concede that, in the main, the first home owners scheme is a good, fairly well targeted scheme, although it could be better targeted. In so far as the Government wants to help low income people to purchase their own homes, I think that is a rational way of doing it. If the Government has chosen a good policy it is a shame that it has not carried on the promise the original policy gave for younger people buying their own homes but instead has taken more and more funding away from that scheme. As house prices have increased-of course, they have increased massively since the policy was first introduced-so interest rates have increased. Yet as interest rates and prices have increased, funding for the first home owners scheme has actually declined. Instead, the Government has transferred resources away from assisting young first home buyers at this very difficult time and into the public housing sector.

The Australian Labor Party is very proud of its commitment to public housing; it always has been. It has always been an article of faith in the Labor Party that it should get more and more Australians into public housing. One of the great boasts of the Labor Party is that this year X people are in public housing, whereas under the Liberals Y people were in public housing, and Y is less than X. That is the sort of game this Government likes to play because it thinks it might be popular with the electorate. Actually, it reflects one of the strands of socialism, if you like, that still run through the Labor Party: its commitment to get more and more of the Australian community into dependence on the Government and away from the ultimate independence of having their own property and their own homes.

There is no question that public housing is a necessary thing for certain categories of people. No government would abolish public housing and I am not arguing that it should be abolished. What I am saying is that this Government's emphasis in its housing policies and through all its Budgets since it came to power in 1983 has been on providing more resources for public housing and fewer resources to help young Australians get into their own homes. I think that is a terrible indictment of this Government. As I have said, in general, public housing makes people dependent on the state. Home ownership gives them independence. Public housing also means that people become immobile. For example, people in public housing in the town of Murray Bridge in my electorate cannot afford to move to Adelaide to take work. If they move to Adelaide they will be out of public housing and back onto the public housing waiting list. That just does not make sense.

The Government's housing policy, in placing emphasis on public housing, is also very discriminatory. It discriminates in favour of those who are lucky enough to get into public housing-if we could call it lucky enough-and against those people on low incomes who are on public housing waiting lists and who are forced to go into the private rental market. At the moment there are about 180,000 people on public housing waiting lists, and they are there partly because increasingly they cannot afford to buy their own homes, as they could in better economic times, and partly because, effectively, they get more financial assistance in public housing than they do in the private rental market. So the Government's policies actually provide an incentive for people to get out of the private rental market and into public housing. I think that sort of housing policy is wrong and needs to change fundamentally. After all, the highest incidence of housing related poverty is found not in public housing but amongst low income people in the private rental market-the people for whom this Government has done the least.

Housing policies need to change fundamentally, and I think we need to look at some radical changes to those housing policies to ensure that low income people are guaranteed a roof over their heads in a way that is not discriminatory. Let me mention one of the ways in which we could do that. Instead of providing funding directly for public housing, as is currently done, we should use that money to introduce a housing benefit which is paid directly to qualifying low income households. Those people who qualify to receive the housing benefit would then be able to use that money for one of three things. Firstly, they would be able to use it in the form of rent assistance to help them pay the cost of rent in the private rental market. Secondly, they would be able to use it to help purchase a home, to help meet mortgage repayments, although I am quick to confess that very few people would be able to afford to purchase their own home, and in particular to accumulate a deposit to purchase their own home, if they fell into a category where they were able to qualify for a housing benefit. But that could be done and, where it could be done, I think it would be a very practical use for the housing benefit. Thirdly, the individual would be able to use that funding to pay the public housing authority in his or her State to help meet the cost of the provision of public housing.

The net effect of this would not necessarily be a reduction in funding for public housing, if that were the choice that individuals who received the benefit actually made. On the other hand, if individuals overwhelmingly decided that they did not want to go into public housing but instead wanted to go into the private rental market-and I would submit that individuals would overwhelmingly make that choice-there would be a reduction in demand for public housing, a reduction therefore in the need for public housing, and obviously a reduction in funding for public housing. Ideally, I would like these people to choose whatever they wanted. I do not want to discriminate in favour of one form of tenure and against another form of tenure. I want individuals to be able to make those choices for themselves. By contrast, the Government's policies discriminate in favour of those lucky enough to be balloted into public housing and against people in the private rental market, who get an infinitesimal proportion of the assistance that those in public housing get. Because of the emphasis on high interest rates, the Government's policies discriminate, in a macro-economic sense, against young people who go out to purchase their own homes, to get into the home ownership market.

I know that the Labor Party's rhetoric is always the rhetoric of equality, equity, fairness and that sort of thing. Members of the Labor Party talk a lot about it, but I have just explained how their policies are basically unfair. If they are serious about equity they should provide equity in tenure between those who rent, those who purchase their own homes and those who go into public housing. That would also provide for much greater mobility of labour than is the case under current policies because people would still get the benefit if they were to move from, say, Adelaide to Newcastle or Wollongong, or where ever it may be. They would still get the benefit; they would still get assistance. That is not so easily done with public housing.

In conclusion, there is one other thing we could do to help young people get into home ownership, and that is to introduce a scheme which I spoke about in the earlier part of this year and which the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) christened the homesure scheme where we propose that those young people who go into superannuation funds would be able to cash in 75 per cent of the accrued superannuation benefits at the age of 25 and use that money as a deposit on their first home. Of course, there would have to be provision to ensure that they remained in the superannuation fund; they could not just take the money and sprint out of the fund.

I think this would have two very beneficial effects. Firstly, it would provide a deposit averaging in the vicinity of $16,000 for young people to help them purchase their own homes. That would be an enormous step forward. Secondly, it would provide an incentive for people under the age of 25 to enter superannuation schemes. Honourable members may not be aware that only 17 per cent of people under the age of 25 are currently in superannuation schemes. So with the homesure scheme, as we call it, there would be a very real incentive for what we might call the rational young person to go into superannuation, to remain in superannuation until he retired and, therefore, to make provision for his own retirement-something that both sides of the House support-and also to have the opportunity of purchasing his own home which might otherwise be denied him.

The Treasurer (Mr Keating)-indeed all members of the Parliament-may wonder how much a scheme like this would cost. I submit that such a scheme would cost nothing at all on top of the cost that already exists for superannuation concessions. So I think it is an imaginative scheme and a way that we can encourage home ownership in our society, which has always been one of the fundamental objectives of the Liberal and National parties-though certainly not of the Labor Party.

I am glad that the present Government, as has been the case with the Opposition, has resisted the political temptation of going down the path of providing quick fixes in the housing area; of doing things such as providing tax deductability for mortgages which would do nothing but massively inflate property prices around Australia at an enormous cost to the Commonwealth's Budget, and I think the net result would be just a substantial reduction in the Commonwealth's Budget deficit. It would certainly do nothing, ultimately, to make housing more affordable because prices would go up as a result of the increased demand provided through the tax deduction.

In conclusion, Mr Deputy Speaker, we need more imagination in the housing area, including more rational and less discriminatory policies. But so we do throughout the Budget. This is a Budget which is full of lost opportunities and which has turned its back on Australia's great problems. It will do nothing to help us become the economically powerful nation we really ought to be, given the resources that we have.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, at the outset I would ask you to pass on my congratulations to the Speaker and to the Deputy Speaker on their elevation to high office. It is always a great pleasure for me to follow the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) in this House. I always find it interesting when he starts speaking about the less privileged and so on. I always find it a little strange that someone in this chamber who comes from the most privileged of backgrounds has this close identification with those who talk about the less privileged. It is also interesting that he harked back to home ownership in the Menzies era. Rest assured that there are more young people today owning their own homes under the Hawke Government than there were in the Menzies era. He might be too young to remember the Menzies era but I remember it and I remember the people then who could not get into homes and the tragic situation of homelessness in that era.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that, and having been slightly critical of the honourable member, I must say that his idea about being able to draw on superannuation in the early part of one's life is one that does attract me. It is an argument that I have used. I would go even further, though, and say that under a national superannuation scheme everyone would be able to be part of a superannuation scheme that people could draw on. I always believe it is in those early years when people get married, maybe have a couple of children, maybe buy a car on hire purchase, are often on low wages, and are trying to get into a home, that it is much more difficult for them. Later on in life, when the family is off their hands, when their home is paid for and their salary is usually greater, they do not need it. I have great sympathy for the scheme that the honourable member put up. I think it is a good scheme and, as he said, it is an imaginative scheme and one that deserves some attention.

At the outset of his speech the honourable member criticised the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Lavarch), saying that he was just talking about State politics. I listened very carefully to the speech of the honourable member for Fisher and all he was doing was pointing out in his opinion the misappropriation of Federal funds that have gone to Queensland. That is something that I thought members of the Opposition would be very interested in. I am not saying whether they were misappropriated or not; I am just repeating what the honourable member for Fisher said. But perhaps it is something that, if the honourable member for Mayo feels so strongly about, he might be able to refer to the Opposition Waste Watch Committee. It seems to be looking into every other thing, so why not have it look at Commonwealth funds that have gone to Queensland over the last couple of years to see whether there has been any misappropriation there. It is certainly very quick to look at funds going to research in universities and other places like that; let it have a look at the funds going to Queensland and maybe we can have the benefit of the committee's collective wisdom on this matter.

Having listened to the many speeches in this House on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) it seems to me that members of the Opposition have exercised the luxury of opposition by criticising, but as usual they fail to tell us what they would do. They fail to tell us what they would cut. They tell us about how this Government has not funded appropriately various pet schemes that the Opposition has; but they never tell us what they would fund. The only thing we can do is guess. They have given us a few hints over the last couple of years of what they would cut. We have a hint that welfare would be cut; we have a hint that there might be a bit of a slash to pensions which, in their view, are too high. There has even been one hint that the telephone concessions for pensioners could well be cut. As I say, these are only hints that we have had from Opposition members. We on this side are waiting for their policies. We will watch with interest the relaunch of the famous 13 that did not gain enough publicity and we will have a look at those.

One of their policies of which we are aware, of course, is their industrial relations policy, and in the present pilots dispute we have a good example of how this would work. But it is not really these policies that we want to see. We have had a look at their industrial relations policy; we are seeing it working. It is their economic policies that we are really interested in, as indeed are the people of Australia. Until these economic policies are released I am afraid that our Opposition members must lack credibility, not only with us on this side but also with the Australian people.

Ever since I have been a member of this place my electorate office has kept a record of all the telephone calls that we receive in the days immediately following the release of each Budget regarding the measures announced. It gives me, as the local member, an idea of what people are concerned about, what issues need more explaining and, dare I suggest it, what issues we have wrong. In the days following this latest Budget, I did not receive one call concerning the Budget. That has led me to the conclusion that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) got it right. It was a Budget for all Australians and it was well received. I think he got it so right and it was basically so well received because it is a document that is fundamentally based on social justice. Representing, as I do, an electorate in New South Wales, I am well aware of how important social justice is. Since the election of the Liberal-National Party Government in New South Wales my area has seen an unprecedented attack on services-an unprecedented attack by the Liberal-National Party Government in New South Wales. Make no mistake about it, this Opposition wants to introduce Greinerism, which is the Australian version of Thatcherism, throughout Australia.

The 1989-90 Budget provides the most significant package of reforms for the aged introduced by any Federal government since the age pension system commenced some 80 years ago. A number of measures introduced in the Budget were in response to the issues pensioners raised with the Prime Minister's task force on retirement incomes. This Government not only listened to but also acted on their concerns. The youth package also could only have been, and indeed would only have been, introduced by a Labor government. I turn now to an area that is of particular interest to me and--

TALK.START.PARA: —Antarctica! Travel!

—In a way it is travel, as my colleague says. It is Antarctica. I was particularly pleased with the announcements contained in the Budget concerning Antarctica. At a time when more Australians are showing a concern for the future of Antarctica this Hawke Labor Government is supporting a range of innovative programs on that continent. In 1989-90 the Government is supporting Australia's largest ever Antarctic science program-a total of 135 projects.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) was critical about what the Government had not done in the science field. He may have a point when he is talking about insects. Nevertheless, he failed to mention the significant increase in the very exciting work in the science field that this Government is doing in Antarctica. Many of the projects involve international collaboration, including important studies on atmospheric, ecological and environmental issues. At a time when many people are concerned about the greenhouse effect, about one-quarter of the program focuses on research relating to the greenhouse effect, ozone layer depletion, the history of climatic change and future climatic trends. The continent is also a critical baseline laboratory for research into global environmental change. If we are going to understand changes to our weather patterns, much of the research will have to be carried out in Antarctica. Antarctica is the last clean place of any size that is left on earth. We each have a duty to ensure that it stays that way-a place for scientific research. We have managed to spoil so many areas. Surely there is one place left that we can leave in its pristine state.

During a trip to Antarctica earlier this year, I was made aware of the deplorable state of the meteorological stations at Davis and Mawson. I raised this matter in a speech in this House on 12 April this year and also discussed it with the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson. I was therefore delighted to read that new meteorological laboratories will be built at both Davis and Mawson. Scientific facilities at Davis Station will be the biggest beneficiary of $13m provided for the construction and fitout of four buildings in Antarctica. This will include construction of a general science laboratory and an upper atmospheric physics laboratory at Davis, as well as the meteorological balloon building and the fitout of new living quarters at Mawson. The Davis Station general science laboratory will be used for wildlife and fossil studies in the Vestfold Hills region and for atmospheric chemistry studies of greenhouse and other gases. The physics laboratory will have facilities for long term monitoring of the earth's lower and upper atmosphere, including studies and aerosol concentrations, ozone depletion, magnetic field variations and the ionosphere. The Mawson Station meteorological balloon building is to be built for the safe inflation and release of the balloons used to obtain weather data for forecasts and for research into climatic change and the impact of the greenhouse effect.

I must congratulate the Minister for agreeing to this proposal. In my own modest way I hope that the visits I had to the Minister's office and the discussions I had with him about the conditions under which the meteorological balloons have to be released at this station played a small part in obtaining the funding to rebuild these two very important meteorological laboratories. I also pay tribute to the workers who, over many years, have carried out their important duties in totally unsafe and dangerous conditions. It was only their dedication that enabled much important information and research to be carried out. I was also pleased with the announcement that there would be trials for an intercontinental Australia-Antarctica air link which will involve two Royal Australian Air Force Hercules flights from Hobart to an ice runway at Casey Station. In addition, an air transport system within Antarctica will also be tested using long range helicopters.

There has been some debate about the building of an airfield in the Australian claimed territory in Antarctica. I inspected one proposed site near Mawson which would have been prohibitively expensive to develop and also damaging to the environment. The proposal for an ice runway at Casey and an expanded air transport system is a possible solution to a difficult problem. Air transport will enable more scientists to work in Antarctica over the summer months. It would also provide for quicker deployment to field sites and allow the introduction of new science programs which need air support.

The maiden voyage of Australia's new research and supply ship, Aurora Australis, will take place in 1990. This voyage will be a dedicated marine science cruise with a diverse range of oceanographic and marine biology projects to be conducted aboard. I am delighted that Australia will finally have its own Antarctic ship. The Aurora Australis will be equipped for research. The continent of Antarctica itself is largely a frozen wasteland. But the waters surrounding it are the richest reservoir of life on the planet and support the familiar large animals of the far southern seas-the penguins, gulls, seals, dolphins and whales. If we damage this region badly we will tear an enormous hole in the fabric of the planetary ecology and cause damage elsewhere. I was delighted that earlier this year the Government refused to sign the Antarctic Mining Convention. As would be obvious from my comments, I support the Government's efforts to have Antarctica declared a world wilderness park-an area reserved for scientific research. I hope that other countries will support Australia's efforts in this field.

The Antarctic region is valuable because of its ecological role and as a mine of information useful to science. In addition, we have a responsibility to try to protect and preserve in as pristine a state as possible the few areas on earth not spoiled by man. In this regard it is excellent news that this environmentally conscious Government will continue the clean-up process around the Australian bases. Not only is the present waste being returned but waste left from previous years, when perhaps Australians were not so environmentally conscious, is also being returned. Australia's record in regard to the environment in Antarctica, especially around our bases, is excellent.

One aspect that does worry me is the prospect of tourism in Antarctica. I am of the firm view that any tourism would need to be ship based. Opening up the continent for tourists will make protection of the environment that much more difficult. A continual infusion of sightseers will only make accidents such as the Argentinean oil spill earlier this year much more likely. The Argentinean ship that went aground and spilled diesel fuel was a supply ship for the Argentinean scientific station on the continent. But it also carried about 100 tourists. Such ships should, I believe, limit themselves to their essential functions. It is not only in Antarctica that this Government has a proud record. The 64 per cent increase for funding for the environment is an indication of the high priority the Hawke Government is putting into the environment.

In conclusion, I would like to say that I strongly support the comments about sport made by my colleague the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) in this chamber last night. He made his usual excellent contribution and spoke from the knowledge that he has gained after many years of association with the sporting industry, in which he has a very distinguished background.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of your proteges.
—As the honourable member for Grey says, he is one of my proteges. I take slight exception-and he knows I do-to one small comment he made. In his speech he said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is very interesting that in this country people are quite willing to support struggling artists or people involved in cultural pursuits.

I know that the Minister at the table, the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories (Mr Holding), would agree with me when I say that my friends in the theatre and those involved in other cultural pursuits are unaware of any great sums of money being thrown their way. Having said that, I support very much the comments made by my colleague, the honourable member for Macarthur. I congratulate the Government and the Minister for increasing funding for sport.

There has been the usual wide-ranging debate on this Appropriation Bill. On this side we are delighted to speak on the Bill and to be part of the Government that introduced it. It will go down as one of the greatest and most responsible Budgets ever introduced into this Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods Dr R. L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address the 1988-89 Budget. I have to start off by saying how saddened I am by this Budget because, unfortunately, it does nothing to address our overriding problems-our lack of international competitiveness and our poor productivity rates. These problems have contributed to an overseas debt of $108 billion, as we heard in the last 48 hours. This rise of some 400 per cent in six years puts us on a par with countries such as Brazil and Mexico.

SPEECH.PARA: As other members have pointed out, this is clearly an election Budget. But it is not an election Budget in the old fashioned sense of the word. It is not about blatant handouts to all and sundry. It is about targeting benefits to particular problem groups-the aged, sports clubs, et cetera. Most importantly, it is about not upsetting any major constituencies. As the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) said, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) got it right because he did not upset anybody. He did not do anything positive and, as the honourable member said, he did not target any groups for any major accounts. That is why the honourable member did not get any phone calls, apart from the fact that he is probably never in his office to get them.

The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer have attempted to sell this Budget as an economically responsible Budget when the truth is quite clearly exactly the opposite. They claim a tight fiscal policy, responsible wages control and encouragement to save, but of course the realities are quite different. Fiscal policy has been eased, not tightened. For example, personal taxes have been cut by $5 billion. There is an odd accounting process in the Budget. For instance, a couple of items of revenue from last year have been delayed and some items of revenue from next year have been brought forward. When one adds those up and does the balance figures one finds that this year's much-vaunted surplus is actually lower than last year's. The Forward Estimates also show expected real growth in outlays over the next two years. There is no increase in planned public savings. If one excludes asset sales and the cuts in State grants, one finds that Commonwealth outlays increased by almost one per cent. So much for Labor Government restraints on spending. The only restraints are on the grants to the States, not on its own spending. Quite clearly, the public sector is expanding rather than contracting.

At the same time, wages policy has been eased. Wages policy should allow for flexibility but prevent abuse by the Government, employers, employees and their employee organisations with, if necessary-as the Opposition has often pointed out-appropriate sanctions introduced at the right time. Our current earnings growth is already moving ahead of the agreed rate under the Government-Australian Council of Trade Unions deal which called for 6.5 per cent earnings growth in 1989-90, which would cause no problems if only it were tied to productivity increases, but of course it is not. The truth is that wages and fiscal policy have both expanded at a time of disastrous economic news. In the last day or two our overseas debt has skyrocketed and our inflation rate of 7 to 8 per cent is higher than that of almost all of our competitors. Moody's Investors Service Inc. downgraded our credit rating and we are now on the bottom of the rung of industrial nations. Why is that? The brief answer is that the decisions made in the Budget are not economic decisions but political ones. As a result monetary policy will continue to be the only lever which the Government can pull to control the economy. Therefore, high interest rates will continue for the foreseeable future and, in turn, our cost of living will be higher, inflation will increase and there will be corporate failures-in both large and small companies-bankruptcies and the possibility of a recession at the end of the financial year-all at a time of a world boom. The Reserve Bank of Australia, in its reserved way, summed up the situation with the kindest possible view of Australia's economic future under the Hawke Government. It stated:
Retention of the present stance of policy should produce a more significant restraint for spending as 1989-90 progresses.
Whether this will also be sufficient to lay the groundwork for winding down the current account deficit is uncertain: There are risks that it may not.
These risks will be much greater if there is a substantial slowing of world growth and a decline in commodity prices.

In other words, even at a boom time for most world economies and with record commodity prices in most areas, the Labor Government still made a mess of it. What should be done? There is no short term solution. In summary, the solution would be to increase productivity and competitiveness and increase our export markets so that we can trade our way out of the mess. How can we do that? A whole range of measures need to be introduced which the Budget does not address. We need a tax system which is not penal, which does not deter people from working harder or doing overtime. We must bear in mind that the Hawke Government is the heaviest taxing government ever in peacetime. We need a flatter tax system. We need to get rid of excess bracket creep. We must remove disincentives to save and invest and we must remove the bias against the establishment of industries in Australia. We must equate more closely top corporate and personal tax levels and we need to abolish the capital gains tax. We need to remove the bias against savings and we need to reform and rationalise the indirect taxation system which has increased so much in the last few years under the Hawke Government. We need to be able to deregulate businesses. The shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), suggested that in business regulations there should be sunset clauses. Basically, that would work by all business regulations becoming non-functional at a certain time unless it could be shown clearly that there was a need for them as opposed to what happens at present, which is, unless specific action is taken the regulations apply forever.

We need to remove the dead hand of government. We need to prevent government spending from increasing. We need to remove regulation and encourage enterprise and freedom. That means, at least in part, privatisation to give incentive and reward for hard work, enterprise and efficiency. Part of that would involve decentralising the wages determination system so that we can achieve flexibility and offer reward for ability and productivity. We need to give incentive by introducing profit sharing schemes and so on whereby an employee benefits if his company does well partly as a result of his own labours. Schemes such as the employee's share ownership scheme, where a company belongs in part to its employees, have worked well in both Australian and overseas companies where they have been introduced.

We also need to reform our infrastructure. Goodness knows why it costs twice as much to transport a chest from Melbourne to Burnie in Tasmania as it does to transport one from the United Kingdom to Melbourne, as somebody trying to do that only a month or two ago pointed out to me. Surely there can be no logical explanation for that sort of cost. However competitive our products are when they start, when they are made, when they are dug out of the ground or grown, once transport costs are added they cannot compete. I do not need to list the problems; there are a number of them-for example, shipping, bulk storage, the waterfront and other transport methods. All those problems must be resolved. Outdated and restrictive work practices, which in most cases are the cause of problems, must be reformed. The Government has not had the guts to do that.

We need to be able to introduce competition, incentive and reward for effort in those industries and transport areas as well as in ordinary enterprises and business. Again, we have to reduce the red tape and regulations for those industries. We have to reintroduce a sense of competitiveness into our country. We have a sense of competitiveness in so many areas. We can thrash the hide off the poms at cricket, we can win golf tournaments all over the world and occasionally we can even win an Olympic medal, although not as often as we might like. That sense of competitiveness is there in those spheres. Our reputation in times of war is unsurpassed. However, when it comes to business there is no competitive spirit which is not being drowned or smothered by the dead hand of government. We must relieve our workers and management from this dead hand of government to allow them to show the initiative which we all know they are capable of.

I wish to focus on a couple of specific issues which, unfortunately, have not been addressed in the Budget but I believe they are an important part of the decision-making process. A number of Italian taxpayers and pensioners face a number of problems. I raised this issue in the House in May this year but the Treasurer has not even had the courtesy to reply, let alone to resolve the problems facing a number of people who are in great difficulties. The first concerns the invalid pension received by former residents of Italy which is taxed by the Hawke Labor Government. The invalid pension received by Australians from the Australian Government is not taxed, quite appropriately. Surely an invalid pensioner is an invalid pensioner no matter what his or her background is, unless the Government is saying that Italian invalid pensioners are not really invalids, that only dinky-di Aussies can be trusted to be genuine invalid pensioners, or that the Italians cannot be trusted to be genuine invalids. If that is the case it is a disgraceful slur on the Italian community. Yet it seems to be the only explanation.

The criteria for invalidity in the two countries are basically the same. If there is any doubt in the Government's mind about the genuineness of those Italian pensioners, I am sure that they would be very happy to undergo an appropriate assessment of their medical problems. To make matters worse, the Italian invalid pensioners-unlike their equivalents in Australia-have contributed to a special fund to finance their pensions over a minimum period of five years and often much longer than that. Clearly, there is no significant difference between Australian and former Italian residents in terms of the invalid pension, except of course for their country of origin. I am disappointed that this matter has not been resolved in the Budget. Therefore, I call upon the Government to resolve it now.

There is yet another problem facing the Italian community which has not been resolved in the Budget and which clearly should have been. It concerns the double taxation of Italian pensioners. They are taxed by both the Australian and Italian governments. Under the bilateral agreement between Italy and Australia, as from 1 July 1987, which is over two years ago, tax should have been paid to the Australian Government only. However, largely because of differences in the timing of the financial year endings some problems have arisen. They could have been resolved easily, but they have not. The Australian Government has stated that each Italian pensioner must obtain from the Instituto Nazionale della Previdenza Sociole (INPS), which controls Italian pensions, the amount identified as being derived from the pensioner's own contribution to his or her pension. Such information is available, but apparently the Australian Taxation Commissioner, at the behest of the Treasurer, has not accepted the data as being genuine.

I appreciate that part of the problem has been obtaining detailed information from the INPS, but clearly, red tape and bureaucracy are taking over here and the people who are suffering are the poor pensioners of Italian origin. It is clear to me that the available information from INPS regarding the contributory part of the Italian pension should be accepted as the best available data on the contributory part of the pension, and allowances in terms of the taxation system should be made on this basis. The amounts involved are, broadly speaking, accurate, as described in these letters from INPS, and such a ruling would resolve a major problem, without resulting in any major loss of revenue for the Government. It would remove a problem which, I have to say, is hanging over the heads of a large number of Italian pensioners like a sword of Damocles.

In a similar situation, the Department of Social Security faced a problem in obtaining data about the level of Australian age pensions which they were entitled to, which in turn was also dependent upon the contributory part of the Italian pension. The Department of Social Security accepted the letters which I have referred to and said that these were reasonable data and accordingly adjusted the age pensions, and this problem, I am pleased to say, seems now to have been resolved. If, on the one hand, the Department of Social Security can accept the data, why cannot the Taxation Office accept the data? I think that the Treasurer should address this matter as a matter of urgency. The numbers of people involved are small, but the problem, as far as they are concerned, is very, very large.

There is one other specific issue I wish to address which was not, unfortunately, covered in the funding which was made available in this Budget. I refer to the funding for the acquired immune deficiency syndrome and the fact that there is no funding in the Budget for haemophiliacs who have caught AIDS. Let me just outline the background of this problem. The haemophiliacs, people with so-called bleeding disease, have in many cases, through no fault of their own, caught AIDS. The bleeders, as they are often called, suffer from the deficiency of what is called factor 8 or factor 9 in their blood. The treatment for the disease is that they should receive intermittent transfusions of factor 8 or 9, which is in turn taken from hundreds, if not thousands, of donors. It is extracted from each blood donation which is given to the blood banks. The frequency with which they receive these transfusions varies from every other day to very, very occasionally. As a result of those transfusions, at the time when the precautions in terms of AIDS donors giving blood were not as good as they are now, approximately 350 out of the 1,200 haemophiliacs in Australia have now contracted HIV infection.

It is a very difficult problem, of course. Haemophiliacs have a different case from many other patients with AIDS who contracted their AIDS from blood transfusion in as much as they had a pre-existing disease which meant, being haemophiliacs, that they really were in most cases unable to get a disability insurance or a life insurance. They had in many cases, because of their reduced earning capacity, no ability to provide for their own retirement or ill health from their own financial resources. On top of that, of course, there is the emotional and extra emotional and extra physical burden of having two major diseases, on top of the physical, social and psychological problems which all patients with AIDS or HIV infections suffer from.

I believe, therefore, that in view of the fact that there is an even greater burden on these patients of having two major diseases and that they are in fact worse off initially, because of their haemophilia before they caught AIDS, there is a special case for caring for these patients and making sure their lifestyles are as normal as it is possible for them to be. There are indeed a number of options, and many of these have been canvassed with the Department of Health. One was for compensation for each individual patient, but after some discussion it was realised that there may be some difficulties with this and the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) encouraged the Haemophilia Society of Australia to seek an alternative method, which was to arrange for a one-off payment from the Government as a seeding grant to a trust fund administered by independent trustees, which would then undertake to look after patients with haemophilia and AIDS for the rest of their lives. The seeding grant would have generated enough income to cover the needs of these patients. The advantages of this way of offering compensation was, of course, that there was no precedent set and that it was self-limiting, because indeed the problem itself is self-limiting. No new haemophiliacs are now catching AIDS because of the precautions now being undertaken in the blood banks.

The Haemophilia Society went to a lot of trouble and, indeed, a lot of expense in preparing submissions for the Department of Community Services and Health, only in the end to be told that there was no way it was going to receive a grant. In both the Budget and the AIDS paper there is no mention of the question of a grant being given, although in the United Kingdom a similar situation has arisen and indeed the UK Government has given a grant there which is a very adequate grant. I understand that what happened in fact was that, in spite of the support of the Minister for Health for the project, the haemophiliacs' position was rolled by the financial brains of this Government. I understand that Senator Peter Walsh actually won the day as opposed to the more caring members of our society, and the more caring members, in particular in this case, of the Cabinet.

The Minister for Community Services and Health, Dr Blewett, answered a question on this matter a week or so ago and he referred to the fact that haemophiliacs could address themselves to and use the `normal welfare arrangements'. But, of course, this is not a normal welfare problem. These people have their lives destroyed, both metaphorically and in reality. There is no other comparable scheme, according to the Minister, which would be used for people who have contracted diseases from their medical treatment. But of course, there is no other comparable situation; it is a unique situation. It would not set a precedent. He also suggested they might claim for negligence in the courts. There are problems with that. Firstly, there is the difficulty of proving negligence. Secondly, there is the fact, of course, that they are then about to sue the very people who keep them alive. The psychological and emotional problems in doing that, of course, are enormous. And, of course, the most important point is that the last thing the haemophiliacs want to be involved in, when they have AIDS in particular, is expensive, time-consuming and very distressing litigation procedures.

The Minister has said that the basic criterion for any government assistance is the need of the claimant, rather than the cause of the illness. If that is the case, then he should follow the example of the United Kingdom and give a seeding grant to this group, since the needs of this group, with two major physical problems, are indeed unique and their need is great. I believe that if he does not revise his decision, it will in fact be a very heartless consideration for a very, very special group in our society. The numbers involved are not small; the amount of money involved is not large. I believe that for once we should find some compassion from this Government and it should make a special grant to the Haemophilia Society which would enable it to care for its members. The problem then would resolve itself in terms of the ongoing care. The Government commitments would have ended with a one-off payment. There would be no long term problem, and indeed, these poor patients, who suffer so much in so many different ways, would have their problem, not resolved, but certainly minimised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Neil Mr L.R.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like, first, to direct my remarks towards some of the ill-informed comments that come from the Opposition from time to time and certainly from the National Farmers Federation and many other vested interest groups, particularly in the area of the lack of reform with the waterfront unions and the seagoing unions. No other unions within Australia have played a more positive or constructive role in trying to co-operate with the Government in changes that need to take place not only to assist the economy but also to make their unions more economically viable. The seafaring unions in particular have been at the forefront of multi-skilling. This has taken place only because of the constructive, objective and positive role that Pat Garrety, the Secretary of the Seamen's Union of Australia (SUA), has been able to play in cooperating with this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: In the Budget Papers a key element of the Government's shipping reform strategy is the program to reduce the size of crews on existing ships. To complement this program, the Government has agreed to partly fund retraining and voluntary early retirement schemes for the industry. Funding for these schemes of up to $15m has been allocated this year to the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority. I pay tribute to Pat Garrety for his cooperation with the Government in bringing this change about. It has certainly been no easy task for him to convince his members that fewer people are needed to man ships. Therefore, I really take exception to the fact that vested interest groups continually bag the Seamen's Union quite wrongly. It has certainly been at the forefront of making change within Australia.

The other union that always seems to get carpeted is the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia. If we have a look at the history of the Waterside Workers Federation we see that 20 years ago containerisaton was introduced into Australian ports. The cargo handling wharfies at that time numbered 21,000. Today there are only 5,000 in this industry. In the past each person handled something like 1,000 tons. Today each waterside worker handles something like 5,000 tonnes. Waterside workers have lifted their game and I think it is a tribute to Tas Bull, the Secretary of the Waterside Workers Federation, that they have cooperated with the Government. It is quite disappointing to see the ignorant way in which the National Farmers Federation and some members of the Opposition continually have a go at these people when they have served a constructive role in bringing their industry to the forefront of mechanisation and have tried to expand their output.

The Government has recognised this and has set aside $38m as part of its contribution towards the waterfront reform package on the basis that an acceptable in-principle agreement will be achieved throughout the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority. The bulk of this amount is to fund a retirement and redundancy program for stevedoring labour and to continue training, research and workplace reviews. A number of waterside workers have approached me and they are quite happy and contented with the way the discussions have taken place with the Government and the unions. That has been very good indeed.

I want to talk about a number of things that were in the Budget. At the forefront is road funding. Although I am disappointed that there was not more money allocated to road funding, this year's Budget has provided a total of $1.341 billion for road funding, an increase of $120m or almost 10 per cent. This compares with the consumer price index (CPI) increase of 7.6 per cent in 1988-89. Local roads in South Australia have received a 9 per cent increase in Federal Government funding. Local roads in South Australia have been allocated $22.7m in this year's Budget. In total South Australia will receive $91.3m from the Federal Government for road funding in this financial year.

The national highway system in my State of South Australia will receive more than $34m for maintenance and new construction work. Some major works on the national highway system include the upgrading of the Stuart Highway between Pimba and Wirrappa and reconstruction of sections of the Eyre Highway between Adelaide and Port Augusta. Major work totalling more than $24m will also be undertaken on national arterial roads in South Australia. I am pleased to say that on top of this the Federal Government is also providing more than $10m to assist the South Australian Government to meet its road responsibilities. I know that a number of roads, particularly within my electorate, are quite appalling but I am sure that slowly we will get there to surface these roads and to get them in a condition we all expect.

I would like to talk about Labor's commitment to health and community services. The Budget announcement in the community services and health portfolio showed a solid commitment by the Labor Government to the welfare of our nation. The combined package that was announced addresses essential areas of need in the community by providing for the following matters: There will be a new $15m safety net for home buyers facing extreme difficulty with mortgage repayments and $1,290m-up by 35 per cent-for public housing, home purchase assistance and new rental trust housing programs. An extra $27m has been allocated for accommodation projects as well as $7m over four years for health services for homeless youth.

An amount of $40m has been allocated over four years to improve women's health, with $8.9m extra for child care increases and indexed fee relief. An amount of $59.6m-up 40 per cent-has been allocated for HIV/AIDS prevention, treatment and research. Over four years a $13.13m user rights program will protect aged people and people with disabilities. A sum of $6.3m will be spent over four years for multi-purpose facilities to provide health, residential and community care services for aged people in country areas. There will be extended entitlements to pensioner health benefit and health care cards for older and long term unemployed people. Over three years $1.65m will be spent to improve access by people from non-English speaking backgrounds to health and community services. This is extremely beneficial for the area where I live in Whyalla, where 65 different nationalities live in unique harmony.

There will be extra funds of $2.4m for health and medical research over three years. Half a million dollars has been allocated for computing facilities for the Australian Institute of Health and $277,000 to improve income support and increased work force participation for people with disabilities. Maximum patient contribution under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme will rise from $11 to $12 from 1 October. Pensioners will still get pharmaceutical benefits scheme items free and concessional users will still pay only $2.50 a prescription. I have been particularly concerned about cervical and breast cancer in women and see the additional funding to provide extended screening programs-along with alternative birthing services-as a significant step forward in addressing identified needs under the national women's health policy.

Another very important issue is that of homeless youth. I welcome the news that $27m has been provided for accommodation linked to innovative support services which will assist young homeless people to become more independent and guide them to longer term stable accommodation to be complemented by $7m over four years to provide health services for homeless young people.

I also welcome the initiatives announced in the Federal Budget to assist pensioners to achieve a better standard of living. The detailed measures outlined by the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) in the Government's historic document Better Incomes: Retirement Policy into the Next Century will assist people approaching retirement with the opportunity to provide better incomes for themselves under sweeping reforms announced in the Budget. Labor's longstanding commitment to an age pension of 25 per cent of average weekly earnings will be not only met but exceeded in April 1990 when there will be a special $2 a week increase for single pensioners and a $3.30 increase per week for pensioner couples. I am extremely pleased that this increase will be in addition to the planned indexation increase.

Furthermore, rent assistance will be increased by $5 a week in December 1989 and by a further $5 a week in September 1990. Again these increases are in addition to those announced in last year's Budget. From March 1991, for the first time, rent assistance will be indexed every six months. One of the most important areas in which I have campaigned concerns the indexation of the pensioner income test-free area-$40 a week for single pensioners and $70 a week for combined pensioner couples. This has now become a reality and, from July 1991, will be indexed on an annual basis. This builds on measures announced in the April 1989 economic statement which made an income test-free area totally tax free by July 1990.

One of the main problems brought to me by pensioners in my electorate of Grey concerns the confusion created by the differences in the Social Security Act and the taxation system. The new measure simplifies the age pension and the taxation system. Furthermore, from 1995 no age pensioner will pay income tax, whether he receives a full or part rate pension.

There are further measures to assist pensioners. Concessional treatment under the pension income test of income received from home equity conversion schemes and annuities, as well as a simplified pension earnings credit scheme, will be provided to allow pensioners to receive higher incomes while retaining their full pensions. A new bereavement package will provide financial assistance to pensioners through a very difficult time. A range of new and upgraded independent financial, advisory and information services will be established for pensioners. These services recognise the increasing complexity of financial products available to provide retirement income. Pensioners need reliable information on the treatment of investments under income and assets tests as well as taxation. The better incomes package announced by the Government, as well as providing for those who have already retired, outlines and recognises the needs of our ageing population, and changes to superannuation arrangements will increase opportunities for those approaching retirement, especially women, to save for their own retirement. I will be detailing all of these measures announced in the Budget for pensioners in September in my twice-yearly pensioners information kit for pensioners in my electorate. I must say that they look forward to receiving that package.

One of the announcements in the Federal Budget which I feel has been overlooked by the media and which is extremely important to my electorate, covering 86.2 per cent of the State of South Australia, is the additional funding for multipurpose centres. The funding for these multipurpose centres comes under the portfolio of the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples), and an additional $6.3m has been allocated for this initiative over the next four years in recognition by the Government of the needs of small communities. At the present time, people living in small communities in rural and remote areas do not have access locally to a range of services because the size of these communities will not sustain the viable operation of separate services. In line with the Government's commitment to provide accessible health services to all Australians, 40 multipurpose centres will be developed, to be located in underserviced rural areas in 1989-90, and more will be approved in future years, depending on demand. I think this is a very positive step. Project officers from the Department of Community Services and Health will work with local community groups and State governments to develop proposals and bring together small ventures of two or more types of service to reduce overhead costs for each service. In addition to this, a small multipurpose centre standard grant will be available for some centres to help meet the higher cost of a small-scale operation.

In conclusion, I want to talk about the southern bluefin tuna program. It is quite appropriate that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), who has had such an outstanding rapport with the fishermen in my area, is at the table tonight. I commend him for the grants that he has made available under the southern bluefin tuna program. I welcome the funding announcement in the Federal Budget for the southern bluefin tuna program. Maintaining the program is of prime concern to me and my constituency on the west coast, and is extremely important to the tuna industry, and I am delighted that the fishermen at Port Lincoln see this as an extremely constructive move by the Minister. The amounts allocated, $700,000 for 1989-90 and $750,000 for 1990-91, will maintain and expand aspects of the research and monitoring program, which is used to assess the status of stocks of southern bluefin tuna. I understand that the investigations will continue into the parameters used to identify recruitment to the fishery, changes in abundance and the control measures necessary to monitor the adherence to stock limits.

Furthermore, the Commonwealth will continue to press for a global management arrangement on the southern bluefin tuna stocks to ensure that, should a recovery occur, the benefits of such a recovery will not be dissipated. I say to the Minister that I am sure that the red carpet will be out when he next goes to Port Lincoln as the fishermen there certainly see him as doing an excellent job in his role as Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I thank him on behalf of the fishermen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with a great deal of pleasure that I rise to make a contribution to this debate on the Appropriation Bills because there are so many areas in Australia where there is a need for improvement, where there is a need, even in some small ways, for government to do things better. I make the point first of all that my personal disappointment in this most recent Budget was that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) could not find it in his heart to provide some form of tax exemption for donations to mobile life education units. I am fully aware that donations to life education centres are tax deductable but that applies to centres in the capital cities. Right around Australia there are at least 27 mobile life education centres doing, I believe, a marvellous job in teaching our children about their bodies and what to avoid in the way of drugs and all sorts of substances that are harmful to them. I am very disappointed that the Treasurer could not provide tax deductability for donations to mobile life education centres.

SPEECH.PARA: I am also interested to report a letter that I had from the Canteen Manager at St Joseph's Hastings Regional School in Port Macquarie about the sales tax on milk. This Government last year managed to take $400m off the excise on beer, yet it still taxes flavoured milk for kids at 10 per cent. I think the interests of Australia's children justify the reversal of that tax.

I was also interested to note a letter I have received from VOTE-Voice of the Elderly, the Coffs Harbour and Districts Branch-expressing its great desire for some form of additional hostel and nursing home accommodation for the aged in that area. Of course, that does not apply solely to Coffs Harbour. The need is throughout my electorate, but I am interested that the people of VOTE in Coffs Harbour make the point to me in their letter that there is a genuine need for a special care hostel-hospital with highly trained staff to cater for sufferers of Alzheimers disease and related disorders. This is something that is sweeping through Australia, yet all the Government wants to do, I believe, is to sweep it under the carpet. We should realise that, of those Australians who live to be 80 years or more, one in five will suffer from some form of dementia, whether it is Alzheimers or some other form.

I am most grateful to the people of VOTE for taking the stance that they have done, because it supports me in the moves that I have been making ever since I have been elected to try to gain more attention for aged and elderly Australians. These are the people who have made their contribution to our society, and I think it is less than satisfactory that we are not providing absolutely everything that should be required.

I would like to detail some figures relating to the growth in the number of persons aged 70 years and over in my area. In health area 4, the Coffs-Bellingen-Nambucca area, the 1986 census revealed that the number of people aged 70 years and over totalled 5,931. By 1989 that had jumped by another 1,720 to a total of 7,651 people. That is a massive jump. According to the 1986 census, in area 5, the Kempsey-Macleay Valley area, the number of residents 70 years old and over totalled 1,766. That figure is now up to 2,314. In the Hastings area, 4,656 people of 70 years were covered by the 1986 census. That figure has now grown to 6,049. This is a massive jump. We are not providing for this increase because we have the home and community care (HACC) formula. We all know the HACC formula. It is not adequate because it is not keeping up.

The population growth estimates for the north coast of New South Wales are perennially proved wrong. They are always too low. We have a rapidly increasing population of ageing people and we are not putting in the infrastructure to cope with their needs. In the 1981-86 inter-census period, Coffs Harbour grew by 22.29 per cent; Nambucca, 24.96 per cent; Hastings, 17.69 per cent; and Kempsey, 17.06 per cent. These are massive growth figures. They are certainly the highest in total in New South Wales, if not the whole of Australia.

On the question of nursing home and hostel beds, I make the point that in area 4, the Macksville-Bellingen-Coffs Harbour area, there are not just people who are at risk of future institutionalisation, but people who are in desperate, urgent need of a bed right now, tonight. In the hospitals in that area 21 people and, in the community, 48 people-a total of 69-desperately need nursing home beds right now. As for hostel accommodation, there are 31 people who tonight, now, need a bed. There is a total bed deficit of 106 in that one little area of my electorate.

A little further to the south, in the Macleay Valley, a total of 36 people are in desperate need of nursing home beds now-not a risk in the future but a need right at this minute.
