Eleven of them are in hospital and there are 25 out in the community. Another 30 desperately need hostel beds. There is a total bed deficit of 66 in the Macleay Valley area. In the Hastings area, the situation is not quite as bad, I am pleased to say. There are five people in hospitals awaiting nursing home beds and 14 in the community, giving a total of 19 people who desperately need nursing home beds now. In the Hastings and Macleay Valley areas there are private nursing homes that are prepared to spend the money, at no expense to government, to put in extra beds but this Government will not let them go ahead and undertake that work. I believe that is shameful.

In the Hastings area there are 30 people awaiting hostel beds. There is a total bed deficit of 49 in that area. We cannot shut our eyes and hope it will go away. It just so happens that the north coast of New South Wales, because of its superb climate, attracts people. We have the fastest growth rate in Australia. People would rather live there than in many other places. We are not going to stop them. This is a free country. If they want to live in that marvellous mid north coast area, they should be allowed to do so. The fact that demographic studies continually underestimate growth must be addressed by government very quickly.

I would also like to address a current dramatic problem affecting pharmacies around Australia. I know that this is of particular significance to my electorate. I prefer to refer, not to pharmacists, but to one's friendly family chemist. Australians think of them in that way. It is proposed that dispensing fees will be cut by up to 25 per cent. The average cut per prescription will be $1.05. The projection from the Pharmacy Guild is that up to 30 per cent of pharmacies may close. I find this absolutely appalling. I hope it does not happen. I hope the estimates are wrong, but the indications I received from the pharmacists, the friendly family chemists, in my electorate are that the figures are pretty right. Of course, most of those that will close will be in country and regional centres. The majority of these pharmacies employ only one pharmacist. They are not huge businesses; they are small family businesses.

I have already mentioned the growth rate on the north coast of New South Wales. The growth rate of elderly residents in that area has been 16 per cent. They have a greater need for pharmaceutical care than many other sections of the community. The Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal in its report admits that this recommendation will cause `an unacceptable diminution of the services available to the community', as well as `unplanned' restructuring of the industry. That is just a bureaucratic way of saying that people will lose jobs and pharmacies will close. That is not satisfactory.

It should be recalled that when one talks about a pharmacy, one is not talking about handing pills over the counter; one is talking about service, caring advice, free home deliveries to the elderly who cannot go out to get their prescriptions filled, and free home deliveries to women with small children and to the disabled. We should pay tribute to the pharmacists of this country for the marvellous job they do in advising and helping people and treating minor injuries such as cuts and sprains or helping people to remove ticks and other problems of that nature. The Government must rethink what it will do to the pharmacists of this country.

I am always concerned that the present Government increasingly tends to use the environment as a smokescreen to obscure the real problems of our economy. Our net foreign debt is now $108 billion. When Labor came to power in 1983, after almost 200 years of this nation's existence, we had amassed a total overseas debt, public and private, of $23 billion. It took six years of Labor government to boost it to $108 billion. That is absolutely appalling. It is no wonder that Moody's Investors Service Inc. has downgraded our credit rating to AA2. We have had the world's greatest environmental statement which promised that a billion trees would be planted. Of course, it turned out that about 600 million of them were to be tossed out of the back of aeroplanes as seeds. That is a great tree planting program! If the Government is so concerned, why is it not fair dinkum about doing more in the area of soil conservation? In 1987-88, $6m was spent nationally on soil conservation, while $5m was spent on landscaping Parliament House. It is not in balance. As I said before, the Government is not fair dinkum. Had the coalition Government still been in office, our policy was to provide $50m for soil conservation between 1983 and 1989. Under Labor, the total figure since 1983 is only $21.8m. In spite of the fact that some people cannot see the wood for the trees, soil conservation is our number one environmental problem.

The other side of the coin is flood mitigation. We have what is known as the 2:2:1 system whereby the Commonwealth puts in $2, the States put in $2 and local government puts in $1. I do not know what occurs in other States, but in New South Wales the Commonwealth never puts in enough. It is never prepared to match what the State and local governments are prepared to put in.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish; last year we fully funded the New South Wales bid.

—That is not true. This Government is big on words, but it is short on funding and it is short on action. Most flood mitigation money appears to be spent on urban drainage. There is no money for river improvement works to stop Australia being washed out to sea. I believe that river improvement works are just as important in terms of soil conservation because every year-and look at the wet year we are having so far-Australia is being washed out to sea and we cannot get a penny for river improvement works.

SPEECH.PARA: In Kempsey there is one floodway project. Under the 2:2:1 system each year, the Commonwealth gives $15,000, the State gives $15,000 and local government provides $7,500. That totals enough to buy one old house a year in order to clear the floodway. The trouble is that 70 houses need to be cleared, so it will be 70 years before we can clear that floodway. Similarly, in Coffs Harbour there is a flood mitigation project in the urban area. Under the 2:2:1 system, we are getting approximately $100,000 per year. At that rate of funding it will take between 15 and 20 years to fix the problem.

In the few minutes remaining to me I would like to talk about the urgent need for airport upgrading at Port Macquarie. As honourable members know, Port Macquarie is one of the jewels of the Australian coast. It has a superb climate. In fact, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation says it has optimum climate for the human animal. Anybody who has been there would appreciate the great beauty of the place. The airport is desperately in need of and overdue for upgrading to jet standard. The cost is $6.122m. I flag the need for $2m of Commonwealth money to get that airport upgraded to jet standard.

With regard to Kempsey airport, while it has landing lights, there are no night landing facilities. This severely restricts the possibility of flights into and out of Kempsey. It really needs a T-VASIS system, but successive Ministers have flatly said no. Kempsey is so keen about the matter that it is spending its own money to put in a non-directional beacon. It has been waiting for two years for the Department to approve the tender. It is taking far too long. The Department now says, `We are pulling one out of Orange. You can borrow that until you get the recommendation and the tender for the other one'. That would mean double installation costs and, of course, double testing costs. The amount involved is only $80,000. I believe the Government should make a contribution because aviation-not that we have much of it at the moment!-is vitally important. If we ever doubted that, the present situation shows how important aviation is to this country. Government members are doing nothing except exacerbating the situation. They are being led by that flight lieutenant, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). I believe that this Government must do better.
Debate (on motion by Mr Lee) adjourned.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: (Budget Debate)
Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, Mr Speaker, I would like to add my congratulations to those of other members of the House on your elevation to your present position. I am sure that you will continue to serve your own electorate and this House with distinction. I hope you will forgive me if on a few occasions in future months I refer to you as Madam Speaker. I hope you do not take it personally. I will try to adjust as quickly as I can.

SPEECH.PARA: Appropriation Bill (No. 1) deals with matters brought down in the Budget by the Treasurer (Mr Keating). The most important part of the Budget Papers that affects my electorate is the announcement regarding retired and elderly people. Mr Speaker, having visited my electorate in December last year on the Prime Minister's task force on retirement incomes, you will be aware that there are more age pensioners in the electorate of Dobell on the central coast of New South Wales than in any other electorate in Australia. Through the efforts of yourself, Mr Speaker, and people such as your co-chairperson of the Prime Minister's task force on retirement incomes we were able to achieve some quite significant improvements for retired Australian citizens. I wish to spend a little time tonight going through those issues.

I am sure that members of the Opposition will give the Government the credit that it deserves for these historic reforms. They add up to a package of more than $700m this financial year. The Government's decision to increase the base rate of the pension by $2 a week next April has earned the greatest response from the community. That increase is on top of the normal indexation increases which will occur in November and April. The reason why increases are coming through in November and April is that the Government announced in the April statement this year that it would be bringing forward the dates on which cost of living increases will be paid to pensioners and people receiving benefits. This means that people receiving pensions will be getting their cost of living increases 12 weeks earlier than they now do. Many of those pensioners have reminded me that that is simply restoring a delay which was inserted a few years ago, but I think the Government should be commended for taking the action that it has in bringing forward those cost of living increases by 12 weeks.

One area which has created a great deal of confusion amongst retired people is that of tax. The difficulty has been the concept of a tax rebate for some pensioners and not for others. Each year pensioners have had to sit down, make calculations and determine how much they could earn on top of their pension before starting to pay tax. On occasions one almost needed a masters degree in economics to work out how much could be earned as the calculations were so complex. This confusion is being eliminated by the Government in two steps: first of all, in this financial year from 1 July the tax threshold for married pensioners was brought up to the same level as the social security threshold for married pensioners; that is, they can each earn $35 a week before their pension starts to be reduced and from 1 July this year they can each earn $35 per week before they start to pay tax. That has simplified the system and one does not have to sit down halfway through the year and do calculations to work out how much one can earn before tax is paid. The tax threshold is equal to the social security threshold; that is, $70 a week combined for married pensioners.

For single pensioners there has been an even bigger increase. A couple of years ago single pensioners could earn only $4 a week before they started to pay tax. Last financial year that rose to $10 a week; this financial year the Government is pushing it up to $25 a week; and from 1 July 1990 single pensioners will also have the tax-free threshold equal to the social security threshold; that is, $40 per week. By simplifying the system we are removing a lot of the confusion amongst elderly people. I am hopeful that at the end of this financial year I will have fewer pensioners calling my office and raising questions because we have simplified the system. I think that that will be welcomed.

One of the most radical measures announced in the Budget Statements by the Treasurer was the Government's retirement incomes policy, which we have been working on for some time. I hope the Opposition is considering this matter. I am sure the Australian people would welcome bipartisan support for a retirement incomes policy. The reason why it would be good to have a bipartisan policy on this matter is that I think elderly people believe that once a new system is introduced for retired people and they make decisions about where they should place their investments, it is a little unfair to change the rules halfway through the game. The Government has announced that in 1995 no part pensioner-either service pensioner or age pensioner-will pay any income tax. I am disappointed that to date the Opposition has not come out in support of that policy so that we could say that there is bipartisan support for this revolutionary measure. I hope that in the weeks to come the Opposition will look at this closely because at the moment part pensioners are paying too much in tax. They lose 50c in the dollar by a reduction in their pension by the Department of Social Security and if they are paying tax they lose at least another 21c on the remainder in income tax. We are saying that no part age pensioner or service pensioner will pay any tax. Instead of paying 71c or more in the dollar, pensioners will simply be paying the 50c in the dollar. That is quite radical and will encourage more people to provide for their own retirement. It will make those fortnightly superannuation pensions and fortnightly annuities more attractive than they were in the past. I think that should be welcomed.

During the recent parliamentary sitting break we had some interesting comments from senior spokesmen on the Opposition benches on the question of retirement and welfare. Senator Stone, the Opposition finance spokesman, made some quite amazing comments. I will quote from an article in the Sydney Morning Herald. It is headed, `Welfare blamed for lack of saving'. It states:
The growth of the welfare state has eroded Australia's level of savings, the Opposition finance spokesman, Senator John Stone, said yesterday.
. . . 20 years ago Australia had a very high level of savings. What has changed since then, he said, was that Australia had become a welfare state.
He refused to say how far he would wind back the welfare system, saying he wanted to first get to the point where enough people acknowledged a problem exists.

So there we have it. The Opposition says that it wants to go back 20 years to the welfare system that applied in the 1950s where the majority of retired people did not get an age pension and had to live with their children. They did not get the sort of support they can today. The Opposition says that that is the way it will promote more savings-by ripping the welfare system to shreds. I mention in passing that Senator Stone, the Opposition spokesman on finance, has called for cutbacks in welfare but he has not done too badly himself. He retired from the Public Service on the very generous superannuation system that applied to senior bureaucrats. Of course, now he is accumulating a parliamentary pension. So I am sure that Senator Stone's calls for the 1950s welfare system will not interfere with his measures for providing for his own retirement.

We have also had comments made by the Federal President of the Liberal Party, Mr Elliott. I wish to quote from an article in the Sydney Morning Herald headed `Elliott attacks Australian belief in ``handouts'' '. The article says:
The Federal president of the Liberal Party, Mr John Elliott, called yesterday for the removal of `welfare shackles' to improve Australia's economy, even though this would cause pain for some people.
He goes on to say:

There will therefore be pain for some of us as one takes away some of the welfare shackles, as we support causes that are going to improve the productivity and living standards of our citizens overall.

I just wonder how Mr Elliott will be hurt by slashing back the welfare system. I would be surprised if Mr Elliott was receiving any support at all from the social security system. In fact, I find it obscene that someone as wealthy as Mr Elliott is leading the charge to cut back the sort of assistance that we provide to our elderly people receiving service and age pensions.

Let us just look at the Opposition's overall position on tax. It has come up with this gimmick scheme to provide for an inflation adjustment of interest from banks and building societies. It looks like the Opposition will have to dump that gimmick because it has realised that a few fishhooks are hidden in it. We know that the Opposition has promised those senior businessmen that it will not be retrospective, so Mr Bond and Mr Elliott will not have their massive borrowings affected. We know that the Opposition has promised the Real Estate Institute of Australia that it will not apply to negative gearing, so its friends in the real estate industry will not be upset; yet it has told us that, for some reason, credit unions will not be included in the scheme. Simply saying that the scheme will not be retrospective creates all sorts of problems. Imagine if the Liberal Party-shock, horror!-were elected at the next election and it announced that it was going to introduce its scheme to cut back the tax deduction which businesses get for their borrowings. Before the legislation passed both Houses of Parliament we would have a massive borrowing spree by the businesses of Australia to try to make sure that they could borrow as much as they could so that they could claim the tax breaks on those borrowings before the new proposal came into effect. That is absolute madness.

In the short time that is available to me I simply make the point again that the Opposition has not really sorted out its views on retirement incomes and on tax. It has said that it wants to abolish the capital gains tax-the one measure that has cut down all those massive tax avoidance schemes that tried to convert income into capital gain. I think it is really time that the Opposition went back through its policies again.

TALK.START.PARA: —What policies?

—As the honourable member for Fisher has interjected, what policies? The other day I saw an interesting cartoon suggesting that one of the first things spotted by the Voyager spacecraft on the other side of Neptune was the tax policy of the Liberal Party, but someone said that that could not be true. I commend the Bill to the House and I congratulate the Treasurer once again on another magnificent Budget.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee), who preceded me in this debate, referred in particular to pensioners. If this Government is in office any longer, there will not be any pensions for pensioners. That is the reality of the economic crisis that is facing this country today. The major crisis that we are faced with is a huge overseas debt created largely by this Government. The honourable member for Dobell referred to the miserly $2 that pensioners will get; yet only a few days ago this Government announced that it was going to increase the stamp allowance for members of parliament by $21,000. Those are the sorts of standards of this Government. I say to the honourable member for Dobell: there will be no comfort for his pensioners from any government which brings those sorts of issues to the fore-a $2 increase for pensioners and a $21,000 increase in the stamp allowance. It is absolutely ludicrous and shows the sorts of priorities that this Government has. It wants to be re-elected at all costs and it is going all out to do that at the expense of the weak and needy people in our community.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia's debt crisis can only be illustrated by the following figures: for the first 82 years of Federation our debt rose to about $33 billion. In the last six years it has risen to $130 billion; in other words, it has risen by $100 billion in six years. That is the crisis which faces Australia today. This Budget and this Government are not addressing that issue.

Sometimes members of the Government come in here and say that they have a great record. But housing interest rates are 37 per cent higher under the Hawke Government than they were under the Fraser Government. Let us look at what this means for the average modest family. Many people in my electorate of Braddon have very modest incomes-about $22,000-which is less than the average in Australia. A family on that income with a $30,000 home loan, which everybody in Australia knows is very low these days, has been paying $70 per month extra on interest rates over the last six years, the last 72 months, compared to what they would have been paying in the years of the Fraser Government. That is the difference in regard to interest rates.

The Government talks a lot about the employment opportunities that it has created. Of course, it has created very few. It is the small businesses and the business people out in the community, working themselves to the bone, that have created those jobs. But let us look at the Government's unemployment record. If its record in creating employment has been so good, why are our unemployment figures not down to one or 2 per cent? Under the Fraser Government unemployment averaged 5.9 per cent. Under the Hawke Government it is 7.9 per cent, which is up 34 per cent each year on average for the last six years. Our external debt figures are up, not by 30 per cent, 100 per cent or 200 per cent but by 600 per cent. That is the crisis that this nation is facing. In the Australian of 16 August this year, after the Budget, Mr McGuinness commented:
There is no more reason to rely on the forecasts in the Treasury documents than there was last year.

What happened last year? It was forecast that we would have a current account deficit of $9.5 billion. That figure blew out enormously. So why should we believe that this year the figure will be $18.5 billion? What an incredible indictment of any government! As each month goes by, under the framework and policies that this Government has put in place in this great nation of ours, we are going down the tube to the tune of $1.5 billion. Here we are, one of the richest resource countries in the world, with a high standard of education and, up until a few days ago, a good transport and communications system-yet we are failing to produce the goods. We are lacking in competition. And it is due to this Government's activities.

We also find that we are now one of the highest taxed countries in the world. This is the highest taxing government Australia has faced since the Second World War and in fact in the last six years taxation levels per man, woman and child in this country have risen from $2,900 to $5,800. In other words, the increase has been 100 per cent.

The significance of that is when we compare it with the increase in average weekly earnings. Over the same period we would have expected a reasonable increase to match the extra taxation burden that this Government has placed on the Australian people. But the reality is that the average wage earner's packet has risen only 50 per cent in that period while taxation has risen 100 per cent. That is why the ordinary person, the average Australian is feeling the pressure under this Government. Taxation levels have doubled under its administration but the pay packet of the average wage earner has gone up by only 50 per cent. That causes a crisis in many families in this nation-the less well off families; the people earning under $25,000 with two or three children and trying to maintain a job. Those people are operating on a very tight budget. When we have interest rates at 17 per cent in this nation caused specifically by government policy it is the children and the young families that are severely hurting. This Government is largely to blame for it through specific monetary policy to squeeze those people and to make them share the burden of this Government's reckless administration of this country. It is a great tragedy that those people are being forced to carry the burden of maladministration of the huge overseas debt which grew under this Government.

I know some Government members would like to argue that it is not their fault, but it is the Government of Australia that sets the framework in which everybody in this nation operates and it has failed dismally to set a framework in which Australia has been able to rein in the debt or maintain a low level of debt. That debt crisis will be a noose around the neck of young Australians for generations to come because of Hawke and Keating and their so-called strategy. We ought to be reminded that one of their promises was that no child would be living in poverty in 1990. The reality is that this Government drives people into poverty. The poorer families in this country now realise that it is the policies of this Government that have really nobbled them as a family in trying to get on. Families want to try to improve their lot in life, to get on and save money so that they can provide a better standard for their young people. The reality is that under this Government's administration more and more of the poor families in this country have become dependent on government welfare. They cannot maintain independence of government welfare on their own resources because of the high taxation levels and the high interest rates in this country. The sooner this Government is removed from the administration of Australia the sooner will be the circumstances in which this great nation is able to get itself back on the track of improving its overseas debt crisis and lifting the burden of taxation from the ordinary Australian.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, very briefly I record my congratulations to you on your election to your high office. I am sure that not only your family but also your whole electorate are delighted at the honour the House has conferred.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to respond to some of the Opposition's remarks but in particular in this debate on the Appropriation Bills I believe there has been a very hypocritical and disgraceful approach by the Opposition to the increase in postage allowance that members of the House of Representatives will now enjoy. I just want to set the record straight from my perspective on this issue. Commentators and other people should look at this as a continuum and an addition to a process that has been going on for some time. What has been that process? I can recall some 15 years ago when I was campaign director for the State member for Mount Druitt, Tony Johnson, when he first ran for the seat, that if one wanted to see a State member or a Federal member in New South Wales one went either to Chifley Square or to Macquarie Street. In other words, to provide a service to their constituents, members of parliament did it out of Parliament House on a State basis or the Commonwealth offices on a Federal basis. We have moved so far over those years with that historic decision to give members an electorate office in their own electorate. What was the implication of that? It brought members of parliament closer to the people and made them more accessible. It provided staff for members of parliament so that they did not have to do it on their own or alternatively rely on a pool typist for correspondence. What was the impact of that? Members gave better service to their constituents and were more accessible. If a constituent could not get the member at least there was a very competent person in that member's office who would compassionately and sensitively take on board the complaint and try to resolve it.

In my own circumstances, coming to this Parliament in 1984, I was really shocked, coming out of the Public Service, that we did not have computers, that in the 1980s members of parliament could be dealing with a huge Public Service, dealing in millions of dollars, making all sorts of decisions and using electronic typewriters.

TALK.START.PARA: —And pretty old, too, some of them.

—They were very old. I can remember hooking up my Apple IIe at my own expense and paying $900 for an interface into a typewriter and thinking how grand that was. It used to take me about 2 1/2 days to send out 300 letters. My electorate office computer and laser printer arrived in the middle of the last election. Now, instead of taking 2 1/2 days to do 300 letters we can do it very quickly. Some members of parliament at that stage were very concerned that computers may take away some of the need for staff and that we could be having some redundancies. But they have created more work. I am pleased they have created more work because we are more accessible to the people and that is what our role ought to be.

SPEECH.PARA: The postage allowance is a logical extension. It has been argued passionately by the Opposition that this is a proposal designed to help marginal members. I have never considered that my seat was marginal-some say it is very safe-but I have a very fundamental view about my electorate. I think exceptionally highly of its people. I believe that they deserve the best and that I have a role and a responsibility to ensure that I can pass off as much information to individual groups and constituents as I can. We live in an age, Mr Deputy Speaker, when people talk about information rich and information poor. I assure this House that I make no apologies for saying that I believe my constituents in Chifley deserve to be information rich. I do everything within my power to ensure that that is the case. I welcome the postage entitlement.

More than 12 months ago I asked the research section of the Parliamentary Library to look at the entitlements for members of parliament elsewhere. It staggered me that a member of parliament in the United States of America-a congressman or senator-can write to every constituent six times a year. In Canada it is twice every year. For the first time, we decided that in our parliamentary submission to the Remuneration Tribunal we would get away from a situation of learned judges gazing at their navel and trying to determine what the incremental increase in stamps should be. Should it be $1,000 a month? Should it be $1,050? These were the sorts of onerous decisions we were putting on them. With no disrespect to learned judges, I must say that I have not much faith in that process.

We have put it on a logical formula basis: a member of parliament is entitled to write to every constituent once a year. We are not going to argue about this formula. The figure used is 70,000. It is a formula basis, which is much better than demanding judges to gaze at their navels and try to make some determination. I predict that in the fullness of time others in Australia will follow what we have done. The Minister at the table, the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West), has played a very important role in trying to improve facilities for members so that they can improve facilities for their constituents. I would like to congratulate him. I would like to see more services being provided to members than we currently enjoy.

In that list of facilities I failed to mention that we were provided with a facsimile machine in our electorate offices. When people asked me whether I had a facsimile machine I used to use the old joke and say, `No, but we do have a design group working on turbo-charged pigeons'. That is how outrageous I thought it was in this day and age not to have a facsimile machine.

Members of the Opposition are playing a hypocritical role in this matter by saying that they are concerned about the formula. They say they are worried about whether the entitlement can be transferred. It cannot. It is to be used for parliamentary and electorate purposes, and it will be.

Let us look at the Senate. Senators are creating such a fuss about the fact that they do not have the same entitlement. Senators say that they do not have an electorate as members do, but are representatives of the State and that, indeed, if there is a vacancy, if someone resigns, the State Parliament fills that vacancy. Let us put aside that sort of argument that they consistently and persistently advance and let us accept that they have electorates. Are the senators arguing that if we go to formulas they should have the same formula? If they are, then they are saying that there should be an extra $40m spent solely on the senators. I think that is ridiculous. The Senate has a different role to play in this place. It has established a reputation for its committee work and reviewing of legislation and it ought to concentrate on what it does best.

It will come as no surprise to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, when I say that I strongly endorse this increased postage allowance. As a member in a so-called safe seat, I see this increase as vital for me and my constituents. They are not going to have second-best treatment. It will allow me to fulfil one of the roles that I think important-that is, providing as much useful information to them and keeping them informed of a whole variety of things as best I can. It is something that I have done previously. I will continue to do it and this increase will allow me to do it even better.

In the few minutes remaining I would like to respond to some of the other things that have been said. The honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) tried to express some concern about the national debt. He did not give the source of that debt. More than 60 per cent of the national debt comes from private enterprise. That has been the really significant increase. The other area of debt is State governments and statutory authorities. The smallest component is the Commonwealth Government. Our proportion of debt is quite small and is rapidly diminishing. It is diminishing because we are doing something that the so-called conservative, born-to-rule economic experts were never able to do-that is, to have surpluses that are being put towards paying off our part of that debt that the honourable member for Cowper talked about.

The honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles) talked about the living standards of ordinary people and the burden of taxation. One needs to repeat that, in terms of personal income tax scales applying today in Australia, we should look at what the Opposition left us with. It left us with personal rates, particularly the 60c rates, which were not being paid by those who were incurring them. If we take those rates that Mr Howard had when he was the Treasurer in the last outgoing conservative Government and index them to today, we would be paying more than what the Labor Government and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) have set in terms of personal income tax. The Opposition does not mention the way that we have cleaned up the tax system and made it much fairer. No longer are we subsidising anyone's free lunches, as we so frequently did.

The honourable member talked about children and families. It is quite true to say that the working men and women of Australia, by accepting restraint-restraint not exhibited by the pilots-have made an enormous contribution to Australia and have created so many jobs. We have a low unemployment rate of 6 per cent, a great source of pride in this part of the House. We want to get that rate down. We want to create more jobs. That is the way we believe we need to go.

The other thing that we have done, which no other government has done, is to index family allowances and supplements. No longer will such important assistance to the poorer people in our community erode over time, because this Labor Government has shown its commitment to giving money not to the millionaires, not to those who can afford it, but to those who are really most in need.

I support the Appropriation Bill. I repeat that I applaud the Budget that has been brought down successfully by the Treasurer-it is his seventh Budget-in difficult circumstances. He is making a tremendous contribution to the economic recovery of Australia and is certainly providing a sound future for all young Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate you, Mr Chairman of Committees, on your recent appointment. Your contribution since you have been here has been noted by everybody. Before the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) departs, I must say that his speech on justifying electoral stamp allowances amounted to virtual justification for electoral fraud. The implications of expanding the stamp allowance from $9,000 to $30,000 in an election year and the complete bend in the words put out by the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) give massive latitude to those who would walk right across it. I have no doubt what those in the Australian Labor Party in New South Wales have thought of this. They have spent a lifetime trying to convert the costs of political parties to the taxpayers. They have done it all. You pay them for the State electoral areas. You have settled what you get in your seat since you have been a member.
—You like the sleazy donations, don't you?

—No, I do not. Mr Brereton, one of the Australian Labor Party's newly endorsed candidates, would know all about sleazy engagements. The New South Wales Labor Party is the most sleazy lot I have ever come across-the greatest lot of sleazebags I have ever come across.
—What about Murray in New South Wales?
—I am surprised at the Minister. He is a left winger and not even part of the New South Wales right wing louts.
—What about the $25,000 that went to Murray?
—Order! The honourable member for Ryan has the call. I suggest to the honourable member that he would assist the Chair if he directed his remarks through the Chair.

—Indeed, Mr Deputy Speaker. In the limited time available-I am sorry that I have only 10 minutes in which to speak because I would have liked to say many things about the Budget-I will speak about the contents of the Budget and then about the statement of Moody's Investors Service Inc., which I regard as significant. The Trade Practices Commission is within my area of responsibility as shadow Minister for business, privatisation and consumer affairs. In the Budget the Trade Practices Commission received a princely $700,000 increase in its total expenditure for the coming year. The Trade Practices Commission is probably the most important commission in commerce in Australia. We have stated quite clearly in our policy that the Trade Practices Commission will play a significant role in ensuring competition in the marketplace. It is very important in the privatisation program. The Chairman of the Trade Practices Commission has said that the extra $700,000 just will not allow the Commission to do its job. In a nation such as ours nothing is more important than ensuring competition. I deplore what the Government has managed to come up with in that area.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Securities Commission (ASC) proposal is also within my area of responsibility. In the ASC earlier this year there was a new grab for power by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), without a referendum being held. A series of Bills seeking to transfer corporate power in Australia from the cooperative scheme to the Federal Parliament were introduced. For years the Labor Party has been trying to get its hands on corporate powers but it has had no justification for doing so, except that the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), in its plan for the future of Australia, has said, `We want to get control of the corporate powers so we can place trade unionists on boards of companies in this nation and expose all sorts of things'. We would like to expose a few things in the ACTU and look at the management of some of those trade unions. That would be more to the point. That is the place to go to see some of the rorts that go on in this nation.

The Australian Securities Commission Bill came before the House and now a sleazy deal is going on to try to make Victoria the principal place for the Commission's operations. Mr Cain said, `If you put the Commission in Victoria, we'll give you our whole corporate division. But you have to take the lot-all the employees and their superannuation'. The Attorney-General is not too sure about that because he knows in his own heart that the Commission's operations should go to Sydney. And so the argy-bargy goes on.

It is worth recording the fact that currently the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC) is battling on with the $3.5m which it received from the Commonwealth Government last year. That amount was matched by the States, so it received a total of $7m. In this Budget-the new body has not even been set up; it will not start till 1 July next year-$15.7m has been allocated for this year alone, which is double what the NCSC operates on. What will happen the following year with this great efficient operation? It will be allocated $65m. That is not bad, is it?-going from $7m to $65m in 18 months. Really and truly, what sort of a caper does the Government think it is on about? It is a complete rort. It is just grabbing the power, pumping the money in and making all Australian companies complete new forms. Mr Deputy Speaker, you know as well as I do that the affairs of State governments, including the Western Australian Government, will not be served by this measure. Even you attested to that. As my time is limited I will not go into that matter. I will turn to an issue which I am sure is at the heart of the concern of the Minister for Administrative Services, who is at the table, and that is asset sales. The Minister is a great privatiser! He knows all about selling things: he loves to sell things!

TALK.START.PARA: —I do well with property.

—I hope that he does. In the Budget he has nominated the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation and the Moomba pipeline for sale. I thought that the Minister did not like selling assets. He is the man who said, `There will be no sales while I am the Minister'. The proposals are in the Budget and the Minister's name is on the line. What is he doing about it? What is his commitment to this? He is selling public assets although he does not believe in doing so. Where is his name on the list? Those New South Wales Labor Party members are great people: they stand by their principles! The Opposition's policy on privatisation is quite clear. It is well known and articulated and it is in print. We will deliver. The people of Australia want to see efficiency, competition and employees having the right to own shares in the equity process.
—Will you sell Telecom?
—That is not in the first three-year program.
—When will you sell Telecom?

—I did not say that we would. It is not in our first three-year program. However, we will sell Qantas Airways Ltd and Australian Airlines. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) also wants to sell them. However, the Minister and the Labor Party do not want him to do so. Most of all, the ACTU says that the Government must not sell them. It does not matter what goes on about Telecom Australia. What goes on in the Labor Party is that the Prime Minister and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) want to sell Telecom but they do not have the guts to do so because their Party will not be in it.

SPEECH.PARA: We will deliver to Australia the competitiveness which is necessary for our economy. We will not call upon taxpayers to put up the billions of dollars that ought to be put into Australian Airlines, Qantas, the Commonwealth Bank, Telecom, Australia Post and so on. We are determined that those bodies should stand on their own feet and be competitive. But the Government is not; it is running for cover. So much for what is in the Budget.

I will turn quickly to another matter which fascinated me enormously, and that is Moody's press release. I have not seen a more condemning statement on Australian economic policy in years. It was quite fantastic. Before quoting from the statement I will repeat the Treasurer's comments. That great collector of watches and clocks, who still copped a living away from home allowance, said:
The Moody's judgment is ill-founded and vindicates the Government's decision to put Australia's reputation and independence above that of a New York company.

He went on to downgrade Moody's a trifle by saying that it had made an `incompetent judgment'. He then went on to say that it was a `lightweight and illogical judgment'. That is not bad. After all, in 1986 Moody's was joined in this by the other world known rating agency, Standard and Poor's. Moody's and Standard and Poor's are the two greatest and best known rating agencies in the world. Everyone in the commercial world is judged by them at some stage or other. The effects of their most recent efforts will not be felt just by government. It seems to be taken by the Treasurer that he is the only one offended. We cannot possibly offend the Treasurer because he is above offending, or so he thinks. Other people were offended by Moody's downgrading, helped by the Treasurer's ill-judgment. If he goes around abusing these people and refusing to allow them access to the Department of the Treasury and such nonsense, what does he expect to get, a blue ribbon? That would be quite ridiculous.

The organisations which will be affected are the Australian Industry Development Corporation, the Government's merchant banks part of which it intends to try to sell on the market in the near future-it is well underwritten-the Australian Resources Development Bank, the Australian Wheat Board, the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, the National Australia Bank, National Mutual, the Westpac Banking Corporation, the Queensland Treasury Corporation and the State Bank of New South Wales. Those are just a few of the organisations involved in the downgrading. As a result of Australia's credit rating being downgraded the overseas investments of those corporations will be affected. It is worth quoting the reason Moody's took this action because it will enlighten a few people as to what is going on. Moody's press release stated:

The factors that Moody's considers crucial to its rating action include the following: (1) the government's inability to control excessive domestic demand growth-(2) insufficient progress in generating additional export-earning capacity and in restructuring industry to achieve productivity gains--and (3) the continued slow pace of structural adjustment, which makes Australia ill-positioned to weather the next downturn in the global business cycle without further large increases in foreign-currency debt.

That is all very straightforward. It is no wonder that Moody's is concerned. What Moody's is saying is that if there is a downturn in commodity prices-Australia's balance of payments is very dependent on commodity prices-quite clearly, the exchange rate will be at risk. If the exchange rate is at risk those who hold Australian dollar investments will suffer a substantial loss.
The press release continues:
Moreover, the current Labor government has been unable to rein in domestic demand in an overheated economy, despite the opportunities provided by the recent upswing in the business cycle-
it was a very significant upswing indeed-

The Commonwealth government has achieved a growing fiscal surplus on its own account . . . but political and social factors have prevented the application of a total policy mix that is sufficiently rigorous to balance the external accounts. The government has relied primarily on a tight monetary policy, which has bolstered the Australian dollar, thereby stimulating imports and discouraging exports.

In a nutshell, those are precisely the problems. We were going to have, in the third Labor term, great structural reforms, but that became too hard. The Minister knows full well that, where he comes from, they are not going to have structural reforms on the waterfront. There are too many perks and lurks. The ACTU says `No, thank you', so suddenly that great third term reform goes out the window. That is recorded in Moody's judgment of Australia, according to its press release, and until that matter is addressed it will continue to be recorded in our balance of payments problems. It is a great pity that the Government has drawn away from it.
Finally, may I quote from a well known adviser to the Government, Professor Hughes:

The Government's response to the current situation of high demand and inflation coupled with labour shortages and a growth of imports that has far outstripped that of exports has been to continually tighten monetary policy. Interest rates have been driven up in an attempt to slow domestic demand and import growth. This has created serious problems for exporters, both through increased costs and reduced prices as the exchange rate rose and eroded competitiveness.
Do we need to go any further into any analysis of the balance of payments problems in Australia and the total lack of government response to a critical position than those few comments?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I take the opportunity to congratulate you on your appointment. I know that you are going to be very impartial and fair in your judgments on the conduct of members in this House.

SPEECH.PARA: Once again the Commonwealth Government has achieved a Budget surplus. On this occasion it is a record $9,122m compared with $5,899m in 1988-89. As the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has pointed out, the surplus will be more than enough to offset the borrowings by all State and local governments in Australia. The Government must be congratulated on the decision to use the entire surplus to continue repaying our overseas debt. Another aspect of the Budget which has my strong support is the announcement of the retirement incomes policy. Before I go on to talk about that I would like to say a little more about Moody's Investors Service Inc. in view of the fact that the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) has found it necessary to give it such strong support.

In circumstances of strong economic stability and responsibility, it is incomprehensible to me that the international credit rating agency Moody's should once again have downgraded Australia's long term credit rating. I think it is now down to AA2. I find it very surprising that the honourable member for Ryan had to quote examples to explain away why this discredited international agency has chosen to downgrade Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who had discredited it? Only Keating.

—Not only the Treasurer but many other people too. Australia's credit rating had already been reduced to the second rating of AA1 in 1986 and the new third rating means that it will be more difficult for Australia to borrow overseas at reasonable rates of interest. I do not know why the honourable member for Ryan is so pleased about this. It is typical of the Opposition. It is always pleased at anything that downgrades Australia's economic opportunities. It is particularly difficult to understand why the downgrading has occurred at a time when Australia is repaying government overseas debt and distinguished economists overseas have been congratulatory of the Australian Government's fiscal and monetary policies. The problem is, of course, that the big increase in our foreign debt has been through the activities of the corporate sector, which has not necessarily borrowed on the basis of productive capacity but rather on speculative ventures of one sort of another. I notice that the honourable member for Ryan is not prepared to talk about those things. However, that is not what I want to talk about; the honourable member for Ryan prompted me to make some comments.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said before, the announcement of the retirement incomes policy is an important aspect of the Budget. Some 11 per cent of the Australian population is now over the age of 65 years and by the year 2021 it is estimated that that figure will have increased to around 18 per cent. At that time about 3.9 million Australians will be aged 65-including, I might add, myself and perhaps most of my fellow parliamentarians, although I will probably get there a bit earlier than most. When I first entered the Federal Parliament in 1980 I was most impressed by the retirement income policies which the Whitlam Labor Government intended to introduce in 1975. Unfortunately, as we all know, there was a coup by the then Governor-General and as a result the Whitlam Government lost office. The Fraser Liberal-National Party Government which followed completely rejected any idea of adopting the Whitlam scheme.

The Government is to be commended for its efforts to maintain and improve the age pension. We have at last kept our promise that the age pension will be increased to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. The next goal is to reach 30 per cent of average weekly earnings, but in the meantime the Government is providing better opportunities and incentives for people to add to their pensions with a self-generated retirement income. We must not forget that before the Hawke Labor Government gained office in 1983, the majority of the work force were not members of superannuation schemes. In addition, there was a strong tax incentive for retired workers to take superannuation benefits in the form of lump sums, and in that way they defeated the whole purpose of superannuation in providing a retirement income. Another problem was the lack of portability. The retirement income policy initiative of the Federal Labor Government since 1983 has progressively overcome these problems. Most importantly, the Federal Government has encouraged the growth of superannuation as an established part of the wages policy of the work force.

I would like to have quoted from an excellent booklet entitled `Better Incomes-Retirement Income Policy into the Next Century', copies of which are available from my electorate office in Boronia for my constituents who might be either reading this speech or listening to it. I have been cut back to a very short time and so will not be able to read that quote, but it appears on page 6. It is very important and I hope that people will have an opportunity to read it. As the booklet indicates, the overall result of the Federal Government's commitment to improving superannuation has been the extension of the benefits of superannuation to a much larger proportion of the work force than ever before. It is particularly gratifying to me to note in the Budget that as part of the wages system for 1991 the Government is giving consideration to the gradual introduction of a further 3 per cent award for occupational superannuation. This is in addition to the 3 per cent award which was introduced following the 1986 wages case and involves employer contributions and superannuation for the self-employed and those who may not get the 3 per cent award.

Another matter I should like to raise concerns the funding provided in the Budget for the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. I consider that it is most unfortunate that as a Government once again we find ourselves embroiled with the ABC in yet another funding row. It is also unfortunate that some Ministers have given and are continuing to give the impression that they find the ABC a pain in the neck and an organisation which is not worth supporting. I would like to believe that that is not really the truth, but that certainly is how it is perceived by some people in the community. My own view is that the ABC is an efficient, entertaining, enlivening institution which helps to make Australia one of the foremost democracies in the world. As a democracy there is no doubt that Australia has some shortcomings, as the disadvantaged and the powerless in our community would testify. One thing is certain: the ABC does its best to improve the cultural, intellectual and political life of this nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I know that the honourable member for Fraser agrees with that view because he has said so in the House before. In a recent article in the Sunday Herald the well-known science broadcaster, Robyn Williams, voiced his concerns about the attacks on the ABC. The Sydney Morning Herald and the Australian both attacked the ABC with headlines such as `Time for the ABC to start earning a living'. That appeared in the Australian. It took the Age to defend the ABC by pointing out that it needed financial independence, with the comment that it should not be necessary to remind Australians of the symbolic significance, institutional importance and cultural value of a national and independent broadcasting system. As reported in the Sunday Herald, Robyn Williams said:

SPEECH.PARA: Well, if they don't want an ABC, let them say so. If they want us to dismantle sections of our services, let them be named. If they want us to accept advertising let them legislate for us. What won't work is continually having the floor fall away every few months as supposedly secure budgets collapse.
The article continued:
As ABC director John Cleary pointed out in a letter to The Australian on Thursday, our service has never been cheaper and, I would add, never better.

If Australians really would prefer their current affairs programs presented exclusively by posturing millionaires (sober or otherwise) let them say so. If they really do believe that the same criteria for performance that apply to making hamburgers should apply to national broadcasting-let us know now. The time really has come.

I could not have said that as well as Robyn Williams. He is a distinguished broadcaster and I think we have to be concerned when he has that sort of thing to say. Only about a week before that he said in an interview on the radio that hundreds of professional broadcasters in the ABC are wondering whether it is worthwhile putting in their effort. He said:

We are lean, fast and very efficient and now is the time to build our confidence. The trouble is that the conservatives see us as Pinkos and part of some left wing plot and the ALP see us as just sitting here discussing ballet and pot plants.

Such remarks would be comic if they were not so horribly true. The general feeling amongst ABC staff is one of cynicism tinged with despair and a strong suspicion, as Robyn Williams's previous comments indicated, that the Government is attempting by means of financial stringencies to force the ABC into commercial sponsorship.

I must admit that I share their concerns. Whilst the ABC board continues to reject advertising and commercial sponsorship, the Managing Director for the Special Broadcasting Service (SBS) has not been, I have to say, so reticent. In a recent speech published in Ethnic Spotlight Mr Brian Johns supported such views. I had hoped to quote him but time is getting away from me.

I was pleased to note that in the same June issue of Ethnic Spotlight, which is the newsletter of the Federation of Ethnics Communities Councils of Australia, an article completely refuted the idea that Mr Brian Johns had floated that the SBS should get into commercial sponsorship. Of course it should not get into commercial sponsorship. At least the ABC board has made it very clear that it will not do so and that it will not get into advertising.

In concluding my speech I congratulate Radio Australia, which will shortly reach its fiftieth anniversary. On Tuesday, 20 September 1939, the service in English began with the name `Australia Calling'. This was transmitted to all Australian military personnel in Asia during the war. As the war progressed programs were broadcast in Japanese, Thai, Indonesian and Mandarin. I have a guest listening up in the Gallery. He is an American ex-serviceman and I hope that he too was able to hear this broadcast. Having conveyed my congratulations to Radio Australia I hope that the Government will be able to ensure that it has sufficiently powerful transmitters to broadcast to mainland China. Some of my constituents have complained to me that their Chinese friends are finding it difficult to pick up the programs.
In supporting the Budget I hope the Government will take into account the concerns I have expressed with regard to the funding of the ABC and SBS.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adermann The Hon A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Despite what was stated by the speaker who preceded me, the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton), I want to say at the outset that a nation with a foreign debt of $108 billion is desperately ill. When further investigation reveals that in about seven years that debt has doubled, doubled again and increased about $20 billion above that again we will see that this disease is rampantly moving to destroy the economy totally. A government which presides over a record like that can only be judged to be thoroughly incompetent and totally unable to manage the national economy.

SPEECH.PARA: It is even more reprehensible when the Government denies that we have problems and says that its policies are correct and are beginning to bite, and yet the reality is that the debt is still accelerating. Not all the photographs of the smiling Treasurer (Mr Keating) handing over cheques overseas, allegedly paying off our debt, can cloud the reality of that scenario. It would be bad enough if the Government were willing to accept some small culpability but even when Moody's Investors Service Inc., for the second time in a very short period, has further downgraded our credit rating the Government ignores the disease and attacks the doctor. It seems that we can anticipate a further downgrading of our credit rating almost annually, and this Government blusters and claims that all is well. After all, Moody's is an accredited agency recognised and respected worldwide, and its decision reflects the current judgment of all world authorities on the state of our economy. Others followed them last time and others will follow them this time.

Now, if that does not reveal a sick nation under an incompetent government, let us consider further these facts. The Government has staked all, its entire reputation, on its boast that it has allegedly created a multiplicity of jobs and reduced unemployment. We have heard Government speakers desperately and monotonously repeating this catechism continually throughout this debate. But the Budget Papers themselves contain a plain admission that the monetary and fiscal policies projected will cause unemployment to rise. Further, the Government's totally inept handling of the pilots issue will lead to many thousands more jobs collapsing in the tourist industry and the collapse of many businesses and that is without the accelerator effect in the wider business community where more jobs will be lost. So Labor's mournful song will not be sustainable for much longer.

But that is not all. By deliberate policy the Government has caused interest rates to reach fearsome dimensions. Housing interest rates have shattered completely the great Australian dream. No longer can young or old Australians look forward to owning their own homes. But, even worse, many are losing or being forced to sell their homes because they cannot service their loans any longer. Businesses are contracting-and the collapses will further accelerate because many cannot possibly continue under such awesome service charges. The Government cannot deny that. The Government talks about producing more, and yet by deliberate policy it is destroying all capacity to produce.

If that were not enough, Australia's inflation rate, which the Government has repeatedly boasted is on the way down, is rising and will continue to rise so that our competitiveness is being destroyed. Australia, a great trading nation, is being sabotaged savagely.

We could go on further with that depressing but very real scenario. No matter what economic barometer we employ, our nation is desperately ill-and it is getting worse no matter what yardstick we use. This Government has utterly failed and has proved completely incompetent. So we come to this Budget. This Budget indicates whether the Government has the capacity, the will or the gumption to address our ills. And what does it reveal? Having said last year that our foreign debt would fall, only to see it rapidly rise, the Government throws up its hands and admits that it will rise further. Having told us so positively that inflation would fall, and seeing it rise to almost double the projected figure, it now admits that it will be at least as high-in reality it will be higher-in the 12 months ahead. Having promised that interest rates would fall-remember that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) solemnly predicted that in Perth; he promised it-the Government now says they will have to remain very high well into the future.

What other judgment can one make? What can the world say other than that this Government has given in, that it is lost, that it is incompetent? The arrogance of the Government, the bombast of the Treasurer, the farrago of nonsense we get from Ministers in Question Time are simply further manifestations of the fact that the Government has nothing to say and has no idea at all what to do. The pitiful attempt to buy votes from the pensioners will also fail. The pensioners know that unless our economic illness is cured, they will be the first to suffer and they will suffer the greatest. What an awful mess this Government has created.

Now have a look at the wider spectrum. Our roads are falling to pieces. In a vast country like Australia, so dependent on road transport, the Government has reaped more and more in fuel excise and put less and less back into roads. This Government is doomed to defeat whenever the election comes around. Every home buyer, every small business and every motorist has had enough of them. The pharmacists are in despair and because of the parsimonious treatment and the false economy practised by this Government, many pharmacies will close. The community will suffer; that cannot be denied. What a paradox we have-the heaviest taxing government since the war, the most avaricious money grabbing government in our history and yet our roads are falling to pieces; pharmacies are being forced to close; veterans are being stripped of benefits so that the whole veteran community is up in arms; there is a desperate shortage of aged care, hostel and nursing home accommodation; and young people are being turned away because there are not enough places for them in our tertiary institutions. Surely there can be no plainer evidence that this Government's priorities are all wrong and it must go. We can be certain of one thing-it will be a very long time before the Australian Labor Party is ever again given access to the Treasury bench because memories are long and its economic mismanagement and vandalism will not soon be forgotten.

Yet the Government still treats the people as being stupid. Whilst the tax take, direct and indirect, increases, whilst clawback destroys every reduction almost immediately, whilst inflation causes costs of living to soar and tax receipts to increase, it has the effrontery to try to dupe the Australian people by telling them that it has cut taxes. It has not even begun to give back some of the massive taxes that it has purloined over the years. Nor, surely, do they think the Australian people are so stupid that they do not realise how indexation of indirect taxes and excises is reaping in huge revenues. The Australian people will forgive much. They will forgive the discomfort and sacrifice they perceive to be necessary to get things right. They will cooperate with a government they judge to be honest, equitable and competent. However, the Australian people will not tolerate being treated as fools, misled by spurious promises and repeatedly fed totally unrealistic and specious forecasts. A government-and this Government is one such government-cannot ignore that; if it does it is riding for a fall.

The Government dismisses every unfavourable assessment. It abuses every critic. It denigrates every economic authority which does not suit it and it shows an effrontery and an arrogance the like of which this nation has never seen before. I regret to say that that arrogance is also being exhibited through many of the departments and much of the bureaucracy. Unfortunately, I have to use this debate to illustrate yet another arrogant and inexplicable instance of Australian Taxation Office bureaucracy, of which I have first hand knowledge.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are attacking the Public Service.

—The honourable member had better listen to this and he can tell me if he thinks it is justice. In the early 1980s the Tax Office raised an assessment on a partnership which wrongfully levied tax on what was clearly a capital and not an income transaction. Objections were raised. Years elapsed. The Tax Office just would not answer questions or respond to objections. The assessments, of course, in the meantime had to be paid. That is the usual arrogant and uncooperative behaviour that they mete out-no explanation, no answer, just demands. Finally, after about two years, there was an answer refusing the appeal. One of the partners immediately appealed to the Federal Court of Australia. The Federal Court quickly found clearly against the Tax Office. It upheld that appeal entirely and completely vindicated every representation that the taxpayers and I had been making for years. Furthermore, the Commissioner of Taxation, in writing, has agreed that the circumstances surrounding both the partners are identical.

SPEECH.PARA: But let me tell the House what the Tax Office is doing. It has to accept that judgment in the case of the partner who appealed. For unavoidable reasons, and sad reasons, the other partners, whose appeals had been cursorily dismissed by the Tax Office, were not immediately able to appeal to the Federal Court and later they were told they were too late. They were prevented from appealing. So despite the fact that the court has found the assessment incorrect, has struck it out, despite the fact that the court has said that both partners are in identical situations, the Tax Office says they cannot do anything about it. No matter how wrong the assessment is, despite its having been struck out by the court, the other partners' assessments will not be changed.

If ever there was an immoral decision, an unfair action, a sheltering behind the wording of the Income Tax Act, that is it. A taxpayer had to pay many, many thousands of dollars more than should have been the case. The court has agreed. One partner who appealed is relieved, the others are not. Yet the Tax Office expects respect, honesty and cooperation from taxpayers. All protests have been arrogantly and summarily dismissed. The Commissioner maintains that no matter how unfortunate the matter is, and despite the court's observation, he cannot do anything but grin and bear it and retain the taxes proven to be incorrectly levied. I cannot swallow that. I have respect for the Minister at the table, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand), and I hope that he will make sure that my remarks tonight are seen by the Tax Office. I believe that the Minister is concerned about injustices and I respect him for that. I cannot swallow the Tax Office's answer. I cannot believe that an obvious wrong cannot be rectified. I cannot accept that money which the Tax Office has wrongly levied can be retained. With all the discretion the Commissioner has and has demanded, I find that action unfair, unforgivable and unreasonable.

I do not usually raise such matters in the House, but as every avenue of appeal has been closed and denied, this is now the only forum in which the matter can be exposed. Unfortunately, in all probability, this appeal too will be cursorily dismissed and the answer will be that our hands are tied. But I must make another endeavour to obtain justice and fairness for the family concerned. They are a particularly fine and compassionate family. They are very helpful to others; they would do anything for other people. Their only fault is that they have proved the Tax Office wrong. I suppose, however, it does assist the Government to obtain its so-called Budget surplus.

Let us have a look, in my final minute or two, at that so-called surplus. The Government is boasting about that surplus and claiming kudos. If it had been achieved by good economic management and curbing its spending, it would have earned that kudos. But it has not been. The surplus is an absolute fiddle. Company tax and provisional tax receipts have been brought forward into this financial year. They are being collected early. Other revenues were held over and brought back into this year from last year. Expenditure has been delayed, some for years-as long as, would you believe it, 1995? So although it figures in the Budget Speech, the IOUs are not yet redeemable. Additionally, increased taxation-and do not forget those hidden but savage indirect tax increases-brings in increased revenue.

If out of a fiddle like that a surplus cannot be produced, it would indeed be remarkable. I am encouraged by the determination of the coalition to restructure the taxation system and bring real sustainable cuts in our heavy taxation burden. That will restore some of the hope which has faded under this Government. It will restore some incentive and encouragement which this Government has largely destroyed, and finally it will encourage the saving and self-help which this Government has stifled.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I will make a speech that I have been wanting to make for some years about employment and unemployment. Before I do so I would like to support the remarks of the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton) about the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) and the Special Broadcasting Service. I think it is very important to affirm the excellence of both of those broadcasting systems, the importance of ensuring that they are adequately funded and that they receive the recognition from the wider community which they richly deserve. Anyone who has time to listen to Radio National during the weekend, for example, which is about the only time members of parliament get near a radio, would know what high quality, intellectual material is presented in programs such as The Science Show, the presenter of which was referred to--
—Robyn Williams.

—Robyn Williams, yes. He was referred to by the honourable member in his speech. I think it is important that the ABC knows that there are many people who recognise the enormous value of the contribution it makes to the Australian community.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to speak about employment and unemployment because I think there is no more important contribution that a government can make than to ensure the maximum number of employment opportunities for people in the community. Obviously, it is important that everyone who wants to work has the opportunity to work. In that way the productivity of the community will be maximised. It is also essential that we recognise that there are few experiences more debilitating than the experience of unemployment. Unemployment involves, in a sense, people being told by the rest of the community that they do not want them to work. That is enormously psychologically as well as economically damaging to individuals. It causes a severe loss of confidence, it causes them to lose the capacity to work effectively, and it often leads to a breakdown of families, various forms of addiction, and other kinds of self-destructive activity. It is obviously essential for a responsible government to give top priority to employment creation.

When Labor came to government in 1983 the level of unemployment in the community was 10.2 per cent. That was one of the principal issues that the Australian Labor Party had in mind when the policies for the 1983 election were being prepared. Before that election the Party prepared what was called a national recovery and reconstruction plan. I had the pleasure of doing the first draft of that proposal. It stated:
This program for the recovery and reconstruction of the Australian economy has the dual aims of restoring economic growth and the simultaneous reduction of inflation and unemployment.
The plan made this very bold claim:
By the third year in government Labor would aim to restore economic growth to five per cent and to create at least 500,000 additional jobs.

At the time, people said that that was foolish, that it was extremely over-optimistic, that there was no way that a Labor government could achieve that goal. In fact, not only did we achieve it; we over-achieved it. After 6 1/2 years in government Labor has created 1.5 million jobs-three times the amount promised for the first three years. In fact, Labor has done more than 50 per cent better than the promise it made 6 1/2 years ago. Employment between April 1983 and July 1989-the most recent figures that are available-has increased by 24 per cent, which represents 1.5 million jobs. That growth has occurred in both full time and part time work and among males and females. Full time jobs make up two-thirds of the increase and employment among females makes up 56 per cent of the increase. That is a very important development and a very desirable pattern of employment growth.

During the previous year, 1988-89, employment rose by 5 per cent or 370,000 jobs-quite a remarkable increase. Again, that increase was spread among males and females and full time and part time work. The result, in terms of the reduction in unemployment, is that between April 1983 and July 1989 the number of unemployed people fell by 200,000. There are now 200,000 fewer people unemployed than there were when Labor won government. That is a decrease of 28 per cent. Again, both male and female full time and part time workers have benefited and the unemployment rate has come down by 4 per cent exactly, from 10.1 per cent in April 1983 to 6.1 per cent now. That is an enormous achievement. It is a really quite remarkable achievement, particularly at a time when the participation rate, that is, the proportion of the adult population of working age who are in the work force, has gone up from 67.6 per cent to 63.2 per cent.

That is an enormous increase in the proportion of the adult population of working age who are in the work force. But despite that increase, unemployment is still falling. So that is really quite remarkable. Of course that has been associated with a reduction in the duration of unemployment and also with an improvement in the teenage level of unemployment. Between April 1983 and July 1989 teenage full time employment increased by 33,000. Now that does not sound an enormous number and it is not an enormous number but it reverses a decline which had been under way in the previous 10 years when the number of teenagers who were in full time employment had been steadily falling.
