So it is really quite a remarkable change in trend.

Part of the improvement in employment amongst teenagers is also because an increased proportion of teenagers has been staying on at school and that has contributed to an even greater reduction in unemployment amongst teenagers. The retention rate for people beginning school and completing year 12 has gone up nationally from 36 per cent to 58 per cent. That is an enormously important development not only in terms of the benefit to people who would otherwise be unemployed, but also because of the benefit to the level of education of the whole work force.

These improvements in the labour market have been spread through all States. I note that, for example, in Victoria the level of unemployment is now down to 4.6 per cent which is a great affirmation not only of national policies but also of State policies in Victoria. In my own Territory, the Australian Capital Territory, the unemployment rate is 5.6 per cent-significantly below the national average still-and, in the last year, employment here continued to grow; it grew last year by 5.8 per cent. So those are remarkable achievements.

Now the question is: why did that occur? Of course in large part it occurred because of the accord. It is true that it also was assisted by the benefits to the whole economy from the whole phase of economic growth that has been occurring in the Western world and in East Asia, but without the accord this improvement in employment could not possibly have been as substantial. The accord, which was promised by Labor when it was contesting the March 1983 election campaign, was implemented as soon as Labor won government, and it is a comprehensive, voluntary and equitable prices and incomes policy. It has worked remarkably well, not only because it has assisted in reducing unemployment and increasing employment, but it has done that partly because there has been a substantial decline in real unit labour costs. These really have not been remarked on but they are shown in the Budget Papers.

Between 1982-83-the year in which Labor won government-and 1988-89, which was last year, there was a 12.7 per cent reduction in real unit labour costs. That is partly a reflection of improvements in productivity. It is also partly a reflection of slower growth in wages than some people would like to see-than I would like to see myself, I must say. Nevertheless, it has been one of the key factors in ensuring that there has been an encouragement to employers to continue to employ new workers. That reduction in real unit labour costs has also been associated with a remarkable increase in investment. For the 15 years before 1984, investment in the private sector grew by an average rate of 2.2 per cent a year. For the last five years it has been five times higher; it has grown by 10.8 per cent in each of those years. That is an extraordinary reversal in trend and it is absolutely fundamental to a long term improvement in Australia's growth rates.
To conclude, I would like to note that there is still some way to go.

TALK.START.PARA: —With increases in the social wage.

—That is certainly true and exactly what I want to come to. We still have 6.1 per cent unemployment. As everyone in the Government recognises, that is still unsatisfactory. We are proud of the achievement, but we have further to go. It is important to note that that improvement is expected to continue in the next financial year. Despite the remarks by the honourable member for Fairfax (Mr Adermann), who spoke previously, the Budget Papers show a forecast improvement in employment of 2 1/4 per cent in 1989-90. So, there will be a continuation of the improvement in employment.

SPEECH.PARA: Essential to maintaining the growth in employment and the decline in unemployment is the fact that the accord must be maintained and that is why it is so essential that the Government is firm about the pilots strike. It is important to keep the exchange rate low to contribute to correcting the current account as quickly as possible. We need to minimise interest rates-everyone wants to get them down-and it is important that they come down as quickly as possible so as to encourage new investment. We must maximise our growth of exports and our import replacement-the whole area of industry policy is contributing to that. It is also important that we maximise our expenditure on research in the manufacturing sector and other sectors which will contribute to improvement in productivity.

It is important also that we restore growth in public investment as soon as possible. Private investment has gone up rapidly, but we must move as quickly as we possibly can to increase public investment again because national infrastructure is essential to the growth of national productivity. If it is allowed to decline, it will be very costly to maintain or very costly to renew. We must restore public investment as quickly as possible and we must build up as fast as we can desperately needed public programs. There need to be improvements in hospitals, public housing, education and so on. Finally, we must spend more as soon as we can on employment training programs because they are essential to improving the productivity of the labour force.

To conclude, I will mention some new figures that have come out in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) Employment Outlook which was published just under a month ago. This publication shows figures for expenditure on training programs in all OECD member countries as a percentage of gross domestic product (GDP), as a percentage of national income. I think there is scope for increasing Australian expenditure on training programs. In 1988 we were spending 0.05 per cent of our GDP on labour market training programs for adults. That is really quite a small amount of money. Germany, which is commonly regarded as doing particularly well in this area, spent 0.23 per cent of GDP; that is six times as high a proportion of its GDP. The same sorts of trends can be found in most European countries. For example, Sweden spends 0.51 per cent of GDP on adult training programs. I think there is great scope for us to develop the quality and the breadth of our training programs so that the skills of our labour force are improved and that, too, will contribute to continued employment growth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is regrettable that in a debate on the Budget we are asked to contain our remarks to some 10 minutes when we are really discussing our nation's future and ought to be able to contribute in a significant way. The second point I want to make is that it is a pleasure to follow the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore). He is a thoughtful contributor. I do not agree with a lot of what he had to say, but at least he puts his argument cogently and well. Regrettably, not all government members see things in the same way, and I will offer comments on that in a moment.

SPEECH.PARA: I simply draw attention to the comments of the honourable member for Fraser. I do not think members on this side of the House, particularly in the area of employment, argue that there has not been some marginal improvement in that particular indicator during this Government's tenure. Nor do I argue that there has not been a fall in real unit labour costs as part of the accord. But that is not the question. The question is: is the pace of change that is taking place in Australia fast enough to produce the sorts of gains that are necessary to ensure that this nation retains its place in a competitive world? The real problem that we face is that on the fundamental questions the pace of adjustment is not taking place quickly enough under the policies pursued by this Government, or the Budget which has been presented to the Parliament and which we are discussing now. Anybody who mounts a reasonable argument in a critical way in relation to the Budget finds that he suffers from what I call the `shoot the messenger' syndrome.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will not happen to you.

—No, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) is not here at the moment, but that is the technique which he personifies. We have seen it in relation to one major critic, the international ratings agency, Moody's Investors Service Inc., I suspect mainly for Australian consumption. I do not believe that what the Treasurer has had to say will have any significant impact upon that agency's international reputation or the extent to which those who are guided by its advice will view Australia. There used to be a time when we heard comments which suggested that some other people in the world believed the propaganda that we hear in Australia that we presently have, in this Parliament, the world's greatest Treasurer, but I am afraid that is not the view abroad. From all that I hear, we are fast reaching the stage where we are seen to be a laughing stock internationally.

SPEECH.PARA: I must say that I characterise this Budget in another way. It is one of a large number of Budgets which constitute a lost opportunity for Australia. That is really what it is all about. The Budget was meant to impress the international community by having a large surplus on the Government's own account. The Treasurer's statement about the level of that surplus was intended to forestall a good deal of the criticism that was mounting about the size of the country's overall deficit on its account. The Treasurer frequently tries to blur the distinction. He would have us believe that because the Government has a surplus on its account, we are in some way able to address the fundamental question which this nation faces at this time, and that is the size of the country's debt-the debt that is owed by every one of us. It is debt not yet borrowed necessarily by the Commonwealth Government but debt that has been forced onto State governments and local governments, and accumulated by large companies and others in Australia in the belief that debt is a more appropriate way to raise funds for corporate expansion in Australia than the raising of capital or equity participation.

The Budget does not seek to address the underlying problems that that situation poses for Australia. In statements that have been made by the Opposition shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), the Opposition clearly seeks to address that problem. But the urgency of the problem also fails to be understood. I often explain to people when I try to put economics in simple terms that looking at a nation that is living beyond its means is no different from looking at a family living beyond its means. If a family is to get out of its difficulties when it is living beyond its means it either cuts its cloth, that is, it consumes less and spends less or it increases its income. In the time that it takes to put its affairs in order it may want to borrow some money or it might sell some of its assets.

The short term remedies that this country has been adopting until now have been to sell some of its assets-we talk about that in terms of foreign investment and to borrow money extensively from abroad, and there is a good deal of concern about that. We are hoping to see a turnaround of our nation's own income; in other words, that we will be able to get our income up. But the real problem we face is that while this country has been spending in the order of $1 billion or more each month more than it is able to obtain from exports of its own products, our situation has become progressively worse. In announcements yesterday we found that our net indebtedness as a nation has reached a figure of $108 billion.

The real concern we face is that that situation is not changing. I looked at a small publication produced by the Civic Advance Bank Ltd. The honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) has left us, but he could well have read this publication. The most worrying concern is the statement that I would like to quote because I am aware of so many others which offer this advice. The statement is this:

The upturn in commodity prices since 1987 has underwritten the strength of the $A (recognised as a `commodity currency'). But the rise in commodity prices appears to have run its course-wool prices have recently tumbled following, among other things, the withdrawal of China as a buyer over the past few months. More generally, commodity prices can be expected to fall simply because they have not been higher for several years now, and suppliers have stepped up production to take advantage of those prices. (For example, this year's wool clip is expected to be a bumper, because of the number of farmers who have switched to wool from grain crops.)

The net result of that combination of factors-the high level of current account deficit, rises in interest rates through 1988-89 (impacting with a lag), plus prospective falls in commodity prices (impacting immediately on the $A value of the debt)-is that the net income deficit will continue to grow strongly both this financial year and next.

That must send a shiver down the back of every thinking Australian. The problem is that the steps taken by this Government in this Budget do not address the fundamental problem that this country has as a country that is spending beyond its means.

We have seen creative accounting on the Government's part. My colleague the honourable member for Wentworth pointed this out very clearly in his press statements after the Budget. We saw the Government put up a high surplus on its own account, organised largely because it brought forward certain tax collections into this year; we have seen the proceeds of certain sales brought to account this year rather than last year when they were to be taken; and we have seen profits of the Reserve Bank of Australia held over rather than being brought to account last year and so on.

These are important questions that need to be addressed. In terms of the syndrome that I described earlier-the shoot the messenger syndrome-why is the Treasurer so anxious to shoot the international ratings agency, Moody's? It is because that agency made some very simple points about the Australian debt situation which I have addressed tonight. It has made those statements in the context of the decisions that ought to be taken by the Government in this Budget and to deal with this situation that we face. Moody's press release states:

The factors that Moody's considers crucial to its rating include the following: (1) The government's inability to control excessive domestic demand growth-- (2) insufficient progress in generating additional export-earning capacity and in restructuring industry to achieve productive gains-- and (3) the continued slow pace of structural adjustment, which makes Australia ill-positioned to weather the next downturn in the global business cycle without further large increases in foreign-currency debt.

TALK.START.PARA: —They were all things you did not address when you were in government.

—They are questions we have been addressing every day that we speak on this Budget, every day that we speak about the situation facing this economy-questions which the Government, in office now for some six to seven years, has failed to address.
—You did nothing about any one of them.
—These questions were being addressed--
—Order! The Minister will cease interjecting and the honourable member will address the Chair, not the Minister.

—I thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker, for your assistance and protection. I might say that these questions are fundamental. They have been put before the Australian people by this Opposition over the last six years in the clearest terms. While the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs may want to try to pass the buck in the same way as the Treasurer does, the fact of the matter is that these questions need to be addressed now. Here is another lost opportunity.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to conclude by referring to other points in the press release. It states:

The agency also pointed out that the downgrade reflects several other considerations. The first is the persistence of structural weaknesses embedded in Australia's domestic and international position, such as intransigent rigidities in the local labor market and transport markets. These constrain international competitiveness.

Moreover, the current Labour government has been unable to rein in current domestic demand in an overheated economy, despite the opportunities provided by the recent upswing in the business cycle. The Commonwealth government has achieved a growing fiscal surplus on its own account, Moody's noted, but political and social factors have prevented the application of a total policy mix that is sufficiently rigorous to balance the external account. The government has relied primarily on a tight monetary policy, which has bolstered the Australian dollar thereby, stimulating imports and discouraging exports.

It is interesting that the Government in attempting to deal with the situation has relied on one weapon in its armory: that is called monetary policy. That is a pseudonym to describe high interest rates.

TALK.START.PARA: —We also have a tight fiscal policy.

—The fact is that the Government does not have a fiscal policy that is tight enough. Let me continue in relation to that monetary policy. Even the Government's adviser, the Reserve Bank of Australia, had some comments to make about it. While the Treasurer may be content to try to shoot Moody's, I have not heard from him a detailed commentary on what the Reserve Bank had to say. Implicit in the Reserve Bank's annual report are some of the most damaging comments that could ever be offered about a government's Budget. On page 15 of its report, the Reserve Bank makes it clear in quite unambiguous terms that the Government, which has been setting the pace in terms of interest rate policy for political reasons, sought to slacken off in the early months of 1987. The bank uses these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . As mentioned above, monetary policy is sometimes called `the balancing factor', suggesting some degree of possible trade-offs with other elements of the policy mix. In the early months of 1987, it was judged that fiscal tightening and wage moderation presented the opportunity to lift some of the burden from monetary policy. In the event, the exuberance of markets led to an easing in monetary conditions before the other policies had taken up the slack. In normal circumstances, the effects of this market anticipation might not have been troublesome. However, it coincided with an unforeseen resurgence in demand world-wide and in commodity prices.
The bank concludes:
The experience illustrates a need for great caution in adjusting monetary policy in response to decisions on, rather than the results of, other policies.

What the Reserve Bank is really saying is that the Government, for political reasons, slackened off in relation to monetary policy at a time when it thought its policies were going to achieve the objective, rather than looking at results. What the bank is saying is that if one views the Government's decisions in political terms the Government makes judgments which are not based upon the interests of the Australian people but upon the way in which the Government perceives may assist it. Let me say to honourable members opposite that I do not believe that their management of these issues on this occasion will bring any rewards for the Government whatsoever. This Budget is another lost opportunity; it is falling apart already before our very eyes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bilney Mr G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The previous speaker, the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), characterised the Budget in a certain way. I would prefer to characterise it in a rather different way. It is a no gimmicks, no frills, very honest, straightforward Budget. It is a `what you see is what you get' Budget. It is a Budget which consolidates and carries forward the gains that we have made over the past six years in a variety of fields, for example, in the field of structural economic reform and in the field of employment, which the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore), who has just left the chamber, referred to at some length and in terms with which I fully agree. In particular, it is a compassionate Budget. The gains that we have made in social justice and in bringing about equity in this society are carried forward in this Budget in ways with which I fully agree and which, I believe, will benefit the least advantaged in our society.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition flounders when it tries to attack this Budget, because it is such an honest, straightforward, compassionate document and one which I know will be well received, in particular, in the electorate which I have the honour to represent. The kinds of things that it seeks to ensure-job security, more affordable child care, greater protection for our environment, better security for people who are retired or who are planning their retirement, better community facilities and better sporting facilities-are the kinds of things which electors want to see the Federal Government providing and which this Government, through this Budget, is providing.

Before I address my remarks to those aspects, I want to concentrate on the macro-economic background against which the Budget is framed because, after all, the great responsibility of the Federal Government is to manage the macro-economy. We have to recognise that our policies for promoting growth in the economy have been too successful. Over the last year or so the economy has shown signs of considerable overheating. It is necessary to adopt a macro-economic strategy to bring the level of growth back to one which is more sustainable. If one looks at the forecasts which are contained in the Budget Papers, one will see that, last year, gross national expenditure rose by 7.7 per cent, whereas gross domestic product-output-rose by only 3.3 per cent. The disparity between what we spent and what we produced meant that our imports rose at an unsustainable level, by something like 25 per cent. That led to difficulties with our current account. So the Budget does need to address that situation. It does so explicitly, which will, I believe, lead to the kind of soft landing for the economy which is an important objective to achieve.

Some other indicators were running at unsustainable levels as well. Business investment last year was 15.5 per cent and is forecast in the year to come to be 6 per cent. Spending, as I said, went from 7.7 per cent down to 2 per cent. This is the only responsible policy to follow. When I hear some of the gimmicks and quick fixes which are advocated by some of our opponents-and not just in the coalition parties-I know that that is the primrose path which will lead to disaster for this country and this economy.

In particular, Mr Deputy Speaker, I want to say that this Budget puts in place a strategy which will lead to lower interest rates. The three key elements of the Budget which establish that framework are; first of all, the increase in the surplus to a record $9.1 billion, which of course helps build public savings; secondly, the slow-down in spending, to which I referred earlier; and, thirdly, a gradual improvement through the year in our balance of payments. It is perfectly true that the balance of payments figure will not be turned around rapidly, but as the year goes on, I believe, we will see quite a rapid improvement in it.

I said at the beginning that I wanted to concentrate on certain things which were important to those people whom I represent. First of all, I want to turn to some items within the community services and health portfolio. Foremost amongst those is the further progress made in this Budget towards bringing about more affordable and more widely available child-care. We have already announced our strategy for doubling the number of child-care places provided in Australia by the Government, and this year the initiatives in the Budget focus on affordability and equity. In particular, I was very pleased to see the liberalisation of the fee relief provisions for low income families. Part of that involves the maximum fee up to which the Government is prepared to pay fee relief in child-care centres, which goes up from $90 a week to $92.50 a week. For family day-care schemes, which, I might add, are extremely popular, the figure goes from $65 a week to $68 a week. The income limits for which one is eligible for maximum government benefit for centre-based care go up by $25 so that a family with one child and with a gross weekly income of up to $280 a week will now receive maximum benefit.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is what you have been pushing for in your electorate.

—That is absolutely true. I might add that in my electorate, I believe, there are more government-provided child-care centres than in any other electorate in Australia. There are seven. I have to say in reply to the Minister's remark that I am the envy of a number of my colleagues because of the number of child-care centres which a wise and far-seeing government has built in my electorate. One other thing I should mention is that operational subsidies for child-care centres and family day-care and occasional care schemes are also going to be increased as a result of the initiatives taken in the Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: While I am on the portfolio of community services and health, another aspect which I was particularly pleased to see was the $40m package announced in the Budget to improve women's health. That comprises $33.7m for a new four-year national women's health program in which the States are to share the costs, a $6.5m program to help the State governments establish alternative birthing services, and a program of which I particularly approve, an additional $1.2m over two years to extend breast cancer and cervical screening services-an extremely important reform. These changes arose out of a massive consultation program in which over one million Australian women took part and it is they whose inputs have seen this program developed. The women's health strategy program is something which I particularly commend in this Budget.

Another aspect to which I should like to pay particular attention is housing. My electorate will benefit greatly from the record $1,290m in the Budget for direct housing assistance this year. Of that, there is an additional $15m for mortgage and rent relief schemes. I know that they have not been fully utilised in the past, but we all know that there have been some difficulties there and this will help to address those. As to the first home owners scheme, again my electorate has been a massive beneficiary of that. This year we are expecting to assist an additional 40,000 home buyers to obtain their first home at a cost of $146m. In my own electorate already $12.2m has been approved for families there, of which nearly $11m has in fact been paid out and spent. I am particularly pleased to see that that aspect of housing has been tackled in this Budget.

But as well as that, the needs of the homeless have also received priority treatment. The new supported accommodation assistance program (SAAP) gets $75m for transitional supported accommodation and support services through refuges for youth and for women, and for general services for other homeless people. The funding under the crisis accommodation program for the purchase and renovation of accommodation for SAAP clients is to be doubled to $39m and $10m specifically to meet the needs of homeless youth. In Adelaide there is an extremely sad problem of homeless kids, and I can think of nothing which demands more compassion than a program directed to their needs. Do I have 15 minutes or 10?

TALK.START.PARA: —The time for speaking in the Budget debate is 20 minutes and you have gone for only 12 minutes.

—I realise that time is running short and I will therefore conclude, but I mention just very briefly the massive reforms to retirement incomes which have taken place in this Budget, both for age pensioners and for people on superannuation or planning their retirement. I do not have time to go into the details of those. The environment will receive a 64 per cent increase in funding for the one billion trees program, the save the bush for endangered species program, and so on.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, I mention sport. My own electorate did extremely well out of funding under the community sporting facilities program. Indeed, the Seacliff Tennis Club received $50,000 and the Happy Valley Hockey Club $180,000. There was more funding for those two clubs in my electorate, I point out to the Minister at the table, the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support (Mrs Kelly), than for the entire Northern Territory and Tasmania combined, and possibly one could even add in the Australian Capital Territory. In conclusion, I believe that this is an excellent Budget and I commend it to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened with a great deal of interest to the speech of the honourable member for Kingston (Mr Bilney). I felt quite flabbergasted at the amount of money that he said he has been able to achieve for his electorate when it seems to me to be quite a safe seat for him. I just wanted to make that point. The other point I want to make, Mr Deputy Speaker, is that as you rightly pointed out we have 20 minutes in which to make our comments on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1989-90 and on the Budget. We have agreed to cut that short by half. Unfortunately, I have had to cut my speech in half. Half of it was going to say good things about the Budget and the different Ministers, particularly the Minister at the table, the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support (Mrs Kelly). That came in the second half of my speech so I will have to leave it all out.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to focus on four themes in my comments tonight on the Appropriation Bill and on the Budget. They are: firstly, our national foundation; secondly, our national viability; thirdly, our national security; and finally, our national generosity. When I refer to our national foundation I refer to the family-an institution which is fundamental to the well-being of any society. It is an institution which is under unprecedented social and economic pressures in Australia as we approach the twenty-first century.

The 1989 Budget was quite simply a council of despair for the average family. The bottom line of the Budget was that record mortgage payments and continuing price rises of basics such as food, clothing and transport, are going to continue for the indefinite future. The coalition has been claiming for some time now that the Government is out of touch with the problems of average families. If ever there was clear confirmation of that claim it was the 1989-90 Budget, devoid as it was of any short, medium or long term solution to the pressures on the family. Let me make it quite clear that average families have borne the brunt of this Government's mismanagement.

Two days ago the Australian carried a headline on page 2 which said `Families fall into mortgage arrears'. The article reported a 10 per cent increase in home loan arrears in July this year. It warned of a crunch period during September and October this year when `people who have been battling on in the hope of lower interest rates will start to fall over'. It notes a forecast that mortgage repayments will rise to a record 71 per cent of average weekly earnings by the end of this year. That report reflects the reality that Australian couples are being left with no choice but to be a double income family. It reflects the reality that more and more families are collapsing under the pressure of the Government's policies, determined as it is to ensure that individual families slip into debt and bankruptcy at the same rate as does the country. What happens when a government subverts the foundational institute of a society? We get rising family separation, rising educational difficulties, rising drug and mental health problems, rising homelessness, a blow-out in welfare and welfare dependency and a decaying individual and social morality.

The focus of this Appropriation Bill should have been the restoration and nurturing of the family, chiefly by attacking the key economic problems besetting the family, that is, interest rates and inflation that we all know about so well. It is also important to note the continuing imbalance against the prevention of family break-up in favour of post break-up welfare support. In spite of minor increases, funding for marriage education and counselling compared to welfare allocated after divorce is farcical. Of the $100m allocated to tackle youth homelessness only $5.5m will go towards family mediation to prevent homelessness occurring amongst young people. It is putting the cart before the horse. We should consider the freely available abortion procedures and subsidisation compared to the totally inadequate pregnancy counselling and support systems that we have at the moment. The Government stands condemned for the neglect of this family policy focus in the 1989-90 Budget.

I turn to my second point of focus-the national viability. On the same page as the article in the Australian I referred to earlier was the headline `Inflation, interest rates hit exports'. The article reported on a warning-yet another one-to the Government that high interest rates and inflation were destroying our economy, in this instance by creating serious problems for exporters by increasing costs and reducing prices. The warning came in a report from a committee which reviewed Australia's export assistance programs. The report stressed, as the coalition has been saying for so long now, that a predominantly monetary policy approach, such as interest rates, is too blunt an instrument to fix this economy. It called for a better balance of fiscal and wages policies to encourage higher levels of productivity and living standards-the very themes stressed by the leader of the coalition in his Budget response.

It has been a dominant criticism of the Budget by all commentators that it failed to take positive action to tackle this country's growing foreign debt, our continuing current account deficits, our workplace productivity problems and our failed industry policies. It is increasingly obvious, here and overseas, as our new AA2 credit rating has revealed, that the viability of Australia in a competitive global economy is seriously in doubt. The reality is that we are in a worse situation than when the Treasurer (Mr Keating) rang out his banana republic warning, yet the Budget pretends that all is well. As a result, Australia is sliding gradually into the company of Third World nations. Our economic viability is in doubt. Our children are set to inherit a country sent bankrupt over a single period of government from 1983 to 1989.

As is the case so often, the Government has limited the debate on the Budget, so, as I said at the outset, I must be brief. I turn to my third theme-national security. Commentators and analysts of international relations have increasingly agreed that Australia's regional security position will be less certain and more precarious by the turn of this century than at any time in our history apart from World War II. What is the position of the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) in this year's Budget in this particular context? Our defence budget has been allocated its lowest level of expenditure as a percentage of gross domestic product in nearly 40 years. That means that the morale crisis in the Services will continue to put our operational capabilities in question and new equipment purchases and integration will be deferred and stretched over even longer periods. Again it will be our children who will suffer from the short-sightedness which constrains defence expenditure and which characterises the 1989-90 Budget as a whole.

I turn to my last area of concern-foreign aid, or our national generosity. As serious as our social, economic and security situation has become under the trio of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Treasurer, and Mr Crean-the unseen but ever-present third power in this Government-Australia is still a relatively fortunate country. As such, and given the suffering of people in what we call the Third World, I believe we have an obligation to share our resources overseas. Under this Government, and with this Budget, overseas aid has declined from 0.56 per cent of gross national product in the last year of the Fraser Government to a shameful 0.33 per cent of GNP for the coming year.

Let me indicate the nature of the choices this Government made concerning overseas aid and competing Budget demands by looking at funding for the United Nations Children's Emergency Fund (UNICEF), one of the few United Nations areas that I feel confident of supporting. On 30 May this year I asked the Prime Minister in the House whether his Government would increase UNICEF funding from a mere $3.3m to a mere $7m within an overall increase for our overseas aid budget. The Prime Minister indicated that he, like all of us, would place a tick beside that proposal if fiscal circumstances allowed. The Government brought down a Budget with a $9 billion surplus. Fiscal circumstances allowed for a $44m boost for sport in Australia. How did UNICEF fair? Its grant was lifted from $3.3m to $3.4m, notwithstanding a direct request on UNICEF's behalf for a doubling of the grant by Ken Done, UNICEF Australia's goodwill ambassador, and notwithstanding the Prime Minister's answer on 30 May. If the grant had been doubled it would have amounted to the equivalent of one cent per Australian per week.

I think the failure to increase the UNICEF grant substantially typifies the way overseas aid has been dealt with under this Government. The Prime Minister cut overseas aid in real terms in the 1985-86 Budget by 4.8 per cent. He cut it by 11.9 per cent in the 1986-87 Budget and he cut it by 2.8 per cent in the 1987-88 Budget. He gave some funding back with a 7.4 per cent increase in the 1988-89 Budget. This year he took that back with a further cut of 8.4 per cent.

This Budget, as I have said, failed Australian families. This Budget ignored growing doubts here and overseas about Australia's future living standards and economic viability. This Budget deferred action to lift our defence capabilities to adequate levels. The most shameful aspect of the Budget with a $9 billion surplus was its savage cut to overseas aid. I say to this House: under the Government our priorities are all wrong and this Budget betrays the Government's lack of wisdom and direction. If ever we needed proof that Australia needs a change of government, the 1989 Budget is that proof.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe Mr N.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —When discussing an Appropriation Bill with the breadth of this one and the range of issues that one could turn to, a contribution could go on for hours. I intend to limit myself to three particular areas which I think are extremely significant. The first one is the measures that are included in this Budget relating to mortgage relief and rent relief for people who may need assistance during these periods of relatively high interest rates. I say `relatively high interest rates' because I remember that before I was elected to this Parliament in 1984 interest rates in the market place were in fact higher than they are now-mortgage rates not, certainly; but the cocktail mix being offered by the banks to people was certainly at these levels.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact of the matter is that for some years now our economy has been having to learn to adjust to a high interest rate regime while we redress our balance of payments problems. During that period we have seen a record number of young Australian families enter new homes, to the extent that at this point there are something like 170,000 new home starts on the agenda for this financial year and that is a rate which is far ahead of the capacity of the building industry to sustain. It has led to inflationary trends being fuelled within that industry and it is, I think everyone will accept, the accelerator industry of our domestic economy. Therefore, the maintenance of high interest rates is needed, particularly in this sector. But it has to be done with sensitivity and it has to be done with a sense of priority. I think that this Budget contains both those measures and in very large doses.

It contains sensitivity, in that the Government has put in place via the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement and via the mortgage and rent relief packages which are being negotiated with the state governments, a very generous safety net. I saw a newspaper article yesterday referring to a massive $15m which has been allocated to ensure that no family will need to look at giving up the home because of the interest rate burden. There is scope there for an approach to the State authorities administering the rent relief and mortgage relief schemes to ensure that that safety net is in place. As one of the Government back bench members who focused attention on this question of sensitivity, I appreciate the consideration that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and other members of the Expenditure Review Committee gave to showing that sensitivity and providing a safety net in the Budget.

Another key feature in the housing industry is the recognition of the role that the industry plays in our economy and the measures that are there to ensure the industry is sustained during the inevitable slowing down of private sector construction and demand which will follow both the interest rate measures and a winding back from excessive levels of construction. Built into the package is a massive amount-$1,290m, almost $1.3 billion-for direct housing assistance via the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. That represents an increase of 35 per cent over the last financial year. It is intended to increase and improve the quality of public rental housing and to expand home purchase assistance schemes which are available via the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement.

Recently the Victorian State Government announced a new package called the equity share concept. Under that package home buyers who are not able to meet the full cost of a mortgage from their current wage are able to enter into a partnership arrangement with the State Government and buy a house on an equity share basis. Such funding makes that kind of innovation available. It is to be commended because families which otherwise might be restricted to renting will receive assistance so that later on, when the opportunity arises to buy out the other share-in other words, the Government's share-and their family and financial circumstances allow them to do so, they will be able to get into homes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the government share appreciate?

—No, the government share does not appreciate. The government share is locked in at the time of the contract and the ratio varies from 20 per cent to 80 per cent. The Victorian Government has introduced a very innovative and commendable program and I am glad to see it. It is vital to recognise the role that the industry plays in our domestic economy. We must all understand that housing-a roof over our head-is a basic right of all Australians. Recently reports have highlighted shortcomings in Australia's approach to housing. The widely known Burdekin report entitled Our Homeless Children pointed to a particular area of concern at the moment-that is, youth accommodation. I am pleased to see that there have been substantial allocations in the Federal Budget and in State Budgets to ensure that real priority is given to crisis accommodation and other forms of youth accommodation. That is to be commended.

SPEECH.PARA: I will now move on to the question of superannuation and retirement incomes. If the Budget is to be marked for anything it is for its restoration of the concept of national superannuation. I regard it as light on the hill stuff. The last time that Australia seriously committed itself to a form of national superannuation was in the late 1940s when the Chifley Government proposed that everybody ought to contribute to a pension package. This was widely accepted and well regarded. Of course, since then successive governments have retreated from that notion. The concept of national superannuation as envisaged by Chifley fell apart. We reached a point by the late 1980s when only a third of the Australian work force was contributing to superannuation-it was predominantly an area for the privileged. Although there was scope for people to take out private life insurance and other sorts of insurance packages, obviously the system was not working and there was a dearth of people making provision for their retirement.

The ruling off of the line in 1983 in respect of the assets test was the start of a reform program which will, in the future, be looked upon and seen as a very dramatic shift not only in the attitude to providing for one's retirement but also in the approach to savings investment in this economy. We have now reached the situation where, via the wage-tax trade-off, the productivity agreements and the changing of the wages system, all employees have access to employer-funded superannuation. This Budget makes further provision in respect of this trend which will continue to develop.

Radical steps have been taken in this Budget and in measures announced during April to bring the pension system in line with the tax system and to remove the confusion faced by so many pensioners. All of those steps are not only administrative tidying-up measures but also very real advances in social justice in this country. I am very pleased to support them and I feel that I have taken part in the development process.

The other part of the superannuation equation is national savings. Over a number of years, and particularly in recent times, a lot has been said about national savings. It has often been overlooked that Australians are prolific savers. It is often said that there is no incentive to save in this country. That is absolute rubbish. Australians generally choose to save in the form of bricks and mortar. They set off very early in their working lives with the goal of acquiring a house and land and they pour enormous amounts of their weekly wages into achieving that goal. They see this significant savings approach as a form of long term security.

There is now the incentive to get into and to stay in superannuation. It is predicted that within five years $60 billion per annum-I repeat, $60 billion per annum-will be saved by Australians through their superannuation funds. What is going to happen to that money? As a result of changes to the tax system, which discourage superannuation funds going offshore and investing money in all sorts of unproductive speculative stuff, real incentives now exist in the system which will encourage those superannuation funds to invest the money locally in productive Australian enterprise. Of course, that means a future not only for people working at the moment and saving for their retirement but also for their children. The Australian economy, based on a savings and investment culture, with proper recognition being given to research and development and the need to find a place at the top end of the market, will be adequately resourced from domestic savings without the ever-growing reliance on foreign investment capital which has obtained in this country. I think that is a landmark reform by this Government.
Just to wind up, I know my time is finished but I cannot pass up this first opportunity to congratulate you, Mr Speaker, on your election. I welcome you to the chair.
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Pharmacy Services-Uranium-Gulson Family: Land Donation-Greenhouse Effect-X-Rated Videos

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —May I also add my congratulations, Mr Speaker, on your ascendancy to the throne. Last evening and earlier today in this place we heard a number of my colleagues on this side of the House highlight the potentially traumatic effect of last Monday's determination by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal. Many of us have read also the professional advice of the honourable member for Streeton (Mr Lamb) that the Tribunal was out of touch and that the Government needed to work out a new system of remuneration. Some of us also heard the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples) give a very superficial and, in my view, inadequate defence of that determination in this place last evening and during Question Time again today.

SPEECH.PARA: I therefore take the opportunity to reiterate the views expressed earlier by my colleagues and those of the Pharmacy Guild of Australia. The Executive Director of the Guild, Mr Robert Davies, has made it clear that there is no way that pharmacies can absorb the cuts resulting from the determination and that the determination is, and I quote in part, `disastrous for the community in terms of the ability of pharmacies to service it . . . virtually all of Australia's 5,600 pharmacies are affected and could result in staff cuts'. In a news release the National President of the Guild, Mr Jim Matthews, uses harsher words in his assessment:
Today's determination . . . means the end of community pharmacy services in Australia as we know them.
This decision is an outrage against the community. The Government is responsible because it urged the Tribunal to take this course.
`It is totally deplorable that the health, wellbeing and security of the public should be treated so recklessly.
`The decision means that a great many pharmacies including smaller pharmacies in country towns and outer suburbs will close.
`Most others will not be able to maintain the level of pharmacy stocks, and patients will have to wait in some cases for days for higher cost drugs to be delivered by wholesalers.
The Tribunal's decision is based on a flawed and discredited survey . . . The Tribunal itself questioned the quality of the result achieved'.
`The Tribunal proposes yet a further Inquiry into the structure of pharmacy. This is a cruel joke, as there will be virtually no community pharmacy left to inquire into . . .

That is understandably emotive comment but telephone comments from pharmacists in my electorate today reflect these strong, albeit very pragmatic, views. Clearly the likely consequences will be the curtailment of many of the services which pharmacists currently offer and the closure of even more pharmacies, leaving pensioners and families with children in particular without ready access to the professional services of a local pharmacy. I find it very difficult to reconcile a situation whereby the tribunal is cutting pharmacy incomes by over 20 per cent on top of real cuts of over 10 per cent imposed by the Government in 1988. Pharmacists are not asking for charity; all they want is a fair go in what is a fiercely competitive environment. They simply want to operate on a level playing field.

I agree entirely with what the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack) said in this place today, namely, that what is needed is a meaningful partnership between government and the pharmacists in which a two-way dialogue is a critical ingredient and in which there must be avoidance of the `we and they' mentality. On the latter point, it seems that the Government has failed badly. However, I am encouraged to hear the Minister say today that a meeting of all parties is scheduled for tomorrow to resolve the very real differences of view. The Tribunal's recommendations may save the Government $20m. While this side of the House would endorse substantive economies in the public sector-something, I regret to say, which is lacking in the Budget Papers of the Treasurer (Mr Keating)-such economies should not, as they do here, force many pharmacies to the financial wall and, most importantly, should not threaten public health standards.

Community pharmacies are now fighting for their survival. I hope that the Minister and the parties can come to a reasoned and reasonable accommodation tomorrow. Clearly what is needed in everyone's interest is a more objective fair go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to take the opportunity to congratulate you, Mr Speaker, on your election to the office of Speaker. I wish you well in your new high office. I wish first to express my surprise at and disappointment with the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran). On Thursday, 17 August, in the adjournment debate the honourable member made some inaccurate and, I have to say, offensive remarks about me, the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr John Scott) and the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent). He referred to us as lunatics, having earlier inaccurately used such words as `insanity', `illogical' and `hurtful'. Honourable members may be wondering what terrible crime we had perpetrated to warrant such strong language. Indeed, with regard to the use of the word `lunatic', I was disappointed that the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher), who was in the chair at the time, did not call on the honourable member to withdraw, because he was obviously using unparliamentary language. Sadly, the honourable member for Gippsland also failed to warn me that he proposed to malign me and the other members, as is the usual courtesy in this House. Needless to say, I tried this evening to contact the honourable member for Gippsland to tell him I would speak, but I was unable to contact him by telephone or in any other way, so I am not quite sure where he is at present. I wanted to criticise him for his use of what I considered-as, I am sure, would the House-intemperate and excitable language and to point out how his arguments were inaccurate and illogical.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason for his excitable outburst-some might say it was a hysterical outburst, but I would not go as far as that-was the Australian Labor Party's uranium policy, which restricts the mining of uranium to three named mines: Ranger, Nabarlek and Roxby Downs. Nabarlek is virtually mined out, so for all practical purposes it is now a two-mine policy. Contrary to the honourable member's opinions, the majority of Labor Party parliamentarians in the House and the Senate support the existing policy, although some do not quite agree with it. At present, it is under review, but in view of the overwhelming opinion as expressed in the hundreds of submissions received by the review committee, of which I am a member, it is highly unlikely that the policy will be changed to include more mines. If anything, there could be less mining of uranium than at present. I am able to make such a forecast not only because of the ideological and environmental objections to the nuclear fuel cycle but also because it just is not economic sense to open up new uranium mines in Australia. The infrastructure to support such mines is very expensive and it often results in the use of taxpayers' funds in one way or another. Even more importantly, the supply of and demand for uranium on world markets means that Australia cannot increase its exports of uranium. This is something that the honourable member for Gippsland seems totally incapable of understanding. I refer him to an article which appeared just recently, on 18 August 1989, in the Age. Other articles in the Australian Financial Review and the Australian bear out the same kinds of comments. The fact remains that the price of uranium on the world markets is falling. It is falling because there is an excess of supply over demand.

I am very glad to see that the honourable member for Gippsland has now entered the chamber. It is good that he is here to hear what I have to say. As I said before, the honourable member was not courteous enough to tell me that he was going to call me a lunatic. I hope he will withdraw that remark very shortly. The honourable member also completely fails to understand that there is an oversupply of uranium on the world markets which means that, if we were to open up another mine or more mines, the existing mines would sell less uranium. Overall, Australia cannot increase the profits it gains from uranium exports. I hope the honourable member now understands this and at least will acknowledge it when he has the opportunity to reply.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, may I join other members who have congratulated you on your election to the position of Speaker of this House.
—Oh, don't bother.
—If the honourable member for Gippsland has come into the chamber to interject, he might not be here for too long.

—I rise tonight to pay recognition to a most generous act of charity by a well-known family in the Goulburn district, the Gulson family. The Gulson family has been an integral part of the life of Goulburn and, indeed, the development of that city, over several generations. The present head of the family, Mr Jeff Gulson, last week made a tremendous gesture by donating five acres of prime real estate in the city of Goulburn to the Royal Freemasons Benevolent Institute for the purpose of building a retirement complex in the city of Goulburn.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members may be interested to know that Goulburn is seriously under-serviced by retirement facilities. We are in urgent need of more self-contained hostel units and also nursing home accommodation. There has been a substantial hurdle to the development of these facilities because, despite the fact that the Royal Freemasons Benevolent Institute has been prepared to proceed with the construction and administration of such a facility for the last seven or eight years, it has not been able to proceed beyond the starting post because it has not been able to acquire appropriate land for the purpose. Last week Mr Jeff Gulson made a decision relatively quickly, having heard an interview on radio station 2GN in Goulburn, and also having read an article in Goulburn's local paper, about the land that he was preparing for subdivision into 20 blocks. I understand that plans for that subdivision had been prepared for council approval. He decided to forgo what was quite obviously a large amount of money for him and his family and to donate that land at no cost to the citizens of Goulburn, for the purposes of ensuring that the elderly of the city of Goulburn have an adequate and proper facility for their care in the future.

An exciting spin-off of which Mr Gulson may not have been aware at the time of his donation is that, using Goulburn as a central point, we may be able to establish branches of this new facility in other smaller centres such as Boorowa and Gunning which have no such facilities at present and in which there will be an obvious need in the future. It is terribly important for country people, as they grow older, to be able to retire in their home towns. It is important because it keeps them in close contact with their friends, families, and the environs with which they are familiar. The prospects of people who live in places such as Boorowa and Gunning being able to retire in their home town are very slim. Indeed, most of those people have to move to other towns which are not as accessible to their friends and families and whose environment is unfamiliar to them.

What Mr Gulson and his family have been able to do extends beyond the environs of Goulburn to places like Boorowa and Gunning. I believe the generosity of the Gulson family serves as an example for all citizens of Goulburn and extends the good reputation of the Gulson family that has existed for many generations. It ensures that the Gulson family will be highly regarded for a long time. As residents of Goulburn grow older, we will owe the Gulson family a great debt for which we are forever thankful.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I too would like to congratulate you on your appointment. Tonight I want to talk about the emotional hysteria involving the environmental movement. I think it is extremely dangerous to the environment and will be counterproductive if it is not refuted. I believe the media have a lot to answer for in this regard.

SPEECH.PARA: As a starting point I will take the greenhouse effect. I have been talking about the greenhouse effect for over 10 years-true, I admit, in order to promote uranium, which is a far cleaner source of energy than other fuels. I say in passing that I think it was very churlish of the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) to refer to three of my colleagues as idiots when it is quite clear that it is the policy, not the members, that is idiotic. He was dealing with the three-mine policy, of course.

TALK.START.PARA: —A very subtle difference.

—I am a very subtle person, which I thought would have been evident. When we talk about the greenhouse effect, I note that in the last three months the media have run a multitude of stories, most of them emotionally based. In the previous 30 years there had not been a word from the media on this very obvious issue. The danger is that people become jaded. We will find that people will simply say `This is terrible, it will not happen', and they will lose interest. This is a very real problem, but it is a problem we cannot panic about because we simply do not know.

SPEECH.PARA: I invested $90-odd in a 2 1/2-inch document by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) on the greenhouse effect. While going to London at Christmas I took the opportunity to read it. I found it a thoroughly boring document and it took a lot to wade through it, but I am sure honourable members will give me recognition for my tenacity. The CSIRO says quite clearly that it simply does not know what the effects are; we do not know where we are going with it. It may be that rising carbon dioxide levels are masking a cyclic return to an ice age. If that is so, in a few years time we could be saying, `More carbon dioxide'.

I believe we should operate with extreme caution and that we should be looking to reduce the carbon dioxide output. To do that we must embrace nuclear energy. It is simply nonsense to talk about alternatives because they do not exist. I have been involved in holding patents, which have since lapsed, in the solar energy field. I have taken a big interest in solar energy; I venture to say that I probably know as much about it as anyone in this House. It will not supply the brute power that is needed for industry, but there is a growing place for it and I believe that the price of solar energy is coming down quite rapidly.

If we maintain this illogical position of opposing nuclear energy, the public will simply see through it and the whole movement will tend to lose its credibility. There is a similar situation with the environmental movement not giving enough recognition to the environmentally sensitive proposals of the Western Australian Government to plant trees. The Western Australian Government has a proposal which will see a minimum of two hundred million trees planted, half of them in the private sector. It is true that in the private sector these trees will be mainly eucalyptus globulus. The reason for that is that they are quick maturing and give the necessary cash flow to make the scheme attractive for the private sector. It is very beneficial when we are returning what is now farm land-it used to be timber country-back to forest. Work is also being done in Western Australia by at least one person in agro-forestry. He believes he can demonstrate that there can be a better return from running eucalyptus globulus and emus. This is pioneering work and is very important. It is terribly disappointing to hear the emotional outbursts from the pseudo-environmentalists who really do not understand the situation.

I want to take some time to debunk the work of Keepin and Catts. These two gentlemen, operating from the Rocky Mountains Institute, have put forward a paper purporting to show that nuclear energy is not the answer. No-one suggests that it is the entire answer, but it is certainly a contributing factor. For them to say that nuclear energy affects only about 12 1/2 per cent of electricity use is absurd. I can tell honourable members that in a very short time the public will be demanding that politicians take note of percentages of power far smaller than that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I have not had the opportunity to congratulate you on your fine step up to the Chair, and I do so now. Somebody has said that the Government could well find that its scrap with the pilots is small feed compared with the fight it will have on its hands from the brutal savaging of the services provided by over 5,000 community pharmacies. To trace some of the history, in 1988 the Hawke Government imposed real cuts of 12 per cent, and these cuts, along with the proposed 23 per cent cut, combine to give a substantial amount of 35 per cent. It is a very severe cut that nobody should be asked to cope with. It is quite obvious that pharmacists have been singled out for punitive treatment from this Government. Clearly the Government has no interest in the well-being and livelihood of the profession. I am sure honourable members opposite will be the first, if they fall ill and require medicines, to rush off to the pharmacists.

SPEECH.PARA: The chain reactions that will undoubtedly result from this proposal will move into every facet of the medical industry. Charges will increase in certain areas to compensate for losses in others, and this is something that we really cannot allow to happen in this industry which is so well established and serving the community so well. How can the Hawke Government-maybe I will get some answers from the other side of the House-justify that a proprietor pharmacist is only worth $15 an hour, an amount considerably less than that of any tradesperson-and I am not casting any aspersions on any tradespersons. In comparison to Government pharmacists it is less than half their hourly rate. Again, by what means is this decision justified?

TALK.START.PARA: —Ask the Tribunal.

—Pharmacists run a very customer-oriented community service business, and the honourable member for Streeton would be only too glad to agree with that. Their particular profession is of such importance to the health of all consumers. What the Government seems to forget is that when rural and outer urban pharmacies are closed, which will inevitably happen if these cuts go ahead, consumers will experience difficulties in obtaining very important prescriptions, particularly elderly consumers who will have to catch buses and trains in my electorate to go to the pharmacies which will be left operating.
—From Blaxland and Glenbrook.
—Yes, the honourable member for Farrer would know very well about that. The Remuneration Tribunal states:

SPEECH.PARA: The result has not been reached without regard to the consequences which are likely to follow--

That makes us wonder just what repercussions the Government envisaged it would encounter. In reality, it has only just hit the tip of the iceberg. Pharmacists are not asking for charity; far from it. All they want, and rightly deserve, is a fair go in a fiercely competitive environment. The blase attitude of the Government today towards pharmacists cannot be allowed to continue in this way. According to the President of the Pharmaceutical Society of Australia, Mr John Ware, up to one-third of Australia's pharmacists could go out of business as a result of this decision. Mr Ware added that many pharmacists are already struggling as a result of Federal Government moves, and this latest blow will send many to the wall.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the Tribunal. Why do you hate chemists?

—The Government is hiding behind the Tribunal. In actual fact, the Government is responsible for these decisions and will have to answer to the Australian people if the sad event occurs that the pharmacists begin to take action.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to say, in conclusion, that the Tribunal recommended that a special inquiry be initiated to consider the restructuring of pharmacy outlets aimed at achieving greater efficiency and reduced costs of dispensing. Surely this should have been implemented before the Tribunal made its decisions. Of course, closing the stable door after the horse has gone is of no use to anybody. My sympathies lie very much with the pharmacists.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johns Mr G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to state my views on the question of X-rated videos. The reason I do so is that I am a little angered and sick and tired of those who seek to misrepresent the whole debate on X-rated videos. I want to refer to a report of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material. It is clear to me that we should have a classification of censorship called non-violent erotica (NVE). The single most common problem with X-rated videos is that so few people actually know what they contain. This renders it particularly prone to misunderstanding and/or misrepresentation. Non-violent erotica is a self-explanatory term which is almost impossible to misunderstand; hence the concern on the part of opponents of sexually explicit material. If the NVE category is approved, they will not be able to misrepresent its contents to ordinary people. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table of classifications in Australia.
—You have not shown it to the Opposition, which you should do as a matter of courtesy.

—Let me state my views on the matter. Every Australian adult should have the right to read and see anything that he or she likes, except in circumstances where its propensity to cause harm has been demonstrated. None of the expert and documented sociological evidence presented to the Joint Select Committee on Video Material indicated that there was a causal link between non-violent erotica and any antisocial activity on the part of the normal viewer of such material.
—Leave was granted to table the document. The honourable member cannot incorporate it, as it is not a table.

—Thank you, Mr Speaker. On the question of sexual therapy, it is worth noting that the Committee received evidence to the effect that material depicting explicit sexual activity between consenting adults was often used as a therapeutic remedial aid in the treatment of sex offenders and the perpetrators of violent sexual crimes. In fact, the material that such people prefer to view in order to attain sexual arousal is usually of the violent, not necessarily sexual, variety.

SPEECH.PARA: Non-violent erotica does not debase women any more than it debases men. Women are not shown in subjugated roles; on the contrary, their consent is obvious and mutual sexual stimulation and enjoyment are a feature of this type of material. Videos depicting rape, sado-masochistic or other deviant sexual behaviour are illegal in Australia. Neither X-rated nor NVE videos contain such material.

The wish to protect children from seeing X-rated or NVE-rated video material is acknowledged. However, parental prerogative, not parliamentary prerogative, must prevail in the home. Society deems parents capable of protecting their children from cigarettes, alcohol, firearms and the like.Why would it distrust them on videos? The very people who demand that parents should be responsible for educating their children on sex are those who are now claiming that they are incapable of protecting them from videos depicting sex. Children are not depicted in any X-rated material at present, nor would they be in the non-violent erotica category. The possession or manufacture of child pornography is illegal in Australia.

On the question of artistic value, the suggestion that sexually explicit videos should be banned because they have no artistic merit is a furphy on two counts. The first is that some examples of non-violent erotica do have some artistic merit and are well produced. The second is that society does not ban for that reason alone other types of videos or programs which have no artistic merit. I would suggest that most soap operas on commercial television would be banned on those grounds.

As a political perspective, the banning of non-violent erotica is not a popular issue. Most people are not worried about explicit sexual material that contains no violence or compulsion. The political heat in the debate, to the degree that there is any, is generated by a deliberate campaign of misinformation combined with ignorance of what the current X category actually contains. I might say that Attorneys-General in Labor States have all received the correct information. Either they are choosing to ignore it because they perceive some political advantage in censorship of X-rated videos, or they genuinely believe that the X rating includes material which depicts violence, bestiality and so forth. The question of enforcement seems impossible to me. Banning X-rated videos is impossible to police.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Shack Mr P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 22 August 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are Commonwealth public servants who use their own vehicles on official business and receive an appropriate allowance, not required to meet the substantiation provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

(2) Why has the Australian Taxation Office indicated to the Western Australian Treasury that public servants in that State who receive an allowance for using their own vehicles on official business will now have to meet the substantiation provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act in respect of allowances paid under the Public Service Motor Vehicle Allowances Consolidated Award 1986.

(3) Will he take action to ensure that all States, Territory and Commonwealth public servants using their own vehicles on official business and being paid an appropriate allowance are treated equally in relation to the handling of such allowances for taxation purposes.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Commonwealth public servants are subject to the same substantiation rules as State public servants and all other taxpayers.

(2) The substantiation rules contained in the taxation law do not require an employee who is reimbursed under an industrial award for car expenses on a rate-per-kilometre basis to substantiate claims for car expenses where the award rate has not increased since 29 October 1986. The Public Service Motor Vehicle Allowances Consolidated Award 1986, which applies to Western Australian State public servants was, subsequent to 29 October 1986 varied to increase the rate of reimbursement. As such State public servants who receive reimbursement under this award are required to abide by the substantiation rules in respect of tax deductions claimed against amounts reimbursed. All employees in similar circumstances have the same obligations. The Commissioner of Taxation has told me that the Western Australian Treasury has been advised of the need for public servants in that State to substantiate claims for income tax deductions against car expense reimbursements paid on a rate-per-kilometre basis.

(3) The Commissioner of Taxation has told me that there are no differences in the application of the substantiation rules between State, Territory and Commonwealth public servants and other taxpayers.
