QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support, upon notice, on 28 February 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How does the Mitsubishi MU-2 crash and incident record compare with other similar aircraft both in Australia and world-wide.
(2) Is the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) aware of all of the known and potential problems associated with the operation of the Mitsubishi MU-2, including the auto-pilot problems.
(3) Will she list all Mitsubishi crashes in Australia since its introduction, including the causes of those crashes.
(4) Is the CAA satisfied that it has done everything possible to ensure the integrity of safe flight operations of the Mitsubishi MU-2.
(5) Was the particular aspect of auto-pilot electrical interference in the MU-2 examined in sufficient detail at the time of certification in Australia; if not, why not.
(6) What action does the CAA intend to take to prevent future accidents involving the MU-2 in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kelly The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Since 1969 there have been a total of 4 accidents involving Mitsubishi MU-2 aircraft in Australia. In the same period there have been 19 accidents to other similar aircraft types (twin engine, propeller turbine power).

Statistics provided from overseas sources revealed that between 1964 and 1987, 1.6% of all MU-2 aircraft were involved in accidents annually, compared with 2.0% for the overall class of aircraft. Between 1983 and 1987 the average for the MU-2 fleet was 1% while the figure for the overall class reduced to 0.67%. It is not possible to provide figures for overseas incidents, (occurrences not involving substantial aircraft damage or serious personal injuries), involving the MU-2, because few countries have a detailed incident reporting program, and none have a system as extensive as Australia. There is no evidence from the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation records to suggest that the MU-2 has a disproportionate number of incidents when compared to similar aircraft types.
(2) The CAA is aware of all known and potential problems notified by the manufacturer and other regulatory authorities around the world.
(3) Yes. The details are as follows:
(a) On 24 May 1983 aircraft registered VH-MLU crashed near Bargo, NSW. The pilot, who was the only occupant, was killed. The factors leading to the accident were not positively established.

(b) On 15 November 1983 aircraft registered VH-CJP was damaged during a landing at Cairns, Qld. Neither of the occupants were injured. The significant factors in the accident included pilot fatigue, an uncertainty as to which pilot was in command, and a misjudgment of the height of the aircraft above the runway.

(c) On 14 July 1987 aircraft registered VH-MUK was damaged during landing at Toowoomba, Qld. None of the seven persons on board were injured. The nosewheel landing gear had collapsed following heavy contact with the runway.

(d) On 16 December 1988 aircraft registered VH-BBA was destroyed in an accident near Leonora. All ten persons on board received fatal injuries. This accident is still under investigation, and it would be improper to speculate on the likely factors which might be involved.

(4) Yes. The MU-2 was subject to the normal checks for the issue of a Certificate of Airworthiness in Australia. This followed its successful completion of similar checks in a number of other countries. Since that time all service bulletins and airworthiness directives relevant to that type have been examined and applied to those aircraft in Australia. The aircraft have been subject to the usual maintenance requirements and routine surveillance.

(5) No special attention was given to auto-pilot electrical interference during certification. The CAA was not then, nor is it now, aware of any auto-pilot electrical interference problems. There have been, however, some problems with clutches associated with the auto-pilot types used in the MU-2 which are common to various other aircraft types. These have all been addressed by Airworthiness Directive action.

Auto-pilot problems specific to MU-2 aircraft have involved water ingress into the auto-pilot disconnect switch positioning. The former has been addressed by amendment of maintenance action to call for frequent checking of the sealing of the avionics compartment and the latter is subject to promulgation of an Airworthiness Directive.

(6) The CAA is part of an international airworthiness network which ensures that all information on airworthiness problems is shared. The CAA will use this network to ensure that information affecting the safety of operations of the MU-2 is investigated and acted on. In this regard the CAA is also co-operating with the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation in a survey which the Bureau is conducting at present. The survey seeks information from pilots on any difficulties they may have experienced with the MU-2 at any time.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Housing and Aged Care, upon notice, on 5 April 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What improvements have occurred as the result of government action since the change of government in 1983 to enable young Australian families to purchase their own homes.
(2) How are prospective home buyers better off under the First Home Owners Scheme than they were under the previous assistance arrangements provided by previous governments.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The affordability of home ownership for low and moderate income first home buyers was boosted by the introduction of the First Home Owners Scheme (FHOS) on 1 October 1983. FHOS provides eligible households with assistance over five years to help buy their first homes. To date, more than 330,000 households have benefited from FHOS at a total cost of almost $1.4 billion.

Under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement (CSHA), renegotiated in 1984, there has been a significant increase in the level of funding available for low and moderate income home purchase assistance. In the five years to 1987-88, a total of 68,000 home loans were provided, compared to 50,000 in the five years to 1982-83.

At the May 1989 Premiers' Conference, States agreed on new financial arrangements for public housing funded through the CSHA. In 1989-90, the Commonwealth will provide $1010.5 million to the States and the Northern Territory all in the form of grants. Gearing of Home Purchase Assistance (HPA) funds by the States will enable a far greater number of households to be assisted into home ownership using CSHA funds from previous years. In 1988-89, 26,000 HPA loans were provided to low income households compared with an estimate for 1989-90 of 40,000 loans possible under the new arrangements. Over the next five years, about 200,000 home loans will be made available to low income households if the States take up the Commonwealth's offer.

Access to housing finance also has been improved under this Government. In the three years to June 1983, housing finance institutions made available only 734,916 loans compared with 913,741 in the three years following to June 1986, an increase of 24 per cent. In the period July 1986 to April 1989, the number of housing loans made available increased further to 949,249.

(2) A number of home ownership assistance schemes co-existed prior to the introduction of FHOS. FHOS was therefore more easily comprehensible to potential beneficiaries, than the range of schemes that it replaced.

Eligibility for FHOS is related only to income and the requirement that applicants have not previously owned a home. Earlier schemes (the Home Savings Grant (HSG) Scheme and the Home Deposit Assistance Scheme (HDAS)) also involved a savings requirement, which particularly disadvantaged low income families with children. The HSG Scheme also included an age limit and a house price limit for eligibility.

FHOS provides more generous levels of assistance than previous schemes and gives applicants the choice of three payment options designed to help bridge the deposit gap, increase borrowing capacity and/or manage repayments more easily.
Assistance under FHOS is provided over five years to help households through the difficult early years of home ownership, rather than previous schemes which only provided a one-off benefit.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 15 June 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Minister's Department employ a group of officers or other employees whose function is partly or solely investigatory or who are engaged in any form of law enforcement.

(2) If the Department employs such officers or employees-(a) what are the duties of those officers or employees, (b) what was the cost of (i) employing the officers or employees and (ii) the section or part of the Department where the officers or employees were employed in (a) 1984-85, (b) 1985-86, (c) 1986-87, (d) 1987-88 and (e) 1988-89, (c) how many officers or employees are engaged in detecting or investigating offences against the Commonwealth or breaches of laws administered by the Department, (d) how many of the personnel referred to in part (c) are employed in (i) the examination of documents or records to detect irregularities in Commonwealth procedures that might give rise to the commission of offences or in the supervision of the personnel engaged in such examination and (ii) interviewing, corresponding with or undertaking surveillance of persons in connection with the commission of offences or in the supervision of the personnel engaged in such work, (e) if there are any guidelines or rules prescribed relating to the point in an investigation when the personnel referred to in part (c) are required to (i) advise or (ii) seek assistance from the Australian Federal Police (AFP), what is the substance of those guidelines or rules, (f) at what point in an investigation do the personnel referred to in part (c), as a matter of practice, (i) advise or (ii) seek assistance from the AFP, (g) if the Department has a written agreement with the AFP governing the exchange of information between the Department and the AFP relating to investigations being undertaken, (i) what is that agreement and (ii) where may a copy of it be obtained, and (h) if there is any training provided for the personnel referred to in part (c), (i) by whom, (ii) when and where and (iii) at what cost is it provided.

(3) When it is necessary to launch a prosecution for an offence against the Commonwealth or the breach of a law administered by the Minister's Department, (a) who makes the decision to prosecute and (b) who conducts the prosecution.
(4) Does the Department provide the AFP with the information it obtains in the course of (a) an investigation or (b) a prosecution; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories does not employ a group of officers or other employees whose function is partly or solely investigatory or who are engaged in any form of law enforcement other than officers employed in the Department's Internal Audit function or those involved in the administration of the Department's normal Personnel functions. While some officers are designated as inspectors under particular legislation, for example the Ozone Protection Act 1989, the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975 and the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Amendment Act 1988, their inspectorial duties form only a small part of their overall functions. Other officers may on occasion be involved in investigatory and/or enforcement functions incidental to the normal duties of their positions. For example, officers who are employed as Station Leaders and Voyage Leaders in Antarctica may be appointed as inspectors under the Antarctic Treaty (Environment Protection) Act 1980 and the Antarctic Marine Living Resources Conservation Act 1988 and as Deputy Coroners and in these capacities may on occasions be called on to undertake investigations or law enforcement functions although their appointment would rarely need to be exercised.

(3) and (4) Any prosecutions involving the Department as complainant would be launched by the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP), other appropriate crown law officer or the Australian Federal Police (AFP) or in accordance with the advice of the DPP, other crown law authority or the AFP as appropriate.

ANSWER.PARA: (i) The prices of woodchips exported from Eden are approved by the Government on a commercial-in-confidence basis and the Minister for Resources is therefore not at liberty to disclose those prices. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 16 June 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the Basel Convention and what are its principal provisions.
(2) Was the Australian Government involved in negotiating the Basel Convention; if so (a) what is the Government's attitude to it and (b) is Australia a signatory.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Basel Convention is the Convention on the Control of Transboundary Movement of Hazardous Wastes and Their Disposal. The Convention was sponsored by the United Nations Environment Programme and was finalised at an international conference in Basel, on 22 March 1989. Its principal provisions are that contracting parties shall:
minimise the generation of hazardous and other wastes,
ensure the availability of adequate disposal facilities for such wastes,
ensure that the transboundary movement of such wastes is minimised, and

not allow the export of such wastes without the prior consent of importing countries, without being assured of environmentally sound disposal being arranged for the wastes, nor without such exports being accompanied by a movement document to track the movement to disposal.

Hazardous wastes are defined in the Convention principally by reference to a series of hazardous characteristics, such as corrosive, flammable or ecotoxic. `Other wastes' are defined as wastes collected from households and residues arising from the incineration of household wastes. The Convention specifically excludes radioactive wastes.
(2) Yes; (a) the Commonwealth Government generally supports the objectives and provisions of the Convention; (b) Australia has not yet signed the Convention.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 11 April 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What (a) percentage and (b) sum of Australia's overseas debt as at 1 April 1989 was owed by (i) the Federal Government, (ii) the State Governments, (iii) statutory authorities and (iv) the private sector.
(2) What were Australia's overseas reserves at 1= April 1989.
(3) What effect did the floating of the Australian dollar have on Australia's international debt.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) External debt can be measured on a ``gross'' basis (ie, the total amount that Australia owes to foreigners), or on a ``net'' basis (gross debt minus the amounts that foreigners owe to Australia). Statistics for both measures are presented below. Net external debt is the more relevant measure for most purposes.

Gross external debt-The Statistician publishes external debt estimates as at the last day of each quarter. As at 31 March 1989, gross external debt was estimated at $A128.6 billion, made up as follows:
the official sector (including Commonwealth and State general government and the Reserve Bank) accounted for $35.1 billion (27 per cent of the total);
public trading and financial enterprises (PTFEs) for $26.0 billion (20 per cent); and
the private sector for $67.5 billion (53 per cent).
Disaggregated figures for the official sector as at end-March 1989 have not yet been published. As at end-December 1988, the break-up was as follows:
the Commonwealth (including the Reserve Bank) accounted for $20.6 billion (17 per cent of the total); and
the States for $13.4 billion (11 per cent).

Net external debt-The Statistician provides figures on Australia's debt assets overseas, classified by official assets (mainly official reserves, but including some official lending) and other (non-official) Australian lending overseas. A public/private sector classification of Australian lending overseas is only published with a long lag, but this lending is ordinarily comprised largely of private assets. As at 31 March 1989, net external debt was estimated at $A103.2 billion and, if all non-official lending overseas is attributed to the private sector, the components were as follows:
the official sector accounted for $14.6 billion (14 per cent of the total);
PTFEs for $26 billion (25 per cent); and
the private sector for $62.6 billion (61 per cent).

(2) Australia's official reserve assets at 31 March 1989 were $A19,509 million, of which holdings of US dollars amounted to $6,267 million (32 per cent of the total), holdings of other currencies were $8,762 million (45 per cent) and other official reserves (gold, IMF Special Drawing Rights, etc) were valued at $4,480 million (23 per cent).

(3) Under a `floating' regime, exchange rate adjustments tend to be smaller but more frequent than in the case of a fixed rate regime. Economic fundamentals (notably the country's balance of payments and inflation performance), rather than the exchange rate system per se, determine the exchange rate. Accordingly, over time, effects of exchange rate changes on debt denominated in foreign currencies will tend to be similar under both systems. However, to the extent that a `floating' exchange rate rate system, together with a deregulated financial system more generally, tends to promote a more efficient, flexible and responsive economy than a fixed exchange rate rate regime and a highly regulated financial system, the former can be expected to be more successful in reducing any excessive external debt burden.
